subsection.text: In this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Admissions and amusement tax” means the tax imposed under Title 4 of this article.
“Alcoholic beverage tax” means the tax imposed under Title 5 of this article.
“Boxing and wrestling tax” means the tax imposed under Title 6 of this article.

paragraph.text: “Comptroller” means the Comptroller of the State.
“Comptroller”, unless expressly provided otherwise, includes:

subparagraph.text: an employee of the Comptroller acting within the scope of employment; and
an agent or representative of the Comptroller acting within the scope of the Comptroller’s authority.

subsection.text: “County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.
“Department” means the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
“Financial institution franchise tax” means the tax imposed under Title 8, Subtitle 2 of this article.

paragraph.text: “Income tax” means the tax imposed under Title 10 of this article.
“Income tax” includes the State income tax and county income tax.

subsection.text: “Inheritance tax” means the tax imposed under Title 7, Subtitle 2 of this article.
“Internal Revenue Code” means Title 26 of the United States Code.
“Maryland estate tax” means the tax imposed under Title 7, Subtitle 3 of this article.
“Maryland generation–skipping transfer tax” means the tax imposed under Title 7, Subtitle 4 of this article.
“Motor carrier tax” means the tax imposed under Title 9, Subtitle 2 of this article.
“Motor fuel tax” means the tax imposed under Title 9, Subtitle 3 of this article.

paragraph.text: “Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“Person”, unless expressly provided otherwise, does not include a governmental entity or a unit or instrumentality of a governmental entity.

subsection.text: “Property” means real property and personal property.
“Public service company franchise tax” means the tax imposed under Title 8, Subtitle 4 of this article.

paragraph.text: “Sales and use tax” means the tax imposed under Title 11 of this article.
“Sales and use tax” includes the tax imposed on the use of certain electricity under § 11-1A-01 of this article.
“Sales and use tax” includes the hotel surcharge imposed under § 11-102(b) of this article.

subsection.text: “Savings and loan association franchise tax” means the tax imposed under Title 8, Subtitle 3 of this article.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

subsection.text: Repealed.
“Tobacco tax” means the tax imposed under Title 12 of this article.
In this section, “legal holiday” means:

paragraph.text: the day on which a legal holiday, as defined in Article 1, § 27 of the Code, is observed; or
a federal legal holiday.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, when under State or local law, the last day to pay a tax, file a tax return, or perform any other act that relates to taxes under this article falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, performance of the act is considered timely if the act is performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday.
For purposes of this section, the last day to perform an act is the last day of any authorized extension of time.

A unit of the State government or person responsible for administering or collecting a tax shall give each notice required under this article by mailing it, in a postpaid envelope, to the person for whom the notice is intended:

paragraph.text: at the address in the most recently filed application, report, or return of the person on record; or
if no application, report, or return has been filed, at any address obtainable for the person.

subsection.text: The mailing of a notice in the manner provided in subsection (a) of this section is presumptive evidence of its receipt by the person to whom the notice is mailed.

A requirement in this article that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by a signed statement made under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the knowledge, information, and belief of the individual making the statement.
The oath or affirmation shall be made:

paragraph.text: before an individual authorized to administer oaths, who shall certify in writing to have administered the oath or taken the affirmation; or
by a signed statement that:

subparagraph.text: is in the document or attached to and made part of the document; and
is expressly made under the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: If the procedures provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section are used, the affidavit subjects the individual making it to the penalties for perjury to the same extent as an oath or affirmation made before an individual authorized to administer oaths.
A document made under oath shall be signed:

paragraph.text: for a corporation, by an officer of the corporation authorized to do so;
for a sole proprietorship, by its owner; or
for a partnership, by a partner authorized to do so.

section.text: Before any license may be issued under this article to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ a covered employee, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employer shall file with the issuing authority:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

subsection.text: A license or permit is considered renewed for purposes of this section if the license or permit is issued by a unit of State government to a person for the period immediately following a period for which the person previously possessed the same or a substantially similar license.

Before any license or permit issued by the Comptroller may be renewed, the Comptroller shall verify that the applicant has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Comptroller or the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or that the applicant has provided for payment in a manner satisfactory to the unit responsible for collection.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Evaluation” means the process of legislative review of a tax credit for which this subtitle provides.
“Evaluation committee” means a committee that is appointed to carry out an evaluation.
“Evaluation date” means the date on which an evaluation of a tax credit is to be completed.

section.text: The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: establish a system of legislative review that will determine whether a tax credit is necessary for the public interest; and
ensure that the legislative review takes place by establishing, by statute, dates for review and other legislative action.
If a tax credit has a termination date provided for by law, an evaluation shall be made of that credit on or before July 1 of the year preceding the calendar year of the termination date.
Except as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection, an evaluation shall be made of the tax credits on or before the dates specified in subsections (b) through (e) of this section.

subsection.text: On or before July 1, 2014, an evaluation shall be made of the tax credits under:

paragraph.text: § 10–702 of this article (wages paid in an enterprise zone) and § 9–103 of the Tax – Property Article (qualified property in an enterprise zone); and
Title 6, Subtitle 4 of the Economic Development Article, § 6–119 of the Insurance Article, and § 10–714 of this article (One Maryland economic development).

subsection.text: On or before July 1, 2015, an evaluation shall be made of the tax credits under:

paragraph.text: § 10–704 of this article (earned income); and
§ 10–730 of this article (film production activity).

subsection.text: On or before July 1, 2016, an evaluation shall be made of the tax credits under:

paragraph.text: § 5A–303 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, § 6–105.2 of the Insurance Article, and § 10–704.5 of this article (sustainable communities); and
§ 10–721 of this article (qualified research and development expenses).

subsection.text: On or before July 1, 2017, an evaluation shall be made of the tax credits under:

paragraph.text: § 9–230 of the Tax – Property Article, § 6–116 of the Insurance Article, and § 10–704.8 of this article (new job creating businesses); and
§ 10–726 of this article (biotechnology investment incentive).

subsection.text: Evaluation of a tax credit shall be completed by an evaluation committee appointed jointly by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House.
Each evaluation committee for a tax credit shall be appointed on or before May 31 of the year before the evaluation date of that tax modification or tax exemption.
An evaluation committee shall include at least one member of the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and at least one member of the House Committee on Ways and Means.

section.text: On or before June 30 of the year before the evaluation date of a tax credit, each evaluation committee for that tax credit shall:

paragraph.text: consult with:

subparagraph.text: the Department of Budget and Management;
the Department of Legislative Services;
the Comptroller; and
the Secretary, or the Secretary’s designee, of the department that administers the tax credit under evaluation; and

paragraph.text: prepare a plan for the evaluation.

section.text: During an evaluation, the Comptroller and the Department of Budget and Management shall:

paragraph.text: provide promptly any information that the Department of Legislative Services or an evaluation committee requests; and
otherwise cooperate with the Department of Legislative Services and the evaluation committee.

Subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, on or before October 31 of the year before the evaluation date of a tax credit, the Department of Legislative Services shall submit to the General Assembly an evaluation report on the tax credit.
The Department of Legislative Services shall make copies of the report available to the public.

subsection.text: The report required under subsection (a) of this section shall discuss:

paragraph.text: the purpose for which the tax credit was established;
whether the original intent of the tax credit is still appropriate;
whether the tax credit is meeting its objectives;
whether the purposes of the tax credit could be more efficiently and effectively carried out through alternative methods; and
the costs of providing the tax credit, including the administrative cost to the State and lost revenues to the State and local governments.

section.text: On or before December 14 of the year before the evaluation date of a tax credit, the evaluation committee shall hold a public hearing to receive, from the Comptroller and the public, testimony regarding the evaluation report.

subsection.text: Subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, on or before the 20th day of the regular session of the General Assembly in the year of the evaluation date of a tax credit, the evaluation committee for the tax credit shall submit a report to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The report required under subsection (a) of this section shall recommend whether the tax credit should be continued, with or without changes, or terminated.
The report shall be accompanied by any legislation that is needed to accomplish the recommendations in the report.

section.text: The continuation of a tax credit designated for evaluation under this subtitle is for a 5–year period and is subject to reevaluation 5 years after the previous evaluation, unless another period is set by law.
This subtitle may be cited as the “Tax Credit Evaluation Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Quarter” means a calendar quarter.
“Revenue” means revenue from a tax imposed under this article and interest and penalties related to the tax.

section.text: In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this article and in other articles of the Code, the Comptroller shall administer the laws that relate to:

paragraph.text: the admissions and amusement tax;
the alcoholic beverage tax;
the boxing and wrestling tax;
the income tax;
the Maryland estate tax;
the Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax;
the motor carrier tax;
the motor fuel tax;
the sales and use tax;
the savings and loan association franchise tax; and
the tobacco tax.

section.text: The Comptroller shall adopt reasonable regulations to administer the provisions of the tax laws listed in § 2-102 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to the requirements of § 2-110 of this subtitle and subsection (b) of this section, the Comptroller shall design the returns and other forms that, on completion, provide the information required for the administration of the tax laws listed in § 2-102 of this subtitle.

Except for variations that the differences between the federal and State income tax laws require, the forms that the Comptroller designs to administer the income tax laws shall be similar to the forms used to administer the federal income tax laws.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall keep an income tax return for 5 years from the date the return is filed. After 5 years, the Comptroller may destroy the return.
The Comptroller shall keep a sales and use tax return for 2 years from the date the return is filed. After 2 years, the Comptroller may destroy the return.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall design the license form required for:

paragraph.text: the motor fuel tax laws; and
the sales and use tax laws.

subsection.text: The Comptroller:

paragraph.text: shall determine:

subparagraph.text: the design of tax stamps and certificates required for the alcoholic beverage tax and for the tobacco tax; and
the form of any other evidence of tax payment; and

paragraph.text: may adopt any other method or device that the Comptroller considers necessary to:

subparagraph.text: prevent fraud or evasion of the alcoholic beverage tax; or
comply with any restrictions that the federal government imposes on alcoholic beverages during a war or an emergency.

subsection.text: The Comptroller:

paragraph.text: shall provide tax stamps and certificates to indicate that the alcoholic beverage tax or tobacco tax has been paid; and
may adopt reasonable regulations to prevent abuse but ensure the adequate availability of tax stamps and certificates, including regulations that:

subparagraph.text: limit excessive disbursement of tax stamps and certificates; and
require proof of need for tax stamps and certificates.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Nonresident” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article.
“Resident” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article.
“Wages” has the meaning stated in § 10-905(f) of this article.
The Comptroller shall prepare income tax tables to show the income tax for an individual.
The Comptroller shall prepare tables based on Maryland taxable income that provide for:

subparagraph.text: income intervals not exceeding $100 for Maryland taxable income; and
the State income tax due for each income interval.

paragraph.text: The State income tax for each interval is the whole dollar amount of tax for the income that is at the midway point of the interval.
The Comptroller shall prepare income tax withholding tables that show the income tax to be withheld from wages. The Comptroller may prepare separate tables for residents and nonresidents.
The withholding tables shall provide for:

subparagraph.text: wages for each withholding period allowable under § 10-909 of this article; and
the State income tax required to be withheld for a withholding period, after:

sub-subparagraph.text: an adjustment is made for the exemptions for the period; and
if there is a separate table for nonresidents, an adjustment is made to allow the exhaustion of exemptions for a nonresident before any income tax is withheld.

paragraph.text: The total amounts required under the tables to be withheld during a taxable year shall approximate the total income tax due on the wages for the year, determined as provided in subsection (f) of this section.

The Comptroller may prepare income tax percentage withholding schedules that show the percent of income tax to be withheld from wages. The Comptroller may prepare separate schedules for residents and nonresidents.
The optional percentage withholding schedules shall provide for:

subparagraph.text: wages for each withholding period allowable under § 10-909 of this article; and
the percent of State income tax required to be withheld for the withholding period, after:

sub-subparagraph.text: an adjustment is made for the exemptions for the period; and
if there is a separate schedule for nonresidents, an adjustment is made to allow the exhaustion of exemptions for a nonresident before any income tax is withheld.

paragraph.text: The total percentages required under the schedules to be withheld during a taxable year shall approximate the income tax due on the wages for the year, determined as provided in subsection (f) of this section.

subsection.text: At the option of the employer, withholdings may be made using either the withholding tables or the percentage withholding schedule.

The total income tax required to be withheld on wages for purposes of the withholding tables and withholding schedules under this section shall be calculated without regard to the marginal State income tax rates less than 4.75% set forth under § 10–105(a)(1)(i) through (iii) and (2)(i) through (iii) of this article.
Authorized employees of the Field Enforcement Bureau of the Comptroller’s Office:

paragraph.text: shall be individuals who are sworn police officers; and
have all the powers, duties, and responsibilities of a peace officer for the purpose of enforcing the laws pertaining to:

subparagraph.text: alcoholic beverage tax;
tobacco tax;
motor fuel tax;
motor carrier tax;
motor fuel and lubricants; and
transient vendors within the meaning of Subtitle 20A of Title 17 of the Business Regulation Article.

paragraph.text: The Department of State Police shall help the Field Enforcement Bureau in enforcing the motor carrier tax, motor fuel tax and motor fuel and lubricants laws.
The Comptroller shall pay the salaries and expenses of all Department of State Police staff assigned to the Field Enforcement Bureau.

subparagraph.text: Except for the Sheriff, constables and bailiffs of Baltimore County, each law enforcement officer shall enforce the alcoholic beverage tax and tobacco tax laws.
A State’s Attorney or other prosecutor may prosecute alleged violations of the alcoholic beverage tax or tobacco tax laws.

paragraph.text: The Field Enforcement Bureau:

subparagraph.text: shall advise a State’s Attorney and law enforcement officers about enforcement problems; and
otherwise may work cooperatively with law enforcement officers and prosecutors to carry out the duties of the unit.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not restrict the appropriation of money by a political subdivision of the State to aid in the enforcement of the alcoholic beverage tax and tobacco tax laws.

Each unit of the State government shall cooperate with the Comptroller’s Office by making available, on request, any information in the unit’s possession as may be of assistance in the administration and enforcement of the motor carrier tax, motor fuel tax, and motor fuel and lubricants laws.

The Field Enforcement Bureau shall cooperate with and help the federal government, other states, and local governments and law enforcement personnel of those jurisdictions to enforce the motor carrier tax, motor fuel tax, and motor fuel and lubricants laws.

section.text: If, in good faith and with reasonable grounds, the Comptroller or a peace officer of the State seizes contraband property or a conveyance used to transport contraband property under § 13-835 of this article, the Comptroller or peace officer shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-523 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: collect the taxes that the Comptroller administers or is otherwise required under this article to collect;
account for the revenue from those taxes and any other tax required to be remitted to the Comptroller; and
distribute the revenue in the manner required under Subtitles 2 through 16 of this title.

subsection.text: The requirement to make a distribution of tax revenue means to segregate, deposit, transfer, credit, disburse by warrant, or otherwise apply the revenue in accordance with the accounting practices and procedures required under the State Finance and Procurement Article and elsewhere in the Code.
Except for a distribution required under § 2-604 of this title, the requirement to distribute to an account means to make a bookkeeping entry in the accounting records of the State.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall include on the individual income tax return form a checkoff designated as the “State Chesapeake Bay and Endangered Species Fund Contribution”.
The checkoff shall state that:

subparagraph.text: the individual, or each spouse in the case of a joint return, may contribute to the State Chesapeake Bay and Endangered Species Fund the amount designated by the individual; and

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual shall deduct the amount of the contribution from any refund to which the individual is entitled; or
if the individual is not entitled to a refund, the individual shall add the amount of the contribution to the income tax to be paid with the return.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall include, with the individual income tax return package, a description of the purposes for which the State Chesapeake Bay and Endangered Species Fund was established and the purposes for which the Fund may be used.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: collect the checkoff contributions and account to the State Treasurer for the money collected;
from the contributions collected, distribute the amount necessary to administer the checkoff system to an administrative cost account; and

after the distribution under item (2) of this subsection, distribute the remainder of the money collected under this subsection to the Chesapeake Bay and Endangered Species Fund established under § 1-702 of the Natural Resources Article.

section.text: In the case of an individual described in § 7508 of the Internal Revenue Code, the period of service referred to in that section shall be disregarded in determining the due date for the following:

paragraph.text: filing a Maryland income tax return or declaration of estimated income tax under § 10-820 of this article;
filing a refund claim under § 13-1104 of this article; and
filing an appeal to the Maryland Tax Court under § 13-510 of this article, an appeal to the circuit court under § 13-532 of this article, or any further appeal permitted under Maryland law.
The Comptroller shall include on the individual income tax return form a checkoff designated as the “Maryland Cancer Fund Contribution”.
The checkoff shall state that:

subparagraph.text: the individual, or each spouse in the case of a joint return, may contribute to the Maryland Cancer Fund the amount designated by the individual; and

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual shall deduct the amount of the contribution from any refund to which the individual is entitled; or
if the individual is not entitled to a refund, the individual shall add the amount of the contribution to the income tax to be paid with the return.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall include, with the individual income tax return package, a description of the purposes for which the Maryland Cancer Fund was established and the purposes for which the Fund may be used.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: collect the checkoff contributions and account to the State Treasurer for the money collected;
from the contributions collected, distribute the amount necessary to administer the checkoff system to an administrative cost account; and

after the distribution under item (2) of this subsection, distribute the remainder of the money collected under this subsection to the Maryland Cancer Fund established under § 20-117 of the Health - General Article.
The Comptroller shall include on the individual income tax return form a checkoff designated as the “Developmental Disabilities Waiting List Equity Fund Contribution”.
The checkoff shall state that:

subparagraph.text: the individual, or each spouse in the case of a joint return, may contribute to the Waiting List Equity Fund the amount designated by the individual; and

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual shall deduct the amount of the contribution from any refund to which the individual is entitled; or
if the individual is not entitled to a refund, the individual shall add the amount of the contribution to the income tax to be paid with the return.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall include, with the individual income tax return package, a description of the purposes for which the Waiting List Equity Fund was established and the purposes for which the Fund may be used.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: collect the checkoff contributions and account to the State Treasurer for the money collected;
from the contributions collected, distribute the amount necessary to administer the checkoff system to an administrative cost account; and

after the distribution under item (2) of this subsection, distribute the remainder of the money collected under this subsection to the Waiting List Equity Fund established under § 7–205 of the Health – General Article to be used to provide community–based services to individuals who are on the Developmental Disabilities Administration waiting list and are eligible for, but not receiving, services from the Administration.

section.text: From the admissions and amusement tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute each quarter the amount necessary to administer the admissions and amusement tax laws in the previous quarter to an administrative cost account.

subsection.text: After making the distribution required under § 2–201 of this subtitle, within 20 days after the end of each quarter, the Comptroller shall distribute:

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, from the revenue from the State admissions and amusement tax on electronic bingo and electronic tip jars under § 4–102(e) of this article:

subparagraph.text: the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 20% to the General Fund of the State; and
the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 5% to the Special Fund for Preservation of Cultural Arts in Maryland, as provided in § 4–801 of the Economic Development Article; and

paragraph.text: the remaining admissions and amusement tax revenue:

subparagraph.text: to the Maryland Stadium Authority, county, or municipal corporation that is the source of the revenue; or
if the Maryland Stadium Authority and also a county or municipal corporation tax a reduced charge or free admission:

sub-subparagraph.text: 80% of that revenue to the Authority; and
20% to the county or municipal corporation.

subsection.text: From the revenue from the State admissions and amusement tax on electronic bingo and electronic tip jars in Calvert County under § 4–102(e) of this article, the Comptroller shall distribute:

paragraph.text: for fiscal year 2013, the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 8%:

subparagraph.text: $100,000 to the Boys and Girls Club of the Town of North Beach; and

the remainder to the Calvert County Youth Recreational Opportunities Fund under Title 5, Subtitle 19 of the Natural Resources Article that may only be used for a project approved by the Secretary of Natural Resources that increases youth recreational opportunities in the county;

paragraph.text: for fiscal years 2014 through 2016, from:

subparagraph.text: the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 1.5%:

sub-subparagraph.text: $100,000 to the Boys and Girls Club of the Town of North Beach; and
the remainder to the Town of North Beach;

subparagraph.text: the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 2.5% to the Town of Chesapeake Beach; and
the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 4% to the Calvert County Youth Recreational Opportunities Fund under Title 5, Subtitle 19 of the Natural Resources Article; and

paragraph.text: for fiscal year 2017 and each fiscal year thereafter, from:

subparagraph.text: the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 1.5%:

sub-subparagraph.text: $100,000 to the Boys and Girls Club of the Town of North Beach; and
the remainder to the Town of North Beach;

subparagraph.text: the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 2.5% to the Town of Chesapeake Beach; and

the revenue attributable to a tax rate of 4% to the Calvert County Board of Education for school renovation and renewal projects that may not be used to supplant county funds for public school construction.

section.text: The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the admissions and amusement tax from undistributed tax revenue attributable to the Maryland Stadium Authority, the county, or municipal corporation that is the source of the tax.

subsection.text: From the alcoholic beverage tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to administer the alcoholic beverage tax laws to an administrative cost account.
After making the distribution required under subsection (a) of this section, the Comptroller shall distribute the remaining alcoholic beverage tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.

section.text: The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the alcoholic beverage tax from the General Fund.
The Comptroller shall distribute the proceeds from sales of contraband alcoholic beverages and conveyances under § 13-841(a) of this article to the General Fund.

From the boxing and wrestling tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute each quarter the amount necessary to administer the boxing and wrestling tax laws in the previous quarter to an administrative cost account.
After making the distribution required under § 2-401 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute the remaining boxing and wrestling tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the financial institution franchise tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the financial institutions franchise tax that the Department certifies under § 8-212 of this article from the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Corporation” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article.
“County income tax” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article.
“Individual” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article.
“State income tax” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article.

section.text: From the income tax revenue from individuals, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to pay refunds relating to income tax from individuals to the income tax refund account.

subsection.text: After making the distribution required under § 2-604 of this subtitle, from the remaining income tax revenue from individuals, the Comptroller shall distribute the cost of administering the income tax laws to an administrative cost account.
The Comptroller shall include within the distribution required under this section the amount necessary for the counties’ share of the cost of administering the income tax laws.
The share of administrative costs for each county is the amount equal to the product of multiplying the cost of administering the income tax laws by a fraction:

paragraph.text: the numerator of which is the amount of county income tax from individuals collected and attributable to residents of the county; and
the denominator of which is the total amount of income tax collected from individuals and corporations.

subsection.text: After making the distributions required under §§ 2–604 and 2–605 of this subtitle, from the remaining income tax revenue from individuals, the Comptroller shall distribute to an unallocated individual revenue account the income tax revenue:

paragraph.text: with respect to which an income tax return is not filed; and
that is attributable to:

subparagraph.text: income tax withheld from salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services under Title 10 of this article; or
estimated income tax payments by individuals.

paragraph.text: In June of each year, from current collections, the Comptroller shall reserve an amount of unallocated revenue that the Comptroller estimates will be claimed on returns and refunded to taxpayers within 3 years of the date the income tax return was due to be filed, and distribute to each county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district a pro rata share of the balance of the unallocated individual income tax revenue.

The Comptroller shall adjust the amount distributed under paragraph (1) of this subsection to a county, municipal corporation, or special taxing district to allow for the proportionate part of tax claim payments for a prior calendar year made after a distribution is made to the county, municipal corporation, or special taxing district for that year.
To compute the pro rata share for a county, the Comptroller shall:

subparagraph.text: compute the amount equal to the product of multiplying the unallocated individual income tax revenue by a fraction:

sub-subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the income tax for the county collected for a calendar year; and
the denominator of which is the total income tax from individuals collected for that year; and

subparagraph.text: reduce the amount computed under item (i) of this paragraph by the pro rata share computed under paragraph (2) of this subsection for municipal corporations and special taxing districts that are located in the county.

paragraph.text: To compute the pro rata share for a municipal corporation or special taxing district, the Comptroller shall compute the amount equal to the product of multiplying the pro rata share for a calendar year for the county where the municipal corporation or district is located by a fraction:

subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the amount distributed under § 2–607 of this subtitle to that municipal corporation or special taxing district for that year; and
the denominator of which is the total income tax for that county collected for that year.

subsection.text: On or before June 30, 2009, the Comptroller shall distribute $366,778,631 from the Local Reserve Account established to comply with this section to the General Fund of the State.

paragraph.text: On or before June 30, 2010, the Comptroller shall distribute $350,000,000 from the Local Reserve Account established to comply with this section to the Education Trust Fund established under § 9–1A–30 of the State Government Article.

In each of fiscal years 2014 through 2020, the State shall pay to the Local Reserve Account $50,000,000 to repay the $350,000,000 transfer to the Education Trust Fund authorized under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

On or before June 30, 2011, the Comptroller shall distribute $200,000,000 from the Local Reserve Account established to comply with this section to the General Fund of the State for use in funding the Maryland Medicaid Program for fiscal year 2011.

In each of fiscal years 2021 through 2026, the State shall pay to the Local Reserve Account $33,333,333 to repay the $200,000,000 transfer to the General Fund authorized under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: After making the distributions required under §§ 2-604 through 2-606 of this subtitle, from the remaining income tax revenue from individuals, the Comptroller shall distribute to each special taxing district that received an income tax revenue distribution in fiscal year 1977 and to each municipal corporation an amount that, based on the certification of the Comptroller as to State income tax liability and county income tax liability of the residents of the district or municipal corporation, equals the greater of:

paragraph.text: subject to subsection (b) of this section, 17% of the county income tax liability of those residents; or
0.37% of the Maryland taxable income of those residents.

subsection.text: If the county income tax rate for a county is less than 2.6%, the amount determined under subsection (a)(1) of this section shall be multiplied by a fraction:

paragraph.text: the numerator of which is 2.6%; and
the denominator of which is the county income tax rate for the county.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall adjust the amount distributed under subsection (a) of this section to a municipal corporation or special taxing district to allow for a proportionate part of refund and interest payments for a prior calendar year made after a distribution is made to the municipal corporation or district for that year.

paragraph.text: After making the distributions required under §§ 2–604 through 2–607 of this subtitle, if it is determined that a county has not met the local funding requirements for education under § 5–202(d) of the Education Article, the Comptroller shall distribute to the county board of education an amount equal to the amount calculated under § 5–213 or § 5–213.1 of the Education Article.

After making the distributions required under §§ 2–604 through 2–607 of this subtitle and paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Comptroller shall distribute to each county the remaining income tax revenue from individuals attributable to the county income tax for that county.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall adjust the amount distributed under subsection (a) of this section to a county to allow for a proportionate part of refund and interest payments made for a prior calendar year after a distribution is made to the county for that year.
In this section, “municipality” means:

paragraph.text: a special taxing district that received an income tax revenue distribution in fiscal year 1977; or
a municipal corporation.

subsection.text: For fiscal year 1990, after making the distributions required under § 2-604 through § 2-608 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute to each municipality the amount, if any, by which:

paragraph.text: a $2 per capita increase over the amount distributed to the municipality under § 2-607 of this subtitle for the 1986 taxable year, based on the most recent census data available from the Department of Planning; exceeds
the amount distributed to the municipality under § 2-607 of this subtitle for the 1988 taxable year.

section.text: After making the distributions required under §§ 2-604 through 2-608.1 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute the remaining income tax revenue from individuals to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall make the distributions of income tax revenue from individuals attributable to county income tax periodically to a county, municipal corporation, or special taxing district.

The periodic distributions of the estimated amount to which each county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district is entitled from withholdings and estimated income taxes paid shall be made:

paragraph.text: for the 1st 3 quarters of the State’s fiscal year, as often as practicable but at least each quarter; and
for the 4th quarter of that year:

subparagraph.text: before the last day of that year, for the months of April and May; and
before August 31, for the month of June.

subsection.text: Abrogated.
The Comptroller shall make a payment of the additional amounts provided under § 2-608.1 of this subtitle on or about December 31 of the fiscal year for which the payment is made.

section.text: From the income tax revenue from corporations, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to pay refunds relating to income tax from corporations to the income tax refund account.
After making the distribution required under § 2–613 of this subtitle, of the remaining income tax revenue from corporations, the Comptroller shall distribute:

paragraph.text: 6% to the Higher Education Investment Fund established under § 15–106.6 of the Education Article; and
9.15% to the General Fund.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, after making the distributions required under §§ 2–613 and 2–613.1 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute monthly 17.2% of the remaining income tax revenue from corporations to a special fund to be distributed as provided in subsection (b) of this section.
The percent of the remaining income tax revenue from corporations distributed to a special fund to be distributed as provided in subsection (b) of this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: 24% for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2011;
9.5% for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2012; and
19.5% for each fiscal year beginning on or after July 1, 2013, but before July 1, 2016.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, from the special fund, the Comptroller shall distribute an amount equal to 17.2% of the cost to administer the income tax on corporations to an administrative cost account.
The percent of the cost to administer the income tax on corporations that is distributed to an administrative cost account shall be:

sub-subparagraph.text: 24% for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2011;
9.5% for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2012; and

subparagraph.text: 19.5% for each fiscal year beginning on or after July 1, 2013, but before July 1, 2016.

paragraph.text: After making the distribution required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Comptroller shall distribute the balance in the special fund to the Gasoline and Motor Vehicle Revenue Account in the Transportation Trust Fund.

section.text: After making the distributions required under §§ 2–613, 2–613.1, and 2–614 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute the remaining income tax revenue from corporations to the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the inheritance tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.
If, under § 7-233(d) of this article, a register of wills certifies a refund relating to the inheritance tax, the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: shall authorize the register to pay the refund from inheritance tax revenue that the register has not paid into the State Treasury; or
if the register does not have enough revenue, shall pay the refund from the General Fund of the State.

section.text: The Comptroller shall distribute the Maryland estate tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the Maryland estate tax from the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax from the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the motor carrier tax revenue and fees collected under Title 9 of this article to the Gasoline and Motor Vehicle Revenue Account of the Transportation Trust Fund.
The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the motor carrier tax from motor fuel tax revenue.
From the motor fuel tax revenue the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to pay refunds relating to the motor fuel tax and the motor carrier tax to a refund account.

After making the distributions required under § 2-1101 of this subtitle, from the remaining motor fuel tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to administer the Motor Fuel Tax Bureau of the Regulatory and Enforcement Division of the Comptroller’s Office to an administrative cost account.
After making the distributions required under §§ 2–1101 and 2–1102 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute:

paragraph.text: the remaining motor fuel tax revenue from aviation fuel to the Transportation Trust Fund; and

all remaining motor fuel tax revenue, equal to the average percentage by which the motor fuel tax rate exceeds 18.5 cents per gallon, to the Gasoline and Motor Vehicle Revenue Account in the Transportation Trust Fund.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, after making the distributions required under §§ 2–1101 through 2–1103 of this subtitle, from the remaining motor fuel tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute:

paragraph.text: 2.3% to the Chesapeake Bay 2010 Trust Fund; and
any remaining balance to the Gasoline and Motor Vehicle Revenue Account of the Transportation Trust Fund.

subsection.text: For each fiscal year beginning on or before July 1, 2015, instead of the distribution required under subsection (a)(1) of this section, the Comptroller shall distribute 2.3% of the remaining motor fuel tax revenue as follows:

paragraph.text: to the General Fund of the State:

subparagraph.text: $5,000,000 for each fiscal year beginning on or before July 1, 2011;
$5,000,000 for each of the fiscal years beginning July 1, 2012, July 1, 2013, and July 1, 2014; and
$4,624,687 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2015;

paragraph.text: $8,000,000 to the Budget Restoration Fund for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2012; and
the balance to the Chesapeake Bay 2010 Trust Fund.

section.text: The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the public service company franchise tax from the General Fund of the State.
From the sales and use tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to pay refunds relating to the sales and use tax to a refund account.

After making the distribution required under § 2-1301 of this subtitle, from the remaining sales and use tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to administer the sales and use tax laws to an administrative cost account.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, after making the distributions required under §§ 2–1301 and 2–1302 of this subtitle, of the sales and use tax collected on short–term vehicle rentals under § 11–104(c) of this article the Comptroller shall distribute:

paragraph.text: 45% to the Transportation Trust Fund established under § 3–216 of the Transportation Article; and
the remainder to the Chesapeake Bay 2010 Trust Fund.

subsection.text: For each fiscal year beginning on or before July 1, 2014, after the distribution required under subsection (a)(1) of this section, the Comptroller shall distribute the remainder of the sales and use tax collected on short–term vehicle rentals under § 11–104(c) of this article as follows:

paragraph.text: to the General Fund of the State:

subparagraph.text: $15,169,444 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2011;
$10,076,582 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2012;
$6,535,845 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2013; and
$3,049,199 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2014; and

paragraph.text: the remainder to the Chesapeake Bay 2010 Trust Fund.

section.text: After making the distributions required under §§ 2–1301 through 2–1302.1 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall pay:

paragraph.text: revenues from the hotel surcharge into the Dorchester County Economic Development Fund established under § 10–130 of the Economic Development Article; and
the remaining sales and use tax revenue into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: The Comptroller shall distribute the savings and loan association franchise tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.
The Comptroller shall pay refunds relating to the savings and loan association franchise tax from the General Fund of the State.
From the tobacco tax revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to pay refunds relating to the tobacco tax to a refund account.

After making the distribution required under § 2-1601 of this subtitle, from the remaining tobacco tax revenue the Comptroller shall distribute the amount necessary to administer the tobacco tax laws to an administrative cost account.
After making the distributions required under §§ 2-1601 and 2-1602 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall distribute the remaining tobacco tax revenue to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Judge” means an individual who serves on the Tax Court.
“Tax Court” means the Maryland Tax Court.

section.text: There is a Maryland Tax Court, which is an independent administrative unit of the State government.

subsection.text: The Tax Court has jurisdiction to hear appeals from the final decision, final determination, or final order of a property tax assessment appeal board or any other unit of the State government or of a political subdivision of the State that is authorized to make the final decision or determination or issue the final order about any tax issue, including:

paragraph.text: the valuation, assessment, or classification of property;
the imposition of a tax;
the determination of a claim for refund;
the application for an abatement, reduction, or revision of any assessment or tax; or
the application for an exemption from any assessment or tax.

subsection.text: This section does not affect any requirement that a decision, determination, or order be appealed to another unit of the State government or of a political subdivision of the State before an appeal is taken to the Tax Court.

section.text: The Tax Court may sit in Baltimore City or in the county seat of any other county.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers and duties set forth elsewhere in this title and in Title 13, Subtitle 5 of this article, the Tax Court:

paragraph.text: as to any matter before it, shall pass a written order that is signed by at least 1 of the judges;
shall have a seal for the certification of copies of orders of the Tax Court by the clerk; and
may ask the Department to perform administrative duties for the Tax Court.

subsection.text: Subject to § 3-103 of this title, Title 13 of this article, and § 14-512 of the Tax - Property Article, the Tax Court may adopt reasonable rules of procedure in accordance with the provisions for adopting regulations under Title 10, Subtitle 1, Parts I through III, V, and VI of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: The Tax Court consists of 5 judges appointed by the Governor from the qualified voters of the State.
Of the 5 judges, the Chief Judge and at least 1 other judge shall be members of the Bar of the State.
Of the 5 judges, at least:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be a resident of Baltimore City;
1 shall be a resident of the Eastern Shore; and
1 shall be a resident of the Western Shore.

subsection.text: The Tax Court may not include more than 3 judges from the same political party.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Tax Court shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a judge is 6 years and begins on the 1st Monday in June.
The terms of judges are staggered as required by the terms provided for the judges of the Tax Court on January 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a judge continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A judge who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a judge for incompetence or misconduct.
Each judge is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a majority of the judges then serving on the Tax Court is a quorum to do business.
The concurrence of a majority of the judges who hear an appeal is sufficient to decide the appeal.
A judge who is a member of the Bar of the State may hear and decide an appeal without the participation of any other judge.
From among the judges, the Governor shall appoint a Chief Judge.
An appointment as Chief Judge is effective during the term of the judge who is appointed to the position.
The Tax Court shall appoint a clerk.
The clerk is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: The clerk shall have custody of and keep as a public record:

subparagraph.text: a docket that is a full and accurate record of all proceedings in the Tax Court; and
a file of all the pleadings and exhibits in all proceedings in the Tax Court.

paragraph.text: The clerk shall issue a subpoena as required under §§ 13-520 and 13-521 of this article.
The clerk shall perform other duties that the Tax Court assigns.

subsection.text: The clerk may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding in the Tax Court.
The Tax Court may appoint 1 or more deputy clerks.
Each deputy clerk is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
A deputy clerk shall perform the duties that the Tax Court assigns, including, in the absence of the clerk, a duty of the clerk.
A deputy clerk may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding in the Tax Court.
The Tax Court may:

paragraph.text: appoint examiners to hear an appeal on the valuation of real property; and
arrange for examiners to hear appeals in the counties where the appeals arise, at times and places that promote accessibility to the examiners by the parties to the appeal.

subsection.text: After a hearing before an examiner, the examiner shall submit to the Tax Court a written recommended decision that includes the findings of fact and conclusions of law on which the recommendation is based.

section.text: The Tax Court may employ staff in accordance with the State budget:

paragraph.text: to carry out the provisions of this title and Title 13, Subtitle 5 of this article; and
to exercise the powers and to carry out the duties otherwise conferred by law on the Tax Court.

subsection.text: The principal office of the Tax Court is in Baltimore City, at a location that the Board of Public Works chooses.
The offices of the Tax Court shall be open for business:

paragraph.text: during the hours that the Governor designates; and
at any additional time as the Tax Court considers necessary.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Admissions and amusement charge”, unless expressly provided otherwise, means a charge for:

subparagraph.text: admission to a place, including any additional separate charge for admission within an enclosure;
use of a game of entertainment;
use of a recreational or sports facility;
use or rental of recreational or sports equipment; and

merchandise, refreshments, or a service sold or served in connection with entertainment at a nightclub or room in a hotel, restaurant, hall, or other place where dancing privileges, music, or other entertainment is provided.

paragraph.text: “Admissions and amusement charge” does not include a charge for admission to a political fundraising event.

subsection.text: “Game of entertainment” includes, in Anne Arundel County or Calvert County, the game of instant bingo permitted under a commercial bingo license.
“Person” includes:

paragraph.text: this State or a political subdivision, unit, or instrumentality of this State;
another state or a political subdivision, unit, or instrumentality of that state; and
a unit or instrumentality of a political subdivision of this State or of another state.

subsection.text: “Stadium Authority” means the Maryland Stadium Authority created under § 10–604 of the Economic Development Article.

In this section, “net proceeds” means the total receipts from the operation of an electronic bingo machine or electronic tip jar machine less the amount of money winnings or prizes paid out to players.
A county may impose, by resolution, a tax on:

paragraph.text: the gross receipts derived from any admissions and amusement charge in that county; and
an admission in that county for a reduced charge or at no charge to a place if there is a charge for other admissions to the place.

subsection.text: A municipal corporation may impose, by ordinance or resolution, a tax on:

paragraph.text: the gross receipts derived from any admission and amusement charge in that municipal corporation; and
an admission in that municipal corporation for a reduced charge or at no charge to a place if there is a charge for other admissions to the place.

subsection.text: The Stadium Authority may impose a tax on:

paragraph.text: the gross receipts derived from any admissions and amusement charge for an admission to a facility owned or leased by the Stadium Authority; and
an admission for a reduced charge or at no charge to a facility owned or leased by the Stadium Authority if there is a charge for other admissions to the facility.

subsection.text: A State tax is imposed on the net proceeds derived from any charge for the operation of an electronic bingo machine permitted under a commercial bingo license or an electronic tip jar machine authorized under Title 13 of the Criminal Law Article that is operated for commercial purposes.

paragraph.text: The State and local admissions and amusement taxes applicable to electronic instant bingo shall be determined on a tax–included or separately stated basis.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, other State and local admissions and amusement taxes applied under this section may be determined on a tax–included or separately stated basis.

subsection.text: The admissions and amusement tax may not be imposed by:

paragraph.text: a county on gross receipts derived from any source within a municipal corporation located in that county, if the municipal corporation imposes an admissions and amusement tax on any gross receipts or specifically exempts any gross receipts from the admissions and amusement tax;
Baltimore County on gross receipts:

subparagraph.text: of a not for profit community association that is organized and operated to promote the general welfare of the community that the association serves and the net earnings of which do not inure to the benefit of any stockholder or member of the association; or
derived from any admissions and amusement charge for any activities related to agricultural tourism;

paragraph.text: Calvert County on gross receipts that are subject to the sales and use tax;
Washington County on gross receipts from an amusement device that is subject to the license and permit requirements of Article 24, § 11–202 of the Code;
Montgomery County on gross receipts derived within an area designated as an enterprise zone under Title 5, Subtitle 7 of the Economic Development Article from a charge for:

subparagraph.text: admission to a nightclub or room in a hotel, restaurant, hall, or other place where dancing privileges, music, or other entertainment is provided; or

merchandise, refreshment, or a service sold or served in connection with entertainment at a nightclub or room in a hotel, restaurant, hall, or other place where dancing privileges, music, or other entertainment is provided; and

paragraph.text: Harford County on gross receipts derived from:

subparagraph.text: any admissions and amusement charge for golf entertainment;
any admissions and amusement charge in connection with a business that provides drive–in movie entertainment;
any admissions and amusement charge for any activities related to agricultural tourism; or
any admissions and amusement charge by a roller skating rink.

subsection.text: The admissions and amusement tax may not be imposed by a county or municipal corporation on gross receipts:

paragraph.text: derived from any charge for merchandise, refreshments, or a service sold or served at a place where:

subparagraph.text: dancing is prohibited; and
the only entertainment provided is mechanical music, radio, or television;

paragraph.text: derived from any charge for admission to:

subparagraph.text: a live boxing or wrestling match; or
a concert or theatrical event presented or offered by a not for profit group that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is organized and operated to present or offer an annual series of scheduled musical concerts; or
is organized and operated for a cultural purpose and receives a grant directly or indirectly from the Maryland State Arts Council;

paragraph.text: derived from any charge for admission to or use of:

subparagraph.text: a facility or equipment in connection with a bingo game that is operated in accordance with § 13–507 of the Criminal Law Article;
a bowling alley or lane;
a charter fishing boat; or
a nontethered hot air balloon;

paragraph.text: derived from any charge for admission or for merchandise, refreshments, or a service, if the gross receipts are used exclusively for:

subparagraph.text: a charitable, educational, or religious purpose;
a volunteer fire company or nonprofit rescue squad;
a fraternal, service, or veterans’ organization chartered by a grant of Congress; or
the improvement, maintenance, or operation of an agricultural fair, if no net earnings inure to the benefit of any stockholder or member of the association that conducts the fair; or

paragraph.text: obtained at admission and used for the cost of prizes or as money winnings distributed, as part of its operation, by a commercial bingo game in Anne Arundel County.

subsection.text: A county or a municipal corporation may exempt from the admissions and amusement tax gross receipts from any charge for admission or for merchandise, refreshments, or a service, if the gross receipts are used exclusively for community or civic improvement by a not for profit community association that is organized and operated to promote the general welfare of the community that the association serves and the net earnings of which do not inure to the benefit of any stockholder or member of the association.

A county or a municipal corporation may exempt from the admissions and amusement tax gross receipts from any charge for admission to a concert or theatrical event of a not for profit organization that is organized to present or offer any of the performing arts.
Wicomico County or a municipal corporation in Wicomico County may exempt, by ordinance or resolution, from the admissions and amusement tax gross receipts from any charge for use of tennis courts.

paragraph.text: An exemption of a class of activity by a county or municipal corporation does not alter the ability of the Stadium Authority to tax that class.
An exemption of a class of activity by the Stadium Authority does not alter the ability of a county or municipal corporation to tax that class.
In this subsection, “arts and entertainment district”, “arts and entertainment enterprise” and “qualifying residing artist” have the meanings stated in § 4–701 of the Economic Development Article.

A county or a municipal corporation may exempt from the admissions and amusement tax gross receipts from any admissions or amusement charge levied by an arts and entertainment enterprise or qualifying residing artist in an arts and entertainment district.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the admissions and amusement tax rate is:

paragraph.text: the rate that a county or municipal corporation sets, not exceeding 10% of gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax; or
the rate that the Stadium Authority sets, not exceeding 8% of gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax.

Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, the rate of the State admissions and amusement tax imposed on electronic bingo or electronic tip jars under § 4–102(e) of this subtitle is 30% of the net proceeds subject to the tax.

The rate of the State admissions and amusement tax imposed on electronic bingo or electronic tip jars in Calvert County under § 4–102(e) of this subtitle is 33% of the net proceeds subject to the tax.

If net proceeds subject to the State admissions and amusement tax imposed on electronic bingo or electronic tip jars under § 4–102(e) of this subtitle are also subject to an admissions and amusement tax imposed by a county or a municipal corporation under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: the rate of the State tax may not exceed a rate that, when combined with the rate of any county or municipal corporation tax, will exceed 35% of the net proceeds; and

the rate of any county or municipal corporation admissions and amusement tax that is applicable to net proceeds derived from electronic bingo or electronic tip jars may not exceed the rate of the admissions and amusement tax imposed by the county or municipal corporation as of January 1, 2009.

subsection.text: If gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax are also subject to the sales and use tax, a county or a municipal corporation may not set a rate so that, when combined with the sales and use tax, the total tax rate will exceed 11% of the gross receipts.

If gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax imposed by the Stadium Authority are also subject to an admissions and amusement tax imposed by a county or municipal corporation, the county or municipal corporation may not set a rate or collect the tax at a rate so that, when combined with the rate of the Stadium Authority, the total tax rate will exceed 10% of the gross receipts.
A municipal corporation may set an admissions and amusement tax rate that differs from the rate set by the county where the municipal corporation is located.
For purposes of setting admissions and amusement tax rates, a county, a municipal corporation, or the Stadium Authority may:

paragraph.text: establish different classes of admissions and amusement charges; and
set different rates of tax for those classes.

subsection.text: The admissions and amusement tax that a county, a municipal corporation, or the Stadium Authority may impose on a reduced charge or free admission is:

paragraph.text: 5 cents, if the charge for any other admission is 50 cents or less;
10 cents, if the charge for any other admission is more than 50 cents but does not exceed $1; and
15 cents, if the charge for any other admission is more than $1.

subsection.text: If a county, a municipal corporation, or the Stadium Authority changes an admissions and amusement tax rate or changes a class to which a rate applies, the county, municipal corporation, or Stadium Authority shall give the Comptroller notice of the change at least 60 days before the effective date of the change.

section.text: A person shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller the admissions and amusement tax return:

paragraph.text: on or before the 10th day of the month that follows the month in which the person has gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax; and
for other periods and on other dates that the Comptroller specifies by regulation, including periods in which the person has no gross receipts subject to the tax.

subsection.text: Each person who has gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax shall keep complete and accurate records in the form and with the information that the Comptroller requires by regulation.
The person who is required under subsection (a) of this section to keep records shall make the records available for inspection and examination by the Comptroller at any time during business hours.

The person shall keep the records required under subsection (a) of this section for 4 years, unless the Comptroller consents in writing to an earlier destruction of the records or requires in writing that the records be kept longer than 4 years.
A person who has gross receipts subject to the admissions and amusement tax shall pay the tax on those gross receipts with the return that covers the period in which those receipts are earned.

If a corporation, other than a nonstock, not for profit corporation, is required to pay the admissions and amusement tax, personal liability for the tax and interest and penalties on the tax extends to any officer of the corporation who exercises direct control over its fiscal management.

If a limited liability company, or limited liability partnership, including a limited partnership registered as a limited liability limited partnership, is required to pay the admissions and amusement tax, personal liability for the tax and interest and penalties on the tax extends to any person who exercises direct control over the fiscal management of the limited liability company or limited liability partnership.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Alcoholic beverage” means a spirituous, vinous, malt, or fermented liquor, liquid, or compound that:

subparagraph.text: is fit for beverage purposes; and
contains one–half of 1% or more of alcohol by volume.

paragraph.text: “Alcoholic beverage” includes:

subparagraph.text: beer;
distilled spirits; and
wine.

subsection.text: “Alcoholic beverage license” means an alcoholic beverage license or permit issued under Article 2B of the Code.

paragraph.text: “Beer” means a brewed alcoholic beverage.
“Beer” includes:

subparagraph.text: ale;
porter;
stout;
hard cider, as defined in Article 2B, § 1–102(a)(9–1) of the Code; and
alcoholic beverages that contain:

sub-subparagraph.text: 6% or less alcohol by volume, derived primarily from the fermentation of grain, with not more than 49% of the beverage’s overall alcohol content by volume obtained from flavors and other added nonbeverage ingredients containing alcohol; or

more than 6% alcohol by volume, derived primarily from the fermentation of grain, with not more than 1.5% of the beverage’s overall alcohol content by volume obtained from flavors and other added nonbeverage ingredients containing alcohol.

subsection.text: “Consumer” means a person who buys, possesses, or transports an alcoholic beverage for a purpose other than selling the alcoholic beverage.
“Direct wine shipper” has the meaning stated in Article 2B, § 7.5–101 of the Code.

paragraph.text: “Distilled spirits” means a distilled alcoholic beverage.
“Distilled spirits” includes:

subparagraph.text: alcohol;
brandy;
cordials;
gin;
liqueur;
rum;
vodka;
whiskey; and
solutions or mixtures of distilled spirits except fortified wines.

subsection.text: “Manufacturer” means a person who operates within the State a place of business for blending, bottling, brewing, distilling, fermenting, or rectifying an alcoholic beverage.
“Nonresident dealer” means a person who is required to obtain a nonresident dealer’s permit under Article 2B, § 2–101(i) of the Code.
“Person” includes:

paragraph.text: this State or a political subdivision, unit, or instrumentality of this State;
another state or a political subdivision, unit, or instrumentality of that state; and
a unit or instrumentality of a political subdivision of this State or of another state.

subsection.text: “Resident dealer” means a person who is required to obtain a resident dealer’s permit under Article 2B, § 2–101(w) of this Code.

paragraph.text: “Retail dealer” means a person who buys an alcoholic beverage for sale to a consumer.
“Retail dealer” includes a county department of liquor control or liquor control board that operates a dispensary.

subsection.text: “Tax stamp” means a device in the design and denomination that the Comptroller authorizes for the purpose of being affixed to a container of distilled spirits as evidence that the alcoholic beverage tax is paid.

paragraph.text: “Wholesaler” means a person who buys or imports an alcoholic beverage for sale to another person for resale.
“Wholesaler” includes a county department of liquor control or liquor control board that operates a wholesale dispensary.
“Wine” means a fermented alcoholic beverage.
“Wine” includes:

subparagraph.text: carbonated, flavored, imitation, sparkling, or still wine;
champagne;
cider;
fortified wine;
perry;
sake; and
vermouth.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 5-104 of this subtitle, a tax is imposed on any alcoholic beverage in the State.

A tax is imposed on each person who sells or consigns an alcoholic beverage in the State from a jurisdiction outside the State, if the Comptroller finds that, in connection with the solicitation, sale, and distribution of alcoholic beverages, the jurisdiction:

paragraph.text: requires a tax, assessment, or charge that is greater for alcoholic beverages consigned from a Maryland licensee or permit holder than the amount required for alcoholic beverages consigned from a licensee or permit holder in another jurisdiction; and
discriminates in fact against the licensee or permit holder of the State.
A county, municipal corporation, special taxing district, or other political subdivision of the State may not impose a tax on any alcoholic beverage.
The Comptroller may not impose the tax under subsection (b) of this section on a person who has distillery plants in this and another state.

subsection.text: A rebuttable presumption exists that any alcoholic beverage in the State is subject to the alcoholic beverage tax.

An alcoholic beverage on which the alcoholic beverage tax is not paid is a contraband alcoholic beverage if it is delivered, possessed, sold, or transported in the State in a manner that is not authorized:

paragraph.text: under this title; or
under Article 2B of the Code.

subsection.text: The person who possesses an alcoholic beverage has the burden of proving that the alcoholic beverage is not subject to the alcoholic beverage tax.

paragraph.text: The alcoholic beverage tax does not apply to an alcoholic beverage that is:

subparagraph.text: brought into the State by a person in accordance with:

sub-subparagraph.text: an import-export permit under Article 2B, § 2-101(j) of the Code;
a nonbeverage permit under Article 2B, § 2-101(c) of the Code; or
a nonresident storage permit under Article 2B, § 2-101(p) of the Code;

subparagraph.text: sold or delivered by a person who holds a Class E, F, or G alcoholic beverage license, while the licensee is operating an aircraft, vessel, or train outside boundaries of the State, including airspace and waterways;
beer or wine that is family-produced and is brought into, possessed, or transported in the State by an individual who is a member of that family if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual is at least 21 years of age; and
the beer or wine is for personal use or for entry in a licensed national family beer and wine exhibition; or

subparagraph.text: brought into the State by a person for storage pending shipment outside of the State, if the alcoholic beverage:

sub-subparagraph.text: is not held for sale, consignment, or delivery in the State;
is under a customs bond; and
is stored in a public bonded warehouse.

paragraph.text: The exemption under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection does not apply to an alcoholic beverage sold or delivered by a person who holds a Class E, F, or G alcoholic beverage license while the licensee is operating an aircraft, vessel, or train within the boundaries of the State, including airspace and waterways.
The alcoholic beverage tax does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: an alcoholic beverage bought by a person whom a proper authority of the United States allows to buy alcoholic beverages for sale and use on a federal reservation in the State where the person is assigned;
wine bought and used for sacramental purposes by a religious organization affiliated with and recognized by a generally acknowledged religious faith; or
wine or distilled spirits bought and used for medicinal purposes by a bona fide hospital.

paragraph.text: A person under paragraph (1) of this subsection who pays the alcoholic beverage tax may obtain the exemption by filing a claim for refund with the Comptroller.
The alcoholic beverage tax does not apply to an alcoholic beverage that a consumer at least 21 years of age brings into the State for personal use:

subparagraph.text: if the quantity brought from within the continental United States does not exceed:

sub-subparagraph.text: at any one time, one quart;
in 1 calendar month, two quarts; and
a total of 1 gallon in the consumer’s possession at any one time;

subparagraph.text: if the quantity brought from American Samoa, Guam, or the Virgin Islands of the United States does not exceed 1 gallon; or
if the total quantity brought from any other place outside the continental United States does not exceed 1 gallon, the 1st quart of that gallon.

paragraph.text: A consumer under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection may obtain the exemption for the 1st quart by:

subparagraph.text: filing an application with the Comptroller on the form the Comptroller requires; and
paying the alcoholic beverage tax on the quantity of alcoholic beverages that exceeds 1 quart.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the alcoholic beverage tax rate for distilled spirits is:

paragraph.text: $1.50 for each gallon or 39.63 cents for each liter; and
if distilled spirits contain a percentage of alcohol greater than 100 proof, an additional tax, for each 1 proof over 100 proof, of 1.5 cents for each gallon or 0.3963 cents for each liter.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the alcoholic beverage tax rate for wine is 40 cents for each gallon or 10.57 cents for each liter.
Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the alcoholic beverage tax rate on beer is 9 cents for each gallon or 2.3778 cents for each liter.
The tax imposed under § 5-102(b) of this subtitle shall equal the amount that the discriminating jurisdiction charges a Maryland licensee or permit holder.
A person who holds a Class E, F, or G alcoholic beverage license shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller an alcoholic beverage tax return:

paragraph.text: on or before the 25th day of the month that follows the month in which the person sells any alcoholic beverage within the boundaries of the State; and
if the Comptroller so specifies, by regulation, on other dates for each month in which the licensee does not sell any alcoholic beverages in the State.

subsection.text: Each manufacturer and each wholesaler shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller an alcoholic beverage tax return:

paragraph.text: on or before the 10th day of the month that follows the month in which:

subparagraph.text: the manufacturer or wholesaler sells or delivers any alcoholic beverage in the State;

a manufacturer that brews malt beverages, under a Class 6 pub-brewery license, transfers the malt beverages for consumption on the restaurant premises in accordance with federal alcohol tax laws and regulations; or

a manufacturer that brews malt beverages, under a Class 7 micro-brewery license, transfers the malt beverages for consumption off the micro-brewery licensed premises in accordance with federal alcohol tax laws and regulations; and

paragraph.text: if the Comptroller so specifies, by regulation, on other dates for each month in which the manufacturer or wholesaler does not sell, deliver, or transfer any alcoholic beverage in the State.

subsection.text: A nonresident dealer shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller an alcoholic beverage tax return:

paragraph.text: on or before the 15th day of the month that follows the month in which the nonresident dealer delivers beer into the State; and
