subsection.text: “Federal generation-skipping transfer tax” means the tax imposed by § 2601 of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Generation-skipping transfer” means a transfer subject to the federal generation-skipping transfer tax.
“Original transferor” means an individual who makes a transfer of property that results in the imposition of the federal generation-skipping transfer tax.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a tax is imposed on a generation-skipping transfer that occurs at the same time and as a result of the death of an individual, if:

paragraph.text: the original transferor was a resident of this State on the date of the original transfer; or

subparagraph.text: the original transferor was not a resident of this State on the date of the original transfer; and
the generation-skipping transfer includes property having a situs in this State.

subsection.text: The Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax does not apply to a direct skip, as defined under § 2612 of the Internal Revenue Code.

section.text: The Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax is the amount of the federal credit.
The value of property included in a generation-skipping transfer is the same value as determined under Chapter 13 of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: The person required to file a federal generation-skipping transfer tax return on which a federal credit is allowable shall complete and file a Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax return with the Comptroller on or before the last day for filing the federal return.

If, after a person files a Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax return, the federal generation-skipping transfer tax is increased, the person shall complete and file an amended return with the Comptroller when the additional federal tax is paid.

section.text: The person required to pay the federal generation-skipping transfer tax shall pay the Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax to the Comptroller on or before the last day for filing a Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax return.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Company” means an association, corporation, or joint-stock company.

paragraph.text: “Financial institution” means:

subparagraph.text: a credit company;
except as provided in paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection, a finance company;
an international banking facility;
a loan company;
a mortgage company;
a safe-deposit company; and
a savings and loan association.

paragraph.text: “Financial institution” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a finance company that makes loans only to farmers for agricultural purposes;
a company licensed under the federal Small Business Investment Act of 1958;
a corporation that elects to be taxed as a small business corporation under Subchapter S of the Internal Revenue Code;
an entity that is a real estate mortgage investment conduit as defined in the Internal Revenue Code;
a limited liability company; or
a commercial bank, savings bank, trust company, or company that substantially competes with national banks in the State.

subsection.text: “Savings and loan association” means:

paragraph.text: a savings and loan association that:

subparagraph.text: is organized under the laws of this State;
is organized under the laws of another state and is admitted to do business in this State; or
is organized under the laws of the United States and has an office in this State; or

paragraph.text: a savings bank chartered by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
“Savings bank” means a company or other institution that is organized to receive deposits of money and pay interest on the deposits.
“Savings bank” does not include a bank with capital stock.

section.text: The franchise taxes under this title are imposed for the privilege of doing business in the State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Approved foreign trade zone” means an area designated as a foreign trade zone under Title 5, Subtitle 8 of the Economic Development Article.
“Taxable net earnings” means the net earnings of a financial institution computed under § 8-204 of this subtitle and modified under §§ 8-205 and 8-206 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: For all taxable years beginning before January 1, 2001, a franchise tax, measured by taxable net earnings, is imposed annually on each financial institution existing or doing business in the State during any part of the fiscal year of the financial institution.

For all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, the financial institution franchise tax is terminated, and Maryland taxable income of financial institutions shall be subject to taxation under Title 10 of this article.

subsection.text: A county, municipal corporation, special taxing district, or other political subdivision of the State may not impose on a savings bank or savings and loan association any tax other than its regular tax on property.

section.text: The financial institution franchise tax rate is 7% of taxable net earnings as determined under §§ 8-204 through 8-206 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A financial institution shall compute its net earnings:

paragraph.text: based on the accounting period used as its fiscal year; and
subject to the modifications required under this section, in the manner that a corporation computes, for purposes of the income tax, the Maryland modified income.

subsection.text: A financial institution shall add to its net earnings computed under subsection (a) of this section the amounts that, even if otherwise allowed to be subtracted under § 10–307(b) and (g)(1) and (4) of this article, equal:

paragraph.text: profit realized from the sale or exchange of bonds issued by this State or a political subdivision of this State;
dividends received from foreign corporations and included in federal gross income under § 78 of the Internal Revenue Code;
interest derived from a United States obligation;
State tax–exempt interest received from a mutual fund and allowed to be subtracted under § 10–307(g)(4) of this article; and
interest excluded from federal gross income under § 103 of the Internal Revenue Code and derived from a bond:

subparagraph.text: issued by a state or a public corporation, special district, political subdivision of a state or their instrumentalities; or
under § 150 of the Internal Revenue Code, treated as a bond issued by a state or a public corporation, special district, or political subdivision of a state or their instrumentalities.

subsection.text: A financial institution shall subtract from its net earnings computed under subsection (a) of this section interest expense incurred to purchase or carry a bond as defined in subsection (b)(5) of this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Foreign person” means:

sub-subparagraph.text: an individual who is not a resident of the United States;
a company, partnership, or trust that is not organized under the laws of the United States or of a state; and
a foreign branch of a company organized under the laws of the United States or of a state.

subparagraph.text: “Foreign person” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: a foreign government or any of its units;
an international organization or any of its agencies;
an international banking facility; or
a company or partnership that is not organized under the laws of the United States or of a state and that has an office and activities within an approved foreign trade zone.

paragraph.text: “International banking facility” means a financial institution that:

subparagraph.text: qualifies as an international banking facility under the laws of the United States or under regulations that the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System adopts;
is located in a county where an approved foreign trade zone is located; and

sub-subparagraph.text: makes, arranges for, places, or services a loan to a foreign person for use outside the United States or in an approved foreign trade zone in the United States; or
derives earnings from a foreign exchange trading or hedging transaction that is related to a loan described in item 1 of this item.

paragraph.text: “Liability” means the total liabilities shown in the records of an international banking facility.

subsection.text: In computing taxable net earnings, an international banking facility shall:

paragraph.text: deduct the qualifying amount computed under subsection (c) of this section to the extent that the amount is not deductible in computing its federal taxable income; or
add any loss computed under subsection (c) of this section to its taxable net earnings.

To compute the qualifying amount allowed under this section, an international banking facility shall determine its gross earnings derived, directly or indirectly, from any foreign exchange trading or hedging transaction that relates to making, arranging for, placing, or servicing a loan to a foreign person if:

subparagraph.text: substantially all of the proceeds of that loan are used outside the United States; or
all of the proceeds are used in an approved foreign trade zone by:

sub-subparagraph.text: a foreign individual;
an individual residing in the United States; or
a foreign branch of a company that is organized under the laws of the United States or of a state, is not a bank, and has at least 80% ownership or control of the foreign branch.

paragraph.text: From the gross earnings computed under paragraph (1) of this subsection, an international banking facility shall subtract all deductions or expenses, directly or indirectly, related to those gross earnings.

From the adjusted gross earnings calculated under paragraph (2) of this subsection, an international banking facility shall subtract the product of multiplying the adjusted gross earnings by a fraction:

subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the fiscal year average amount of liability that was neither owed to nor received from a foreign person; and
the denominator of which is the fiscal year average amount of liability that was owed to or received from any person.

subsection.text: In computing taxable net earnings, a financial institution with net earnings derived outside the State shall allocate its net earnings, in the manner that the Department requires, based on the gross volume of the transactions of the financial institution inside and outside the State.

In computing taxable net earnings, a financial institution shall include only that part of interest derived from the trade or business, in this State, of the subsidiaries of the financial institution, if the financial institution is a holding company because its only activities are to:

paragraph.text: maintain and manage intangible investments; and
collect and distribute income from intangible investments.

section.text: A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax equal to the estimated tax paid under § 8-210(b) of this subtitle.

A savings bank or savings and loan association doing business outside this State may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax equal to the amount paid to another jurisdiction as:

paragraph.text: a tax based on savings accounts or saving share accounts bought in this State;
a tax on gross receipts from business done in this State; or
a tax on income derived from business done in this State.

subsection.text: Each financial institution existing or doing business in the State during any part of the fiscal year of the financial institution shall complete, under oath, and file with the Department a financial institution franchise tax return on or before the 15th day of the 3rd month after the end of that fiscal year.

paragraph.text: Each financial institution that reasonably expects its financial institution franchise tax for a year to exceed $1,000 shall complete, under oath, and file with the Department a declaration of estimated tax, on or before the 15th day of the 4th month of the accounting period used as the fiscal year of the financial institution.

A financial institution required under paragraph (1) of this subsection to file a declaration of estimated tax for a taxable year shall complete and file with the Department a quarterly estimated tax return on or before the 15th day of the 6th, 9th, and 12th months of that year.

subsection.text: To properly identify persons listed in a return or document, a person shall include in a return or document the Social Security or other identifying number that the Department requires.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a financial institution shall pay the financial institution franchise tax with the return that covers the period for which the tax is due.
Each financial institution required to file quarterly estimated financial institution franchise tax returns shall pay:

paragraph.text: at least 25% of the estimated financial institution franchise tax shown on the declaration or amended declaration for a taxable year:

subparagraph.text: with the declaration or amended declaration that covers the year; and
with each quarterly return for that year; and

paragraph.text: any unpaid financial institution franchise tax for the year shown on the financial institution franchise tax return that covers that year, with the return.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the laws that relate to the financial institution franchise tax, consistent with this subtitle and with Title 10 of this article;

adopt reasonable regulations to administer the provisions of laws that relate to the financial institution franchise tax, including regulations that establish, without regard to the methods required under Title 10 of this article, methods for allocation of net earnings based on gross volume of transactions;
design the returns and other forms that, on completion, provide the information required for the administration of the financial institution franchise tax law;
collect the financial institution franchise tax revenue, including penalties and interest; and
certify that revenue to the Comptroller.

section.text: If a financial institution franchise tax refund claim under § 13-901 of this article is allowed, the Department shall certify the amount to the Comptroller for payment.

A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax for wages paid to qualified employees as provided under Title 6, Subtitle 3 of the Economic Development Article.

A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax for neighborhood and community assistance contributions as provided under § 6-404 of the Housing and Community Development Article.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 467 OF 2012 //
A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax for:

paragraph.text: wages paid to a qualified employee with a disability; and

subparagraph.text: child care provided or paid for by a business entity for the children of a qualified employee with a disability as provided under § 21–309 of the Education Article; or
transportation provided or paid for by the business entity for a qualified employee with a disability as provided under § 21–309 of the Education Article.

section.text: A financial institution may claim a State tax credit against the financial institution franchise tax payable under this subtitle as provided under § 9-230 of the Tax - Property Article.
A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax for employer-provided long-term care insurance as provided under § 10-710 of this article.

A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax for One Maryland project costs and start–up costs as provided under Title 6, Subtitle 4 of the Economic Development Article.

A financial institution may claim a credit against the financial institution franchise tax for the cost of providing commuter benefits to the business entity’s employees as provided under § 2-901 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: For all taxable years beginning before January 1, 2001, a franchise tax, measured by deposits held in the State, is imposed, for each calendar year, on each savings and loan association.
For all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, the savings and loan association franchise tax is terminated.

section.text: The savings and loan association franchise tax rate is 0.013% of the total withdrawal value of the deposits that a savings and loan association holds in the State on December 31st.

A savings and loan association organized under the laws of this State and doing business outside this State may claim a credit against the savings and loan association franchise tax in an amount that equals any tax paid to another jurisdiction as a franchise tax on deposits held in this State.

Each savings and loan association that, on December 31, holds deposits in the State shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller a savings and loan association franchise tax return, on or before April 15 of the next year.
A savings and loan association shall pay the savings and loan association franchise tax with the return that covers the period for which the tax is due.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Delivered for final consumption” means delivered by a public service company in its service area as measured at the customer meter or other point of final delivery.

paragraph.text: “Gross receipts” means total operating revenue.
“Gross receipts” includes:

subparagraph.text: gross or total earnings and total receipts;

for a telephone company, the full amount of approved and applicable federal and State tariff charges for telephone lifeline service without the discount provided by § 8–201(c) of the Public Utilities Article; and

for a telecommunications company providing interstate long distance telecommunications service, the gross charges from the sale of long distance telecommunications service that originates or terminates in the State and for which a charge is made to a service address located in the State, regardless of where the amount is billed or paid.

paragraph.text: “Gross receipts” does not include:

subparagraph.text: any revenue that a public service company derives from an activity other than an electric, gas, or telephone business; or
net uncollectible revenue.

paragraph.text: For a public service company engaged in a telephone business in the State, gross receipts does not include:

subparagraph.text: gross charges from the sale by the public service company to another public service company subject to the tax imposed by this subtitle of a service or product for resale;
gross charges from the sale by the public service company of Internet access service by which a connection is provided between a computer and the Internet; or
gross charges from the sale of telecommunications service obtained by using a prepaid telephone calling arrangement, as defined in § 11–101 of this article.

paragraph.text: For a public service company engaged in the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or gas in the State:

subparagraph.text: “gross receipts” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: except as provided in item (ii)2 and 3 of this paragraph, gross charges for the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas or for distribution or delivery–related services; and

competitive transition charges, intangible transition charges, and any other surcharge or other cost–recovery mechanism authorized for recovery of transition costs or the costs of demand side management or other energy conservation programs, universal service or other public purpose programs, or consumer education programs; and

subparagraph.text: “gross receipts” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: gross charges from the sale of electricity or natural gas;

gross charges from the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas to another public service company subject to the tax imposed under § 8–402 of this subtitle if the buyer intends to resell the electricity or natural gas; or
gross charges from an interstate transmission network or from the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas to a customer located in another state.

subsection.text: “Long distance telecommunications service” means telecommunications service for a telecommunication that does not originate and terminate in the same local calling area.
“Production activity” has the meaning stated in § 11-101 of this article.
“Public service company” means a person:

paragraph.text: engaged in a telephone business in the State; or
engaged in the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas in the State.

subsection.text: A franchise tax, measured by gross receipts, is imposed, for each calendar year, on each public service company:

paragraph.text: engaged in a telephone business in the State; or
engaged in the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas in the State.

subsection.text: The tax imposed under subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a public service company that is:

paragraph.text: a county;
a municipal corporation; or
a nonprofit electric cooperative.

In addition to any tax imposed under § 8-402 of this subtitle, a franchise tax is imposed for each calendar year on each public service company engaged in the transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas in the State.
The tax imposed under this section is measured by kilowatt hours of electricity or therms of natural gas delivered by the public service company for final consumption in the State.

subsection.text: The tax imposed under subsection (a) of this section does not apply to therms of natural gas delivered for final consumption by a public service company that is:

paragraph.text: a county; or
a municipal corporation.

subsection.text: The rate of the franchise tax imposed under § 8-402 of this subtitle is 2% of gross receipts derived from business in the State.
The rate of the tax imposed under § 8-402.1 of this subtitle is:

paragraph.text: 0.062 cents for each kilowatt hour of electricity delivered by the public service company for final consumption in the State; and
0.402 cents for each therm of natural gas delivered by the public service company for final consumption in the State.

subsection.text: Each public service company that, in a calendar year, has gross receipts derived from business in the State or delivers electricity or natural gas for final consumption in the State shall complete, under oath, and file with the Department a public service company franchise tax return, on or before March 15th of the next year.

paragraph.text: Each public service company that reasonably expects its public service company franchise tax for a year to exceed $1,000 shall complete, under oath, and file with the Department a declaration of estimated tax, on or before April 15 of that year.

A public service company required under paragraph (1) of this subsection to file a declaration of estimated tax for a taxable year shall complete and file with the Department a quarterly estimated tax return on or before June 15, September 15, and December 15 of that year.

subsection.text: A public service company shall file with the return an attachment that states any information that the Department requires to determine gross receipts derived from business in the State or kilowatt hours or therms of natural gas delivered for final consumption in the State.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each public service company shall pay the public service company franchise tax with the return that covers the period for which the tax is due.
A public service company required to file estimated public service company franchise tax returns under § 8-404(b) of this subtitle shall pay:

paragraph.text: at least 25% of the estimated public service company franchise tax shown on the declaration or amended declaration for a taxable year:

subparagraph.text: with the declaration or amended declaration that covers the year; and
with each quarterly return for that year; and

paragraph.text: any unpaid public service company franchise tax for the year shown on the public service company franchise tax return that covers that year, with the return.

subsection.text: A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax equal to the estimated tax paid under § 8-405(b) of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Subject to the limitations of this subsection, a public service company, including any multijurisdictional public service company, may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax in the amount of $3 for each ton of Maryland–mined coal that the public service company purchased in the calendar year.
The credit under this subsection may not be claimed for Maryland–mined coal purchased in a calendar year beginning after December 31, 2020.
This paragraph applies only to credits claimed under this subsection for calendar years beginning on or after January 1, 2007.
The amount claimed as a credit under this subsection may not exceed the amount approved by the Department under this paragraph.

By January 15 of the calendar year following the end of the calendar year in which the Maryland–mined coal was purchased, a public service company, or a cogenerator or electricity supplier as defined in § 10–704.1 of this article, shall submit an application to the Department for approval of the credit allowed under this paragraph.
Subject to subparagraph (vi) of this paragraph, the total amount of credits approved by the Department under this paragraph for any calendar year may not exceed:

sub-subparagraph.text: $4,500,000 for a calendar year beginning after December 31, 2008, but before January 1, 2013;
$6,000,000 for a calendar year beginning after December 31, 2012, but before January 1, 2015; or
$3,000,000 for a calendar year beginning after December 31, 2014, but before January 1, 2021.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (vi) of this paragraph, if the total amount of credits applied for in any calendar year under this paragraph exceeds the maximum specified under subparagraph (iv) of this paragraph, the Department shall approve a credit under this paragraph for each applicant in an amount equal to the product of multiplying the credit applied for by the applicant times a fraction:

sub-subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the maximum specified under subparagraph (iv) of this paragraph; and
the denominator of which is the total of all credits applied for by all applicants under this paragraph for the calendar year.

Of the total credits approved for any calendar year beginning after December 31, 2006, but before January 1, 2021, the Department shall reserve $2,250,000 of the credits for purchases of Maryland–mined coal that will be used by a facility in Maryland.

If the total amount of credits applied for by all applicants for any calendar year for the purchase of Maryland–mined coal that will be used in Maryland exceeds $2,250,000, the Department shall approve a credit under this paragraph for each applicant in an amount equal to the product of multiplying the credit applied for by the applicant times a fraction:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is $2,250,000; and
the denominator of which is the total of all credits applied for by all applicants under this paragraph for the calendar year for the purchase of Maryland–mined coal that will be used in Maryland.

subparagraph.text: On or before February 15 of the calendar year following the end of the calendar year in which the Maryland–mined coal was purchased, the Department shall certify to each applicant claiming a credit the amount of the tax credits approved by the Department for that applicant under this paragraph.

paragraph.text: To prevent actual multiple taxation of the sale of interstate long distance telecommunications service, a long distance telecommunications company, upon proof that it has paid a properly due excise, sales and use, or gross receipts tax in another state on a sale the gross receipts from which are subject to taxation under this subtitle, shall be allowed a credit against the public service company franchise tax for the amount paid.
The credit permitted under this subsection may not exceed the tax imposed under this subtitle.

section.text: A telephone company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax equal to all approved and applicable federal and State tariff charges for telephone lifeline service not billed to eligible subscribers as provided in § 8–201 of the Public Utilities Article.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the laws that relate to the public service company franchise tax;
adopt reasonable regulations to administer the provisions of laws that relate to the public service company franchise tax;
design the returns and forms that, on completion, provide the information required for the administration of the public service company franchise tax laws;
collect the public service company franchise tax revenue, including penalties and interest;
pay that revenue into the General Fund of the State; and
certify to the Comptroller that revenue.

subsection.text: The public service company franchise tax with respect to gross receipts from telecommunications service shall be added to and disclosed as an element of the public service company’s charge to the customer for the service.
A public service company may surcharge its customers for the public service company franchise tax imposed under § 8-402.1 of this subtitle.

section.text: A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax for wages paid to qualified employees as provided under Title 6, Subtitle 3 of the Economic Development Article.

A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax for neighborhood and community assistance as provided under § 6-404 of the Housing and Community Development Article.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 467 OF 2012 //
A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax for:

paragraph.text: wages paid to a qualified employee with a disability; and

subparagraph.text: child care provided or paid for by a business entity for the children of a qualified employee with a disability as provided under § 21–309 of the Education Article; or
transportation provided or paid for by the business entity for a qualified employee with a disability as provided under § 21–309 of the Education Article.

section.text: A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax for employer-provided long-term care insurance as provided under § 10-710 of this article.

subsection.text: A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax in an amount equal to:

paragraph.text: .002 cents for each kilowatt hour of electricity in excess of 500 million up to 1,500 million kilowatt hours during a calendar year delivered for final consumption to a single industrial customer for use in a production activity at the same location in the State; and

0.0455 cents for each kilowatt hour of electricity in excess of 1,500 million kilowatt hours during a calendar year delivered for final consumption to a single industrial customer for use in a production activity at the same location in the State.

subsection.text: A public service company may claim a credit against the public service company franchise tax in an amount equal to the tax imposed for each therm of natural gas delivered for final consumption in the State to an industrial customer for use in a production activity in the State.

The Public Service Commission shall require that the credits allowed under this section are passed through to the customers to whom the electricity or natural gas on which the credits are based is delivered.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Aviation fuel” means:

paragraph.text: aviation gasoline; or
turbine fuel.

subsection.text: “Aviation gasoline” means gasoline that:

paragraph.text: meets the aviation gasoline standards of specification D-910 of the American Society for Testing and Materials, as amended from time to time; and
is used to propel gasoline-powered aircraft.

subsection.text: “Clean-burning fuel” means, when used for motor vehicle propulsion:

paragraph.text: natural gas;
liquefied natural gas;
liquefied petroleum gas;
hydrogen;
electricity; or
any other fuel at least 85% of which is one or more of the following:

subparagraph.text: methanol;
ethanol;
any other alcohol; or
ether.

paragraph.text: “Gasoline” means a product that:

subparagraph.text: is used as fuel in a spark ignited, internal combustion engine; or
is designated as gasoline by the Comptroller.

paragraph.text: “Gasoline” includes:

subparagraph.text: casinghead gasoline;
absorption gasoline;
other natural gasoline; and
aviation gasoline.

subsection.text: “Motor fuel” means:

paragraph.text: gasoline; or
special fuel.

subsection.text: “Motor vehicle” means a vehicle that:

paragraph.text: is self-propelled;
is designed to be operated on a public highway; and
is not operated only on rails.
“Special fuel” means a product that is usable as fuel in an internal combustion engine.
“Special fuel” includes clean-burning fuel except electricity.
“Special fuel” does not include gasoline.

subsection.text: “Turbine fuel” means Jet A, A-1, or B fuel that is used to propel turbine powered aircraft.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Commercial motor vehicle” means any motor vehicle used or maintained for the transportation of persons or property that:

subparagraph.text: has 2 axles and an operating or registered gross vehicle weight that exceeds 26,000 pounds;
has 3 or more axles; or
is used in combination with another vehicle and has an operating or registered gross combined weight that exceeds 26,000 pounds.

paragraph.text: “Commercial motor vehicle” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a privately owned antique truck that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is registered as a historic motor vehicle under § 13–936 of the Transportation Article; and
displays appropriate registration plates that the Motor Vehicle Administration issues;

subparagraph.text: a commercial motor vehicle that is operated:

sub-subparagraph.text: by a state or a subdivision of a state;
by the United States;
by a joint unit of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: this State and the United States and other states; or
this State and another state;

sub-subparagraph.text: by or for a state, political subdivision of a state, or private school as a school bus;
by a volunteer or paid fire department or rescue squad as fire or rescue equipment;
by a licensed vehicle dealer during a road test for sale, if the vehicle displays dealer registration plates that the Motor Vehicle Administration issues; or

by a person as a privately owned bus used only in the transportation system of a county, municipal corporation, special taxing district, or other political subdivision to transport the public on a regular schedule between fixed termini as those terms are defined in the Transportation Article;

subparagraph.text: a multipurpose passenger vehicle as defined in § 11–136.2 of the Transportation Article;
a multipurpose passenger vehicle or truck that does not exceed 3/4 ton capacity when towing:

sub-subparagraph.text: a camping trailer as defined in § 11–106 of the Transportation Article; or
a travel trailer as defined in § 11–170 of the Transportation Article; or

subparagraph.text: a farm truck as defined in § 13–921 of the Transportation Article or a farm area motor vehicle as defined in § 13–935 of the Transportation Article that has 2 axles and a registered or operating gross or combination weight of less than 40,001 pounds.

paragraph.text: “Motor carrier” means a person who operates or causes the operation of a commercial motor vehicle on a highway in this State.
“Motor carrier” includes:

subparagraph.text: a lessor of a commercial motor vehicle who provides or buys the motor fuel used to operate the vehicle or pays for it as a part of rental or other costs; and
a lessee whose lease entitles the lessee to receive a credit or refund for motor fuel that the lessor buys.

subsection.text: A tax is imposed on each motor carrier who operates or causes the operation of a commercial motor vehicle on a highway in this State.
The tax under this section is imposed whether the commercial motor vehicle is:

paragraph.text: owned by or leased to the motor carrier;
operated loaded or empty; or
operated for compensation or for no compensation.

section.text: The motor carrier tax imposed under § 9-202 of this subtitle does not apply to a commercial motor vehicle that:

paragraph.text: is operated by a motor carrier that leases the commercial motor vehicle from another motor carrier who provides or pays for the motor fuel; or
is operated by a motor carrier that has obtained a trip permit under § 9-219(c) of this subtitle.

section.text: For each type of motor fuel used in the operation of a commercial motor vehicle on a highway in this State, the motor carrier tax rate is the motor fuel tax rate for that type of motor fuel in effect when the return period begins, for each gallon of motor fuel used.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may enter into reciprocal agreements on behalf of this State, with the duly authorized representatives of any other state, that provide for:

subparagraph.text: fuel tax registration of vehicles by motor carriers;
establishment of periodic fuel use reporting and fuel use tax payment requirements by motor carriers; and
disbursement of money that is collected by the Comptroller and is due to other states based on:

sub-subparagraph.text: mileage travelled and fuel used in those states; and
the respective registration fees of those states.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may not enter into any reciprocal agreement that would affect:

subparagraph.text: this State’s motor carrier tax rate; or
this State’s registration fee for motor carriers.

subsection.text: In exercising the authority granted under subsection (a) of this section, the Comptroller is expressly authorized to:

paragraph.text: enter into regional or national fuel use tax agreements;
become a member of any regional or national conference, group, compact, or similar organization of motor carrier fuel use tax administrators; and
enforce the provisions set forth in any regional or national fuel use tax agreements.

subsection.text: The agreement provisions shall apply to the fuel use taxation, registration, and reporting requirements of motor carriers subject to the provisions of the agreement without reference to or application of any other statutes of this State.
Except as provided in § 9-208 of this subtitle, each motor carrier shall:

paragraph.text: complete, under oath, and file a motor carrier tax return for periods that the Comptroller requires; and
provide other information that the Comptroller considers necessary to enforce this subtitle properly.

subsection.text: To identify properly persons listed in a return, each motor carrier shall include in the return:

paragraph.text: the Social Security number or other federal identifying number of the person; and
if the Comptroller requires, United States Department of Transportation (US DOT) identification number.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may exempt a motor carrier from filing a motor carrier tax return if:

paragraph.text: the operations of the motor carrier are intrastate only;
the intrastate commercial motor vehicles of the motor carrier are registered (tagged) by the Motor Vehicle Administration to operate within the State; and
the exemption will not affect the enforcement of this subtitle adversely.

subsection.text: A motor carrier is not required to report, on a motor carrier tax return, a commercial motor vehicle operated under a trip permit.

Each motor carrier shall keep, in the form that the Comptroller requires, records of the operations on which the motor carrier tax returns are based, including records that show the number of miles operated for each gallon of motor fuel.
A motor carrier shall make the records required under subsection (a) of this section available for inspection by the Comptroller at any time during business hours.

A motor carrier shall keep the records required under subsection (a) of this section for 4 years unless the records have been audited and, on written request that states the reasons for the request, the Comptroller authorizes early destruction.

section.text: To compute the amount of motor fuel that a motor carrier uses to operate commercial motor vehicles on highways in the State, the motor carrier shall:

paragraph.text: compute its average fleet miles for each gallon of motor fuel as a fraction:

subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the total miles that the motor carrier’s entire fleet travels in all states; and
the denominator of which is the total gallons of motor fuel used;

paragraph.text: determine the total miles the motor carrier’s fleet travels on highways in this State; and
divide the number computed under item (2) by the fraction computed under item (1) of this section.

section.text: A motor carrier shall pay to the Comptroller the motor carrier tax computed by multiplying the tax rate under § 9-204 of this subtitle by the gallons of motor fuel used, as computed under § 9-212 of this subtitle, less any credit allowed under § 9-214 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A motor carrier may claim a credit against the motor carrier tax to the extent of the motor fuel tax that the motor carrier paid on motor fuel bought in the State.

If the credit allowed under subsection (a) of this section for a return period exceeds the motor carrier tax due in the period, then, in accordance with regulations of the Comptroller, the motor carrier may:

paragraph.text: apply the excess credit to the motor carrier tax due within the next 2 years; or
apply for a refund of the excess credit under § 13-901 of this article.

section.text: A motor carrier shall pay the motor carrier tax for a period with the return that covers the period, in accordance with regulations of the Comptroller.

subsection.text: The terms of a lease determine the primary liability of a lessor and lessee of a commercial motor vehicle for the motor carrier tax.
If either the lessor or lessee with primary responsibility to pay the motor carrier tax fails to pay it in full, both are jointly and severally liable for:

paragraph.text: complying with this subtitle; and
payment of any motor carrier tax due.
Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a motor carrier shall obtain from the Comptroller an identification marker for each commercial motor vehicle of the motor carrier.
A motor carrier that operates commercial motor vehicles on the highways of this State may obtain trip permits instead of markers.

A motor carrier that registers (tags) all intrastate commercial motor vehicles with the Motor Vehicle Administration for operation within the State is not required to obtain identification markers for those commercial motor vehicles to operate in the State.

subsection.text: To qualify for an identification marker, a motor carrier shall submit to the Comptroller an application on the form that the Comptroller requires.

paragraph.text: By regulation, the Comptroller shall establish procedures to issue trip permits and to provide evidence of compliance with this subtitle.

To qualify for a trip permit for a commercial motor vehicle, a motor carrier shall pay to the Comptroller an amount rounded to the nearest dollar equal to the current motor carrier tax payable on 174 gallons of special fuel for each commercial motor vehicle.
Fees for trip permits are in lieu of the motor carrier tax.
A commercial motor vehicle identification marker is effective on an annual basis from January 1 through December 31 of each year.
A trip permit is valid for the 15 consecutive days shown on the permit and only for the specific commercial motor vehicle shown on the permit.

subsection.text: A motor carrier shall display the identification marker for each commercial motor vehicle as the Comptroller requires by regulation.
An identification marker issued under this subtitle remains the property of the State.
The Comptroller may recall an identification marker for a violation of this subtitle or a regulation adopted to carry out this subtitle.
The Comptroller shall provide, by regulation, methods for identification of motor carriers to other motor carriers and the public.

section.text: The Comptroller may issue a temporary authorization to a motor carrier to operate a commercial motor vehicle in the State if the Comptroller is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the motor carrier does not have an identification marker or trip permit for the commercial motor vehicle;
unforeseen circumstances require operation of the commercial motor vehicle; and
a prohibition of operation would cause undue hardship.

subsection.text: In this Part IV of this subtitle “police officer” means:

paragraph.text: any uniformed police officer; or

any civilian employee of the Department of State Police or of the Maryland Transportation Authority Police Force assigned to enforce this Part IV of this subtitle or any rule or regulation adopted under this Part IV of this subtitle, but only while acting under written authorization of the Secretary of State Police.
Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, any police officer shall have the authority to enforce this Part IV of this subtitle and any rule or regulation adopted under it.
A civilian employee of the Maryland Transportation Authority Police Force shall have the authority stated in paragraph (1) of this subsection only if the individual is:

subparagraph.text: acting under the immediate direction and control of a uniformed police officer; and
certified by the Department of State Police to enforce this Part IV of this subtitle and any rule or regulation adopted under it.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Falsify” includes alter, counterfeit, duplicate, manufacture, construct, or forge.

“IFTA identification marker” means any license or decal required by law to be possessed by a motor carrier and displayed on a commercial motor vehicle under the interstate agreements authorized by § 9–205 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly:

paragraph.text: falsify any IFTA identification marker or related document;
use, hold, possess, give away, or sell a falsified IFTA identification marker or related document; or
attempt to falsify or sell any IFTA identification marker or related document.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Blend” means to mix together any combination of:

subparagraph.text: alkylate;
aromatic;
cracked gasoline;
natural gasoline;
polymer gasoline; or
straight-run gasoline.

paragraph.text: “Blend” does not include adding alcohol to gasoline.
“Dealer” means a person who engages in the business of a dealer.
“Dealer” includes:

subparagraph.text: the State when it engages in the business of a dealer; and
a political subdivision of the State when the subdivision engages in the business of a dealer.

paragraph.text: “Distributor” means a person who engages in the business of a distributor.
“Distributor” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a licensed dealer;
a licensed special fuel seller;
a licensed special fuel user;
a licensed turbine fuel seller;
a marina; or
a retail service station dealer.

paragraph.text: “Engage in the business of a dealer” means to:

subparagraph.text: import any gasoline into the State;
blend, in the State, any gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid;
refine, in the State, any gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; or
acquire, in the State, any gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid, for:

sub-subparagraph.text: export; or
wholesale distribution.

paragraph.text: “Engage in the business of a dealer” does not include bringing gasoline into the State in the fuel supply tank of an aircraft, motor vehicle, or vessel.

subsection.text: “Engage in the business of a distributor” means to buy for resale motor fuel on which the motor fuel tax has been paid from a licensed dealer, licensed special fuel seller, licensed special fuel user, or licensed turbine fuel seller.

paragraph.text: “Engage in the business of a special fuel seller” means, with respect to special fuel other than turbine fuel, to:

subparagraph.text: import any special fuel into the State;
sell, in the State, any special fuel on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; or
deliver, in the State, any special fuel on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.

paragraph.text: “Engage in the business of a special fuel seller” does not include bringing special fuel into the State in the fuel supply tank of a motor vehicle or vessel.

subsection.text: “Engage in the business of a special fuel user” means to:

paragraph.text: buy special fuel on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; and
use it in a motor vehicle that is:

subparagraph.text: owned or operated by the special fuel user; and
registered to operate on a public highway.

paragraph.text: “Engage in the business of a turbine fuel seller” means to:

subparagraph.text: import any turbine fuel into the State;
sell, in the State, any turbine fuel on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; or
deliver, in the State, any turbine fuel on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.

paragraph.text: “Engage in the business of a turbine fuel seller” does not include bringing turbine fuel into the State in the fuel supply tank of an aircraft.

subsection.text: “License” means a license issued by the Comptroller under this subtitle to engage in the business of a dealer, distributor, special fuel seller, special fuel user, or turbine fuel seller.
“Licensed dealer” means a person who is licensed to engage in the business of a dealer.
“Licensed distributor” means a person who is licensed to engage in the business of a distributor.
“Licensed special fuel seller” means a person who is licensed to engage in the business of a special fuel seller.
“Licensed special fuel user” means a person who is licensed to engage in the business of a special fuel user.
“Licensed turbine fuel seller” means a person who is licensed to engage in the business of a turbine fuel seller.
“Marina” means a person who maintains a place of business where motor fuel is sold primarily to vessels.
“Refine” means to make crude oil into gasoline or special fuel by changing the physical or chemical characteristics of the crude oil.
“Retail service station dealer” means a person who operates a retail place of business where motor fuel is sold and delivered into the fuel supply tanks of motor vehicles.

paragraph.text: “Special fuel seller” means a person who engages in the business of a special fuel seller.
“Special fuel seller” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a retail service station dealer who pays the motor fuel tax on special fuel to the supplier of the special fuel; or
a marina that sells special fuel only to vessels.

paragraph.text: “Special fuel user” means a person who engages in the business of a special fuel user.
“Special fuel user” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a person whose only storage for special fuel is the fuel supply tank of a motor vehicle;
a volunteer fire or nonprofit volunteer rescue company that is incorporated in the State and buys special fuel from a licensed special fuel seller to operate fire fighting vehicles or equipment; or
a person who pays the motor fuel tax on all special fuels to the supplier of the special fuels.

subsection.text: “Turbine fuel seller” means a person who engages in the business of a turbine fuel seller.

section.text: Except as provided in §§ 9-303 and 9-304 of this subtitle, a tax is imposed on motor fuel.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax does not apply to motor fuel that is exported or sold for exportation from this State.
The motor fuel tax does not apply to special fuel:

paragraph.text: containing dye and sold for uses other than in a licensed motor vehicle;
delivered into a tank used only for heating; or
used for any purpose other than propelling a motor vehicle or turbine-powered aircraft.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax does not apply to aviation fuel that is bought for use by:

paragraph.text: a carrier engaged in the common carriage of individuals or property under Parts 121, 127, and 129 of the Federal Aviation Regulations;
an operator under Part 135 of the Federal Aviation Regulations if at least 70% of the aviation fuel is used in the common carriage of individuals or property;
the State;
a political subdivision of the State;
a unit or instrumentality of the United States government; or
a foreign government.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax does not apply to motor fuel that is bought by the Department of General Services for use by State agencies.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Diplomatic mission” means a permanent mission to the United Nations and foreign embassies and consulates.
“Diplomatic personnel” means foreign embassy and consular officials, and foreign embassy and consular employees that have been certified by the U.S. Department of State.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax, pursuant to § 9-305 of this subtitle, does not apply to the retail purchase of motor fuel that is bought for use by:

paragraph.text: a diplomatic mission; or
diplomatic personnel.

subsection.text: To receive an exemption from the motor fuel tax, a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel must:

paragraph.text: establish its exempt status with the U.S. Department of State;
use a credit card that has been issued by an oil company licensed under § 9-321 of this subtitle; and

certify to the United States Department of State that the diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel has obtained and is covered by security that is in the form of and provides at least the minimum benefits applicable to security required for vehicles registered in this State under Title 17, Subtitle 1 of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: Under the provisions of the Foreign Mission’s Tax Exemption Program, the U.S. Department of State must:

paragraph.text: enter into an agreement with an oil company that wishes to participate in the Program; and
certify to an oil company that a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel is exempt.
An oil company that has issued an authorized credit card to a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel under agreement with the U.S. Department of State may:

subparagraph.text: bill a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel for any credit card purchases of motor fuel, exclusive of the motor fuel tax; and
receive a refund or credit of the motor fuel tax.

paragraph.text: An oil company may not allow an exemption from the motor fuel tax at the time of the retail sale of the fuel.

The amount of a refund or credit will be equal to the amount of the motor fuel tax that has been reimbursed directly or indirectly to the gasoline retailer or the amount of the motor fuel tax that the oil company has remitted to the Comptroller.
An oil company shall be required to verify the amount of a refund or credit that is based upon a credit card sale to a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel.
A tax exemption card issued to a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel by the U.S. Department of State may not be used to purchase motor fuel that does not include the motor fuel tax.

Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, a tax exemption, a refund, a credit or a reimbursement may not be granted if a diplomatic mission or diplomatic personnel purchases motor fuel without using an authorized credit card that has been issued by an oil company.

section.text: The Comptroller may allow, by regulation, a licensed dealer, a licensed special fuel seller, or a licensed turbine fuel seller to omit the motor fuel tax on motor fuel sold to the United States or a unit of the United States.
The motor fuel tax rate is:

paragraph.text: 7 cents for each gallon of aviation gasoline;
23.5 cents for each gallon of gasoline other than aviation gasoline;
24.25 cents for each gallon of special fuel other than clean-burning fuel or turbine fuel;
7 cents for each gallon of turbine fuel; and
23.5 cents for each gasoline-equivalent gallon of clean-burning fuel except electricity.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, each dealer, special fuel seller, special fuel user, or turbine fuel seller shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller a motor fuel tax return:

paragraph.text: for each month in which the dealer, special fuel seller, special fuel user, or turbine fuel seller sells or uses motor fuel in the State:

subparagraph.text: by delivery, on or before the last day of the next month;
by mail postmarked at least 2 days before the last day of the next month; or
if, for cause, the Comptroller grants an extension, by delivery on or before the date that the Comptroller specifies; and

paragraph.text: if the Comptroller so requires, by regulation, on other dates for each month in which the dealer, special fuel seller, special fuel user, or turbine fuel seller does not sell or deliver motor fuel.

subsection.text: Each licensed Class B dealer shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller a motor fuel tax return:

paragraph.text: for each month in which the dealer receives gasoline in the State:

subparagraph.text: by delivery, on or before the last day of the next month;
by mail postmarked at least 2 days before the last day of the next month; or
if, for cause, the Comptroller grants an extension, by delivery on or before the date that the Comptroller specifies; and

paragraph.text: if the Comptroller so requires, by regulation, on other dates for each month in which the dealer does not receive gasoline.

A special fuel user engaged in the business of agriculture shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller a motor fuel tax return for periods and on dates as the Comptroller may specify by regulation.
The Comptroller may not require filings more frequently than monthly.

subsection.text: A return shall state the total gallons of motor fuel received, sold, or used, during the period that the return covers, at each place of business in the State.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller by regulation may require each person that is required to file a return under this section to file the return through electronic means.
A regulation adopted under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall include an exemption from electronic filing for persons that do not have access to means of transmitting data electronically; and
shall include provisions for the periodic affirmation and verification of the information that is submitted electronically.

paragraph.text: Each person who engages in the business of a dealer, distributor, special fuel seller, special fuel user, or turbine fuel seller shall keep for 4 years records of motor fuel that the person:

subparagraph.text: buys in the State;
receives in the State;
sells in the State;
delivers in the State; or
uses in the State.

paragraph.text: The records kept under this subsection shall include:

subparagraph.text: bills of lading;
invoices; and
any other pertinent record that the Comptroller requires to administer the laws that relate to the motor fuel tax.

subsection.text: A person required to keep records under subsection (a) of this section shall make the records available for inspection by the Comptroller at any time during business hours.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may charge a person for the reasonable travel and other expenses of inspecting records required to be kept under subsection (a) of this section, if:

subparagraph.text: the Comptroller decides that the inspection is necessary; and
the person does not make the records available in this State.

paragraph.text: If a person does not pay charges assessed against the person under this subsection within 30 days after receipt of a bill for the charges, the Comptroller may:

subparagraph.text: sue to collect the charges; or
cancel the license, if any, of the person in accordance with § 9-330 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each dealer, distributor, special fuel seller, or turbine fuel seller who sells motor fuel shall give the buyer an original invoice that includes:

paragraph.text: the name under which the Comptroller licenses the seller; and
a statement:

subparagraph.text: of the amount of motor fuel tax charged; or
if tax is not charged, that the “Maryland motor fuel tax is not included”.

subsection.text: Unless the information required by subsection (a) of this section appears on the invoice for a shipment of motor fuel from a dealer, distributor, special fuel seller, or turbine fuel seller, a person may not accept the shipment, pay for it, or offer it for sale.

paragraph.text: A person who sells motor fuel in violation of any provision of subsection (b) of this section shall pay twice the motor fuel tax due.
Any other person who violates any provision of subsection (b) of this section shall pay the motor fuel tax due.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax on gasoline shall be paid by:

paragraph.text: the licensed Class B dealer who first receives gasoline imported into the State;
any other dealer who:

subparagraph.text: uses the gasoline; or
first sells the gasoline in this State to a buyer other than a licensed dealer authorized to acquire gasoline, in accordance with § 9–322 of this subtitle, without paying the motor fuel tax; or

paragraph.text: any other person who acquires gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax on special fuel other than turbine fuel shall be paid by:

paragraph.text: a special fuel seller who delivers that special fuel into a tank from which a motor vehicle can be fueled unless the person who uses or resells the special fuel has an exemption certificate that authorizes the person to acquire special fuel, in accordance with § 9–322 of this subtitle, without paying the motor fuel tax;
a special fuel user who uses that special fuel in a motor vehicle that is owned or operated by the special fuel user and registered to operate on a public highway; or
any other person who acquires that special fuel unless:

subparagraph.text: the motor fuel tax on that special fuel has been paid; or
the person has an exemption certificate that authorizes the person to acquire special fuel, in accordance with § 9–322 of this subtitle, without paying the motor fuel tax.

subsection.text: The motor fuel tax on turbine fuel shall be paid by:

paragraph.text: the turbine fuel seller who delivers the turbine fuel into the fuel supply tank of a turbine–powered aircraft; or

any other person who acquires turbine fuel on which motor fuel tax has not been paid unless the person has an exemption certificate that authorizes the person to acquire turbine fuel, in accordance with § 9–322 of this subtitle, without paying the motor fuel tax.

subsection.text: A person required to pay motor fuel tax under this section shall pay it with the return that covers the period in which the person received, sold, or used the motor fuel.

If a corporation, other than a nonstock, not for profit corporation, is required to pay motor fuel tax, personal liability for the tax and interest and penalties on the tax extends to any officer of the corporation who exercises direct control over its fiscal management.

If a limited liability company, or limited liability partnership, including a limited partnership registered as a limited liability limited partnership, is required to pay the motor fuel tax and interest and penalties on the tax, personal liability for the tax and interest and penalties on the tax extends to any person who exercises direct control over the fiscal management of the limited liability company or limited liability partnership.
A licensed dealer or licensed special fuel seller shall deduct 0.5% of the 1st 10 cents of the motor fuel tax on each gallon of motor fuel, as a discount:

paragraph.text: instead of an allowance for evaporation, shrinkage, and handling; and
to reimburse the licensed dealer or licensed special fuel seller for expenses incurred for the State in:

subparagraph.text: keeping records;
collecting and paying the tax; and
preparing reports.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: any aviation gasoline; or
any other motor fuel on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.

paragraph.text: From the discount under subsection (a) of this section:

subparagraph.text: a licensed dealer who sells gasoline to a retail service station dealer shall deduct on the bill 1/2 of the discount;
a licensed dealer who sells gasoline to a licensed distributor or licensed special fuel seller shall deduct on the bill 2/3 of the discount;
a licensed distributor who sells motor fuel to a retail service station dealer shall deduct on the bill 1/3 of the discount;
a licensed special fuel seller who sells special fuel to a retail service station dealer shall deduct on the bill 1/2 of the discount;
a licensed special fuel seller who sells special fuel to a licensed distributor shall deduct on the bill 2/3 of the discount; and
a licensed special fuel seller who sells gasoline to a licensed distributor shall deduct on the bill 1/3 of the discount.

section.text: A person shall be licensed by the Comptroller before the person may engage, in the State, in the business of:

paragraph.text: a dealer;
a distributor;
a special fuel seller;
a special fuel user; or
a turbine fuel seller.

subsection.text: To qualify for a Class “A” license, an applicant shall be:

paragraph.text: an entity that:

subparagraph.text: blends or refines gasoline;
owns or controls and dedicates at least 1 million gallons of storage capacity in the State to gasoline, other than aviation gasoline, and to special fuel; and
keeps in the State an inventory of at least 500,000 gallons of that gasoline and special fuel; or

paragraph.text: an entity that is wholly owned by one or more entities that would otherwise qualify as a Class “A” licensee.

subsection.text: To qualify for a Class “B” license, an applicant shall be an entity that is licensed by the state from which the gasoline is to be exported for importation into this State.
To qualify for a Class “C” license, an applicant shall be an entity that:

paragraph.text: is based in another state;
is licensed by the state to which that gasoline is to be exported;
has no sales in this State; and
does not own, operate or utilize in this State a facility that can store or dispense motor fuel.

subsection.text: To qualify for a Class “D” license, an applicant shall be an entity that:

paragraph.text: is organized under the laws of the State;
does not blend or refine gasoline;
has, in this State, excluding retail service stations, fixed storage tanks for at least 200,000 gallons of motor fuel other than aviation fuel;
keeps an inventory of motor fuel in the State; and
annually sells in the State:

subparagraph.text: at least 1 million gallons of gasoline to persons who are not licensed dealers; and
of the total gallons of motor fuel acquired, at least 50% in gasoline.

subsection.text: To qualify for a Class “G-Temporary” license, an applicant shall be an entity that:

paragraph.text: is not entitled to any other class of license for dealers;

has a specific federal contract to supply gasoline to the United States or a unit of the United States that is entitled to an exemption under § 9-304 of this subtitle or to a refund under § 13-901(f)(1)(ii)2.A of this article; and
is licensed by the state from which that gasoline is to be exported, if any part is to be imported into this State.

subsection.text: To qualify for a Class “W” license, an applicant shall be an entity that is not entitled to any other class of license.
To qualify for an exemption certificate, an applicant:

paragraph.text: shall hold a Class “F”, “S”, or “U” license;
shall be an entity that is exempt from the motor fuel tax under this subtitle; or
may not own or operate on public highways in this State a vehicle that is propelled by special fuel.

subsection.text: If an applicant is organized under the laws of another state or country, the applicant first shall qualify to do business in this State under the appropriate provisions of the Corporations and Associations Article.
An applicant for a license shall submit to the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: a completed application, on the form that the Comptroller requires, that:

subparagraph.text: is made under oath;
states the name under which the applicant does or will do business in the State;
states, for partnerships, the name of each partner;
states, for firms, the name of each member; and
states, for corporations, the names and addresses of its principal officers, resident agent, and attorney in fact; and

paragraph.text: the bond required under Title 13 of this article.

subsection.text: An applicant for an exemption certificate shall submit a completed application, on the form that the Comptroller requires, that:

paragraph.text: is made under oath;
states the name under which the applicant does or will do business in the State;
states, for partnerships, the name of each partner;
states, for firms, the name of each member; and
states, for corporations, the names and addresses of its principal officers, resident agent, and attorney in fact.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall keep and index:

paragraph.text: each application filed under this section;
each bond filed under this section; and
a record of:

subparagraph.text: each licensee; and
each holder of an exemption certificate.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall issue a license of the appropriate class to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Comptroller shall issue an exemption certificate to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
A Class “A” license authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: import into this State gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid;
export from this State gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; and
acquire in this State from another holder of a Class “A” license gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.
A Class “B” license authorizes the licensee to import into this State gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid, for personal use or for redistribution.
A holder of a Class “B” license may not acquire in this State gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.
A Class “C” license authorizes the licensee to:

subparagraph.text: acquire, in this State, from a supplier whom the Comptroller specifically approves, gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; and
export that gasoline.

paragraph.text: A holder of a Class “C” license may not import into this State gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.
A Class “D” license authorizes the licensee to acquire, in this State, gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid from:

subparagraph.text: a holder of a Class “A” license; or
another holder of a Class “D” license.

paragraph.text: Unless authorized by the Comptroller, a holder of a Class “D” license may not import into this State gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid.

subsection.text: A Class “F” license authorizes the licensee to engage, in this State, in the business of a turbine fuel seller.

paragraph.text: A Class “G-Temporary” license authorizes the licensee during the term of the federal contract for which the license is issued to:

subparagraph.text: acquire, in this State, gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid, in the amount that the contract specifies and from a supplier whom the Comptroller specifically approves; and
deliver that amount to the location that the contract specifies.

paragraph.text: A Class “G-Temporary” license may be extended if:

subparagraph.text: the original federal contract is extended; or
during the term of the license, another contract is awarded to the licensee.

subsection.text: A Class “S” license authorizes a licensee to engage, in this State, in the business of a special fuel seller.
A Class “U” license authorizes a licensee to engage, in this State, in the business of a special fuel user.
A Class “W” license authorizes a licensee to engage, in this State, in the business of a distributor.

A dealer who holds any class of license because the dealer was licensed before July 1, 1985 has the privileges authorized for that class until the dealer is required to apply for a new license, in accordance with regulations of the Comptroller in effect as of July 1, 1985.
As indicated on an exemption certificate, the certificate authorizes the holder to acquire, in bulk and without paying the motor fuel tax:

paragraph.text: special fuel other than turbine fuel; or
turbine fuel.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a license or an exemption certificate expires on the first May 31 after its effective date.
A Class “G-Temporary” license expires on the earlier of:

paragraph.text: termination of the contract for which the license was issued; or
the first May 31 after its effective date.

section.text: Each licensee and exemption certificate holder shall display the license or certificate conspicuously in each place of business, in this State, of the licensee or holder.
A license or exemption certificate is valid only for the person in whose name the license or certificate is issued and is not assignable.

subsection.text: To obtain proper identification of a person who receives, buys, sells, or uses motor fuel, the Comptroller may:

paragraph.text: require information necessary to assign an identification number to the person; and
assign a license or other identification number to the person.

subsection.text: A person required to file a return or other document under this subtitle shall include the identification number of the person filing and of each other person listed in the other document.

A person who is to be listed in any return or other document filed by another person under this subtitle shall give the appropriate identification number to the person who is required to file the document.

To obtain an exemption under § 9-303(a), (b), or (c) of this subtitle, a dealer, distributor, special fuel seller, special fuel user, or turbine fuel seller shall complete and submit any certificates and reports that the Comptroller requires, by regulation.

If the holder of an exemption certificate changes the use of any special fuel obtained under that certificate to a taxable use, the holder shall give the Comptroller written notice of the change within 5 days after the first change.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 9-329 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may deny a license or exemption certificate to any applicant, if the applicant:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively has obtained or attempts to obtain a license or exemption certificate for the applicant or another person;
previously has had a license or exemption certificate canceled for cause; or
in the judgment of the Comptroller, has not filed an application in good faith.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Comptroller takes any action under § 9-328 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Comptroller.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The notice shall be sent so that the applicant has at least 5 days’ notice before the hearing.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.

section.text: Subject to § 9-331 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may cancel a license or exemption certificate if the licensee or certificate holder:

paragraph.text: files false information under this subtitle;
fails to file a report required under this subtitle;
fails to give the Comptroller the notice of a change in use required under § 9-327(b) of this subtitle;
fails to pay any motor fuel tax, interest, or penalty due under this subtitle;
violates any requirement for the class of license held;
violates any regulation adopted under this subtitle;
fails to maintain the bond required under Title 13 of this article;
stops engaging for more than 6 consecutive months in the business for which licensed; or
fails to keep records required under this article, Title 10, Subtitle 3 of the Business Regulation Article, or an applicable regulation.

section.text: If the Comptroller cancels a license or exemption certificate under § 9-330 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall notify the licensee or certificate holder in writing sent to the last known address of the licensee or certificate holder. The notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, under a postmark of the United States Postal Service.

Any person aggrieved by a cancellation under § 9-330 of this subtitle or by a final decision of the Comptroller in a contested case as defined in § 10-201 of the State Government Article may appeal to the appropriate circuit court. The appeal shall be filed within 30 days after the mailing date of the final decision or notice of cancellation.

A licensee may request in writing that the Comptroller cancel a license held by the licensee. The Comptroller shall notify the licensee in writing of the decision on the request. If the request is granted, the cancellation takes effect on the last day of the month in which the request is received.
The revocation or cancellation of a license under this subtitle does not discharge a person from a duty or liability imposed by law on that person before the revocation or cancellation takes effect.
The Comptroller shall surrender the bond filed by a licensee if:

paragraph.text: the license is revoked or canceled; and
the licensee has paid all motor fuel taxes, interest, and penalties that are due.

subsection.text: The Motor Vehicle Administration shall send promptly to the Comptroller the name and address of a person who registers a motor vehicle propelled by special fuel for operation on public highways.
The Comptroller shall notify immediately the Motor Vehicle Administration if:
