paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Business and Economic Development.

subparagraph.text: “Film production activity” means the production of a film or video project that is intended for nationwide commercial distribution.
“Film production activity” includes the production of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a feature film;
a television project;
a commercial;
a corporate film;
an infomercial;
a music video;
a digital project;
an animation project; or
a multimedia project.

subparagraph.text: “Film production activity” does not include production of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a student film;
a noncommercial personal video;
a sports broadcast;
a broadcast of a live event;
a talk show;
a video, computer, or social networking game; or
pornography.

paragraph.text: “Pornography” means any production for which records are required to be maintained under § 2257 of Title 18, U.S.C., with respect to any performer in such production engaging in sexually explicit conduct.
“Qualified film production entity” means an entity that:

subparagraph.text: is carrying out a film production activity; and
the Secretary determines to be eligible for the tax credit under this section in accordance with subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Business and Economic Development.

“Television series” means a group of program episodes intended for television broadcast or transmission with a common series title, with or without a predetermined number of episodes, and shall include a miniseries and a pilot episode produced for an intended television series.

subparagraph.text: “Total direct costs”, with respect to a film production activity, means the total costs incurred in the State that are necessary to carry out the film production activity.
“Total direct costs” includes costs incurred for:

sub-subparagraph.text: employee wages and benefits;
fees for services;
acquiring or leasing property; and
any other expense necessary to carry out a film production activity, including costs associated with:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: set construction and operation;
wardrobe, makeup, and related services;
photography and sound synchronization, lighting, and related services and materials;
editing and related services, including film processing, transfers of film to tape or digital format, sound mixing, computer graphic services, special effects services, and animation services;
salary, wages, and other compensation including related benefits, for work performed in the State, paid to persons employed in the production, writers, directors, and producers;
rental of facilities in the State and equipment used in the State;
leasing of vehicles;
food and lodging;
music, if performed, composed, or recorded by a Maryland musician or published by a person or company domiciled in Maryland;

travel expenses incurred to bring persons employed, either directly or indirectly, in the production of the project to Maryland, but not including expenses of these persons departing from Maryland; and
legal and accounting services performed by attorneys or accountants licensed in Maryland.

subparagraph.text: “Total direct costs” does not include any salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services of an individual who receives more than $500,000 in salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services in connection with any film production activity.

paragraph.text: A qualified film production entity may claim a credit against the State income tax for film production activities in the State in an amount equal to the amount stated in the final tax credit certificate approved by the Secretary for film production activities.

If the tax credit allowed under this section in any taxable year exceeds the total tax otherwise payable by the qualified film production entity for that taxable year, the qualified film production entity may claim a refund in the amount of the excess.
Before beginning a film production activity, a film production entity shall submit to the Department an application to qualify as a film production entity.
The application shall describe the anticipated film production activity, including:

subparagraph.text: the projected total budget;
the estimated number of employees and total wages to be paid; and
the anticipated dates for carrying out the major elements of the film production activity.

paragraph.text: To qualify as a film production entity, the estimated total direct costs incurred in the State must exceed $500,000.
The application shall include any other information required by the Secretary.
The Secretary may require the information provided in an application to be verified by an independent auditor selected and paid for by the film production entity seeking certification.
The Secretary shall:

subparagraph.text: determine if the film production entity qualifies for the credit under this section; and
notify the Comptroller of the estimated amount of total direct costs and the taxable year the credit will be claimed.

paragraph.text: After completion of the film production activity, a qualified film production entity shall apply to the Department for a tax credit certificate.
The application shall be on a form required by the Secretary and shall include:

subparagraph.text: proof of the total direct costs that qualify for the tax credit; and
the number of employees hired and wages paid.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (f) of this section, the Secretary shall determine the total direct costs that qualify for the tax credit and issue a tax credit certificate for:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in item (ii) of this paragraph, 25% of the total direct costs that qualify for the tax credit; and
for a television series, 27% of the total direct costs that qualify for the tax credit.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall notify the Comptroller of the amount of a tax credit certificate issued under this subsection.

subsection.text: On or before January 1 of each year, the Department shall report to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly, on:

paragraph.text: the number of film production entities submitting applications under subsection (c) of this section;
the number and amount of tax credit certificates issued under subsection (d) of this section;
the number of local technicians, actors, and extras hired for film production activity during the reporting period;
a list of companies doing business in the State, including hotels, that directly provided goods or services for film production activity during the reporting period; and
any other information that indicates the economic benefits to the State resulting from film production activity during the reporting period.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, for any fiscal year, the Secretary may not issue tax credit certificates for credit amounts in the aggregate totaling more than $7,500,000.

If the aggregate credit amounts under the tax credit certificates issued by the Secretary total less than $7,500,000 in any fiscal year, any excess amount may be carried forward and issued under tax credit certificates in a subsequent fiscal year.

subsection.text: The Department and the Comptroller jointly shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section and to specify criteria and procedures for the application for, approval of, and monitoring of continuing eligibility for the tax credit under this section.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2016 PER CHAPTER 3 OF 2012 //

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
“Fund” means the Health Enterprise Zone Reserve Fund established under § 20–1406 of the Health – General Article.
“Health Enterprise Zone” has the meaning stated in § 20–1401 of the Health – General Article.
“Health Enterprise Zone practitioner” has the meaning stated in § 20–1401 of the Health – General Article.
“Qualified employee” means a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner, community health worker, or interpreter who:

subparagraph.text: provides direct support to a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner; and
expands access to services in a Health Enterprise Zone.
“Qualified position” means a qualified employee position that:

sub-subparagraph.text: pays at least 150% of the federal minimum wage;
is full time and of indefinite duration;
is located in a Health Enterprise Zone;
is newly created as a result of the establishment of, or expansion of services in, a Health Enterprise Zone; and
is filled.

subparagraph.text: “Qualified position” does not include a position that is filled for a period of less than 12 months.

subsection.text: A Health Enterprise Zone practitioner who practices health care in a Health Enterprise Zone may be eligible for a tax credit against the State income tax in accordance with a proposal approved by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, if the individual:

paragraph.text: demonstrates competency in cultural, linguistic, and health literacy in a manner determined by the Department;
accepts and provides care for patients enrolled in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and for uninsured patients; and
meets any other criteria established by the Department.

A nonprofit community–based organization or a local government agency that submits a proposal to the Department and the Community Health Resources Commission under Title 20, Subtitle 14 of the Health – General Article may also submit to the Department a request for certification of eligibility for certain income tax credits on behalf of a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner practicing or seeking to practice in a Health Enterprise Zone.
The proposal shall meet the requirements specified under Title 20, Subtitle 14 of the Health – General Article.

If the Department approves a request for certification submitted under this section, a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner may claim a credit against the State income tax in an amount equal to 100% of the amount of the State income tax expected to be due from the Health Enterprise Zone practitioner from income to be derived from practice in the Health Enterprise Zone, as certified by the Department for the taxable year.

subparagraph.text: In addition to the State income tax credit provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner may claim a refundable credit of $10,000 against the State income tax for hiring for a qualified position in the Health Enterprise Zone, as certified by the Department for the taxable year.
To be eligible for the credit provided under this paragraph, a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner may create one or more qualified positions during any 24–month period.

The credit earned under this paragraph shall be taken over a 24–month period, with one–half for the credit amount allowed each year beginning with the first taxable year in which the credit is certified.
If the qualified position is filled for a period of less than 24 months, the tax credit shall be recaptured as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: the tax credit shall be recomputed and reduced on a prorated basis, based on the period of time the position was filled, as determined by the Department and reported to the Comptroller; and

the Health Enterprise Zone practitioner who received the tax credit shall repay any amount of the credit that may have already been refunded to the practitioner that exceeds the amount recomputed by the Department in accordance with item 1 of this subparagraph.

subparagraph.text: To be certified as eligible for the credits provided under this section, a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner may apply for certification through the nonprofit community–based organization or local government that submits an approved proposal under Title 20, Subtitle 14 of the Health – General Article.

sub-subparagraph.text: Eligibility for the certification for the credits provided under this section is limited by availability of budgeted funds for that purpose, as determined by the Department.
Certificates of eligibility shall be subject to approval by the Department on a first–come, first–served basis, as determined by the Department in its sole discretion.

subsection.text: The Department shall certify to the Comptroller the applicability of the credit provided under this section for each Health Enterprise Zone practitioner and the amount of each credit assigned to a Health Enterprise Zone practitioner, for each taxable year.
The credits allowed under this section for a fiscal year may not exceed the amount provided for in the State budget for that fiscal year.
The Department, in consultation with the Comptroller, shall adopt regulations to implement the tax credit under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Costs” means the costs to an individual or corporation for:

subparagraph.text: security clearance administrative expenses incurred with regard to an employee in the State including, but not limited to:

sub-subparagraph.text: processing application requests for clearances for employees in the State;
maintaining, upgrading, or installing computer systems in the State required to obtain federal security clearances; and
training employees in the State to administer the application process; and

subparagraph.text: construction and equipment costs incurred to construct or renovate a sensitive compartmented information facility (“SCIF”) located in the State as required by the federal government.

paragraph.text: “Department” means the Department of Business and Economic Development.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Business and Economic Development.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations of this section, for a taxable year beginning after December 31, 2012, but before January 1, 2017, an individual or a corporation may claim credits against the State income tax for:

paragraph.text: security clearance administrative expenses, not to exceed $100,000; and

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, construction and equipment costs incurred to construct or renovate a single SCIF in an amount equal to the lesser of 50% of the costs or $100,000.

The total amount of construction and equipment costs incurred to construct or renovate multiple SCIFs for which an individual or a corporation is eligible to claim as a credit against the State income tax is $250,000.

paragraph.text: By September 15 of the calendar year following the end of the taxable year in which the costs were incurred, an individual or a corporation shall submit an application to the Department for the credits allowed under subsection (b)(1) and (2) of this section.

subparagraph.text: The total amount of credits approved by the Department under subsection (b) of this section may not exceed $2,000,000 for any calendar year.

If the total amount of credits applied for by all individuals and corporations under subsection (b) of this section exceeds the maximum specified under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the Department shall approve a credit under subsection (b) of this section for each applicant in an amount equal to the product of multiplying the credit applied for by the applicant times a fraction:

sub-subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the maximum specified under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph; and
the denominator of which is the total of all credits applied for by all applicants under subsection (b) of this section in the calendar year.

paragraph.text: By December 15 of the calendar year following the end of the taxable year in which the costs were incurred, the Department shall certify to the individual or corporation the amount of tax credits approved by the Department for the individual or corporation under this section.
To claim the approved credits allowed under this section, an individual or a corporation shall:

subparagraph.text: file an amended income tax return for the taxable year in which the costs were incurred; and
attach a copy of the Department’s certification of the approved credit amount to the amended income tax return.

subsection.text: If the credit allowed for any taxable year under this section exceeds the total tax otherwise due, an individual or corporation may apply the excess as a credit against the State income tax for succeeding taxable years until the full amount of the excess is used.
The Department, in consultation with the Comptroller, shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.

On or before December 31 of each year, the Department shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on the number of credits certified in the previous calendar year.
Each person required under this subtitle to file an income tax return or estimated income tax declaration or return shall file a return or declaration with the Comptroller, whether or not:

paragraph.text: the person owes income tax; or
the Comptroller sends the person a form or otherwise requests that the return or declaration be filed.
Each income tax return and estimated income tax declaration and return shall be:

subparagraph.text: signed in the same manner required for the signing of a federal return under §§ 6061 through 6064 of the Internal Revenue Code; and
made under oath.

An individual who is an income tax return preparer with respect to a return or claim for refund of tax shall sign the return or claim for refund after it is completed and before it is presented to the taxpayer or nontaxable entity for signature.

If the preparer is unavailable for signature, another preparer shall review the entire preparation of the return or claim for refund, and then shall sign the return or claim for refund. The preparer shall sign the return in the manner prescribed by the Comptroller in forms, instructions, or other appropriate guidance.

paragraph.text: If more than one income tax return preparer is involved in the preparation of the return or claim for refund, the individual preparer who has the primary responsibility as between or among the preparers for the overall substantive accuracy of the preparation of the return or claim for refund shall be considered to be the income tax return preparer for purposes of paragraph (2) of this subsection.
To properly identify persons listed in a return or other document, a person shall include in the document the Social Security or other identifying number that the Comptroller requires:

subparagraph.text: of the person required to file the return or document; and
of the person on whose behalf the return or document is filed.

paragraph.text: If a return or document is filed on behalf of a person, that person shall provide the identifying number required in a return or document to the person who files the return or document.

Any return or claim for refund prepared by an income tax return preparer shall bear the identifying number for securing proper identification of the preparer, the preparer’s employer, or both, as prescribed under § 6109(a)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: Each resident shall include on the income tax return of the resident:

paragraph.text: for an individual other than a fiduciary, the name of the county and municipal corporation, if any, where the resident resides; and
for a personal representative, the name of the county where the decedent was domiciled on the date of the decedent’s death; or
for a fiduciary other than a personal representative, the name of:

subparagraph.text: the county where the trust is principally administered; or
if the trust is not principally administered in the State, the county to which the trust is otherwise principally connected.

subsection.text: Each person required under this subtitle to file an income tax return or estimated income tax declaration or return shall:

paragraph.text: comply with the regulations of the Comptroller;
keep the records that the Comptroller requires; and
attach to an income tax return or otherwise file with the Comptroller any records or statements that the Comptroller requires, including:

subparagraph.text: for an individual who has income tax withheld from salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services, or other payments, a copy of the statement from the person who withholds the tax that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount of salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services paid and the income tax withheld; or
the amount of payments made and the income tax withheld;

subparagraph.text: a copy of the federal income tax return:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a corporation; and
if the Comptroller requests, for an individual;

subparagraph.text: for a corporation, the statements required under § 10–804.1 of this subtitle; and

if the Comptroller requests, for a corporation that is a member of an affiliated group or controlled group under § 1504 or § 1563 of the Internal Revenue Code, a statement of all intermember costs or expenses and all intermember sales, exchanges, or other transactions involving tangible or intangible property for the taxable year.

subsection.text: An individual may designate a contribution to the State Chesapeake Bay and Endangered Species Fund, established under §§ 1-701 through 1-706 of the Natural Resources Article, by the checkoff system on the return.
The Comptroller shall provide that an income tax return may be completed using whole dollar amounts instead of expressing amounts in exact dollars and cents by:

paragraph.text: disregarding a fractional part of a dollar less than 50 cents; and
increasing to 1 dollar a fractional part of a dollar of at least 50 cents.

subsection.text: An individual may designate a contribution to the Maryland Cancer Fund, established under § 20-117 of the Health - General Article, by the checkoff system on the return.
An individual may designate a contribution to the Waiting List Equity Fund, established under § 7–205 of the Health – General Article, by the checkoff system on the return.

paragraph.text: A taxpayer claiming any of the following tax credits shall submit a claim for the credit by electronic means as required by the Comptroller by regulation:

subparagraph.text: the Job Creation Tax Credit, as provided under Title 6, Subtitle 2 of the Economic Development Article;
the One Maryland Tax Credit, as provided under Title 6, Subtitle 4 of the Economic Development Article;
the Biotechnology Investment Incentive Tax Credit, as provided under § 10–725 of this title;
the Enterprise Zone Income Tax Credit, as provided under § 10–702 of this title; and
any other tax credit specified by the Comptroller through regulation.

paragraph.text: Before adding any tax credit not listed in paragraph (1)(i) through (iv) of this subsection to the requirement of this subsection, the Comptroller shall determine whether the addition of the tax credit will have a material adverse impact or undue administrative burden on the Comptroller.

subsection.text: In this section:

paragraph.text: “corporate group” means:

subparagraph.text: an affiliated group or controlled group under § 1504 or § 1563 of the Internal Revenue Code; or
an affiliated group of corporations:

sub-subparagraph.text: that is engaged in a unitary business; and

more than 50% of the voting stock of each member of which is directly or indirectly owned by a common owner or common owners, either corporate or noncorporate, or by one or more members of the group; and

paragraph.text: “corporate group” does not include:

subparagraph.text: any corporation that, for any reason, is not subject to United States federal income tax;
an insurer as defined in § 1–101 of the Insurance Article; or
a regulated investment company, as defined in § 851(a) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: Each corporation that is required to file an income tax return under this title and is a member of a corporate group shall file with the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: a pro forma “water’s edge” combined corporate income tax return filed in accordance with regulations adopted by the Comptroller; and
in a format specified by the Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: the sales factor that would be calculated for this State and the difference in Maryland income tax that would be owed if the corporation were required to include in the numerator of the sales factor for purposes of apportioning income to the State all sales of property shipped from an office, store, warehouse, factory, or other place of storage in this State where:

sub-subparagraph.text: the purchaser is the federal government; or

the property is shipped or delivered to a customer in a state in which the selling corporation is not subject to a state corporate income tax or state franchise tax measured by net income and could not be subjected to such a tax if the state were to impose it; and

subparagraph.text: for any income that the taxpayer has identified, on the income tax return filed under this title or on an income tax return filed in any state, as income that is nonoperational and therefore not apportionable:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount and source of that nonoperational income; and

if the commercial domicile of the corporation is in this State, the difference in tax that would be owed if the corporation were required to allocate 100% of the nonoperational income to Maryland to the fullest extent allowed under the United States Constitution.

paragraph.text: The statements required under subsection (b) of this section:

subparagraph.text: shall be filed annually, for all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005, but before January 1, 2011, on or before dates specified by the Comptroller in an electronic format as specified by the Comptroller;
shall be:

sub-subparagraph.text: made under oath and signed in the same manner as required for income tax returns under § 10–804 of this subtitle; and
subject to audit by the Comptroller in the course of and under the normal procedures applicable to corporate income tax return audits; and

subparagraph.text: notwithstanding any other provision of law, shall be treated as confidential taxpayer information subject to Title 13, Subtitle 2 of this article.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall develop and implement an oversight and penalty system to ensure that corporations provide the required disclosure statements in a timely and accurate manner.
The Comptroller shall publish the name of, and penalty imposed on, any corporation failing to file a statement required under this section or filing an inaccurate statement.

A corporation submitting a statement required under this section may submit supplemental information that, in its sole judgment and discretion, could facilitate proper interpretation of the information included in the statement.
A corporation shall file a supplemental statement under this section within 60 days after:

subparagraph.text: the corporation files an amended tax return under this title; or
the corporation’s tax liability for a tax year is changed as the result of an audit adjustment or final determination of liability by the Comptroller or by a court of law.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall:

subparagraph.text: collect, compile, and analyze the information submitted under this section;

use the information submitted under this section to provide analyses as requested by the Governor or the General Assembly relating to the corporate income tax or proposals for changes to the corporate income tax; and

on or before March 1 of each year, based on information provided in income tax returns and the data submitted under this subsection, submit a report to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly, concerning the corporate income tax.

paragraph.text: The report required under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: summarize the information submitted under this section; and
provide detailed analyses of the characteristics of corporate taxpayers, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: historical series of data and detailed reports for the reported year; and
the distribution of Maryland taxable income, income tax liability, and other elements of the corporate income tax such as tax credits, modifications to income, and net operating loss carryovers.

paragraph.text: The information provided in the report shall be provided by various categories, including:

subparagraph.text: business category; and
various measures of size, such as taxable income, in–State and worldwide payroll, and in–State and worldwide gross receipts.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall adopt appropriate regulations to implement the provisions of this section.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section and except for a fiduciary, each resident shall file an income tax return if, after exclusion of Social Security and railroad retirement benefits that are included in federal gross income, the resident:

paragraph.text: would be required to file a federal income tax return under § 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code; or

would have federal gross income that exceeds the amount specified in § 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code after the federal gross income is increased by the modifications in §§ 10-204 and 10-205 of this title.

subsection.text: A resident dependent shall file an income tax return if the dependent:

paragraph.text: would have federal gross income that exceeds the amount specified in § 6012(a)(1)(A)(i) of the Internal Revenue Code after the federal gross income is modified under Subtitle 2, Part II of this title; and
otherwise would be described in § 6012(a)(1)(A)(i) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: If an individual whose status changes, during a taxable year, from resident to nonresident or nonresident to resident is required to file an income tax return under subsection (a) or subsection (b) of this section or § 10-806 of this subtitle, the individual shall report on the return the Maryland taxable income:

paragraph.text: received during the part of the taxable year that the individual was a resident; and
derived as a nonresident.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each nonresident who has Maryland taxable income and is required to file a federal income tax return shall file an income tax return.
A nonresident dependent who has Maryland taxable income shall file an income tax return if the dependent meets the requirements under § 10-805(b) of this subtitle.

For county income tax purposes, a nonresident who derives income from salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services for employment in a county shall file an income tax return, unless the Comptroller determines that each locality in which the nonresident resides:

paragraph.text: imposes no tax on the income of a Maryland resident derived from wages for employment in that locality;
exempts that income from its tax on income; or
allows a credit for that income and exempts that income from the withholding requirements for its tax on income.

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a nonresident individual who is not otherwise required to file a return shall file a return if the individual:

subparagraph.text: is not a dependent;
is required to file a federal income tax return; and
has income or losses derived from a business, occupation, profession, or trade carried on in this State.

paragraph.text: A nonresident individual is not required to file a return if:

subparagraph.text: the individual’s only income in this State is wages, as defined in § 10-905(f) of this title, that are earned in this State; and

the Comptroller and the state in which the nonresident resides have agreed in writing to allow a reciprocal exemption from tax and withholding for the wages of residents of each state that are earned in the other state.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a husband and wife who file a joint federal income tax return shall file a joint Maryland income tax return.
A husband and wife who file a joint federal income tax return may file separate State income tax returns if:

paragraph.text: one spouse is a resident and the other spouse is a nonresident;
the spouses are domiciled, or maintain principal places of abode, in different counties on the last day of the taxable year;
the spouses have different taxable periods; or
the Comptroller determines circumstances warrant.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, if an individual required to file an income tax return is unable to do so, an authorized agent of the individual shall file the return.

paragraph.text: If an individual required to file an income tax return is a minor, the individual’s parent or guardian shall file the return.
If an individual required to file an income tax return is a disabled person as defined in § 13-101 of the Estates and Trusts Article, the individual’s guardian shall file the return.

subsection.text: If an individual required to file an income tax return dies, the final income tax return of the individual shall be filed:

paragraph.text: by the personal representative of the individual’s estate;
if there is no personal representative, by the individual’s surviving spouse;
jointly by the individual’s surviving spouse and the personal representative of the individual’s estate; or
jointly by the personal representative of the individual’s estate and the personal representative of the deceased spouse’s estate.

section.text: If an individual is not required to file an income tax return under § 10-805, § 10-806 or § 10-813 of this subtitle, the individual:

paragraph.text: is not liable for income tax; and
may file an income tax return to claim a refund of the income tax withheld or estimated income tax paid or a refund under § 10-704, § 10-707, or § 10-714 of this title.

subsection.text: A corporation that, during a taxable year, has Maryland taxable income shall file an income tax return.
Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, a corporation which is not otherwise required to file a return shall file a return if the corporation:

paragraph.text: is not tax exempt under § 10-104 of this title;
is required to file a federal income tax return;
carries on business within this State; and
has income or losses attributable to sources within this State.

section.text: Each member of an affiliated group of corporations shall file a separate income tax return.

subsection.text: A corporation exempt from income tax under § 10-104 of this title shall file an income tax return if the corporation:

paragraph.text: has unrelated business taxable income, as defined under § 512 of the Internal Revenue Code;
is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code; or
is an S corporation that is incorporated or does business in the State.

subsection.text: An organization that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code may file an income tax return to claim a refund under § 10-714 of this title.

section.text: Each fiduciary who has Maryland taxable income and is required to file a federal income tax return shall file an income tax return.
Each partnership, as defined in § 761 of the Internal Revenue Code, shall file an income tax return.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, each individual who reasonably expects estimated income tax for a taxable year on income not subject to withholding under Subtitle 9 of this title to exceed one-half the amount specified in § 6654(e)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code shall file a declaration of estimated income tax.

Unless withholding is required under § 10-906 of this title, each individual who receives income of $500 or more in cash or property from wagering, including the operation of a gambling machine or device and participation in an amusement, educational, or advertising program, contest, lottery, or raffle, shall file a declaration of estimated income tax.
For any taxable year ending before the date 2 years after the date of the decedent’s death, subsection (a) of this section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the personal representative of the estate of the decedent; or
the fiduciary of a trust:

subparagraph.text: all of which was treated as owned by the decedent under §§ 671 through 679 of the Internal Revenue Code; and

sub-subparagraph.text: to which the residue of the decedent’s estate will pass under the decedent’s will; or
if a will is not admitted to probate, which is the trust primarily responsible for paying debts, taxes, and expenses of administration of the decedent’s estate.

section.text: Each corporation and each partnership that reasonably expects estimated income tax for a taxable year to exceed $1,000 shall file a declaration of estimated income tax.
A person required to withhold income tax under § 10-906 of this title shall file an income tax withholding return.

subsection.text: Each organization that is exempt from taxation under § 10-104 of this title and is required to make its federal annual returns available for public inspection under § 6104(e) of the Internal Revenue Code shall also make available for public inspection any annual return required to be filed under this subtitle.
A return required to be made available for public inspection under subsection (a) of this section shall be made available:

paragraph.text: at any office at which the organization’s federal returns are required to be made available; and
for 3 years from the date the return was required to be filed.

subsection.text: Each limited liability company as defined under Title 4A of the Corporations and Associations Article shall file an income tax return unless it has only one member and it is disregarded as an entity separate from its member for federal income tax purposes.

paragraph.text: If the limited liability company is classified as a partnership, as defined in § 761 of the Internal Revenue Code, it shall file a partnership tax return.
If the limited liability company is classified as a corporation under Chapter 1, Subchapter C or Subchapter S of the Internal Revenue Code, it shall file the appropriate corporate tax return.

subsection.text: If the limited liability company has only one member and it is disregarded as an entity separate from its member for federal income tax purposes, the profit or loss of the limited liability company shall be reflected on the income tax return filed by the member of the limited liability company.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, an individual or partnership required under Part II of this subtitle to file a return for a taxable year shall complete and file with the Comptroller an income tax return:

subparagraph.text: on or before April 15th of the next taxable year; or
if the income tax is computed for a fiscal year, on or before the 15th day of the 4th month after the end of that year.

paragraph.text: Within 60 days after the date on which a partnership is dissolved or liquidated or withdraws voluntarily or involuntarily from the State, the partnership shall complete and file with the Comptroller an income tax return.

If the due date for a federal income tax return filed electronically is later than April 15th of the next taxable year, the due date for an individual to complete and file a Maryland income tax return shall be the due date for filing the individual’s federal income tax return, if the individual:

subparagraph.text: files the Maryland income tax return electronically; and
electronically pays any balance due with the return.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, an individual required under § 10-815 of this subtitle to file a declaration of estimated income tax for a taxable year shall complete and file with the Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: an initial declaration on or before April 15 of that year; and
a quarterly estimated income tax return on or before June 15, September 15, and January 15 after the filing of the initial declaration.

paragraph.text: An individual shall file a declaration that was not filed on April 15 or an amended declaration, on any date allowed in paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection for filing a quarterly estimated income tax return.

If an individual elects to pay the income tax in full on or before January 31, instead of filing the quarterly estimated income tax return required on January 15, the individual shall file a final income tax return on or before January 31.

subsection.text: If an individual required to file a declaration of estimated income tax has estimated gross income from fishing or farming, including oyster farming, that is at least 2/3 of the total estimated income for a taxable year, the individual may complete and file with the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: a declaration of estimated income tax for that taxable year on or before January 15 of the next taxable year; or
an income tax return for that taxable year on or before March 1 of the next taxable year.

subsection.text: An individual required to file a declaration of estimated income tax under § 10-815(b) of this subtitle shall complete and file with the Comptroller, within 60 days after the individual receives income from wagering:

paragraph.text: a declaration of estimated income tax; or
if the individual has filed a declaration during that taxable year, an amended declaration.
A corporation required under Part II of this subtitle to file a return for a taxable year shall complete and file with the Comptroller an income tax return:

subparagraph.text: on or before the March 15 that follows that taxable year; or
if income tax is computed for a fiscal year, on or before the 15th day of the 3rd month after the end of that year.

paragraph.text: Within 60 days after a corporation loses or surrenders its charter in the State, is dissolved or liquidated, or voluntarily or involuntarily withdraws from the State, the corporation shall complete and file with the Comptroller an income tax return.

subsection.text: A corporation required under § 10-816 of this subtitle to file a declaration of estimated income tax for a taxable year shall complete and file with the Comptroller a quarterly estimated tax return on or before the 15th day of the 4th, 6th, 9th, and 12th months of that year.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, each person required under § 10-906 of this title to withhold income tax shall complete and file with the Comptroller a quarterly income tax withholding return, on or before the 15th day of the month that follows the calendar quarter in which that income tax was withheld.

Subject to subsection (b) of this section, if the person reasonably expects the total amount of income tax required to be withheld in a quarterly period to be $700 or more, instead of a quarterly income tax withholding return the person shall complete and file with the Comptroller a monthly income tax withholding return:

subparagraph.text: for the month of January, on or before February 15;
for the month of February, on or before March 15;
for the month of March, on or before April 15;
for the month of April, on or before May 15;
for the month of May, on or before June 15;
for the month of June, on or before July 15;
for the month of July, on or before August 15;
for the month of August, on or before September 15;
for the month of September, on or before October 15;
for the month of October, on or before November 15;
for the month of November, on or before December 15; and
for the month of December, on or before January 15.

paragraph.text: If the person reasonably expects the total amount of income tax required to be withheld in a calendar year to be less than $250 instead of a quarterly income tax withholding return the person shall complete and file with the Comptroller an annual income tax withholding return on or before January 31 that follows that calendar year.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if a person was required to withhold $15,000 or more for the preceding calendar year, the person shall complete and file an income tax withholding return with the Comptroller within 3 business days following each payroll that causes the total accumulated tax withheld to equal or exceed $700.

subparagraph.text: If a person is allowed to file federal withholding tax returns on a monthly basis, the person may apply to the Comptroller for a waiver from the requirements of paragraph (1) of this subsection.
A waiver provided under this paragraph shall allow a person to file State withholding tax returns on a monthly basis for the remainder of the calendar year.
A person may apply for renewal of a waiver provided under this subsection if the person remains eligible to file federal withholding tax returns on a monthly basis.
The Comptroller may establish regulations to implement the provisions of this subsection.

paragraph.text: A person required to file a quarterly or monthly income tax withholding return shall continue to file returns, whether or not the person is withholding any income tax, until the person gives the Comptroller written notice that the person no longer has employees or no longer is liable to file the return.

A person required to file returns under subsection (b) of this section shall file a return at least once every month until the person gives the Comptroller written notice that the person no longer has employees or no longer is liable to file the return.

subsection.text: Each person required to file a return under this section shall file returns for other periods and on other dates as the Comptroller specifies by regulation, including periods in which the person does not pay wages subject to withholding.

section.text: If the Comptroller finds that good cause exists and subject to § 13-601 of this article, the Comptroller may extend the time to file an income tax return:

paragraph.text: up to 6 months for an individual or, if an individual is out of the United States, up to 1 year; and
up to 7 months for a corporation.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Income tax return preparer” means a person who for compensation prepares a substantial portion or more of a qualified return or employs one or more persons to prepare for compensation a substantial portion or more of a qualified return.
“Income tax return preparer” does not include a person who merely performs those acts described under § 7701(a)(36)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code.

paragraph.text: “Qualified return” means any original return of individual income tax imposed by this title, regardless of whether a tax is due or a refund is claimed.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, an income tax return preparer shall file all qualified returns that the income tax return preparer prepares by electronic means as prescribed by the Comptroller if:

paragraph.text: for a taxable year beginning after December 31, 2008, but before January 1, 2010, the income tax return preparer has prepared more than 300 qualified returns in the prior taxable year;
for a taxable year beginning after December 31, 2009, but before January 1, 2011, the income tax return preparer has prepared more than 200 qualified returns in the prior taxable year; and
for any taxable year beginning after December 31, 2010, the income tax return preparer has prepared more than 100 qualified tax returns in the prior taxable year.

subsection.text: Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to a qualified return if:

paragraph.text: the taxpayer has indicated on the qualified return that the taxpayer does not want the return filed by electronic means; or
the income tax return preparer preparing the qualified return has requested and received a waiver from the Comptroller.

subsection.text: On written request for a waiver by an income tax return preparer who is subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Comptroller may grant the income tax return preparer a waiver of the requirements of this section if the income tax return preparer is able to establish to the satisfaction of the Comptroller either reasonable cause for not filing the return by electronic means or that there is no feasible means of filing the return by electronic means without undue hardship.

section.text: Each person making payments not reported on a federal information return shall complete and file with the Comptroller an information return that reports annuities, dividends, interest, premiums, rent, or other income, including salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services that are not subject to the withholding tax under Subtitle 9 of this title.

Notwithstanding § 1-302 of the Financial Institutions Article, if the Comptroller requests, a person, including a financial institution, who files a federal information return shall verify or report the items reported in a federal information return.

A person who pays salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services for which income tax is not withheld shall give the payee 2 copies of the information return required by § 10-827 of this subtitle.
Any real estate reporting person who is required to file a return under § 6045 of the Internal Revenue Code shall file a copy of that return with the Comptroller if:

paragraph.text: the vendor is a nonresident; and
the real property sold is located in this State.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an individual, a partnership, or a corporation that has Maryland taxable income in a taxable year shall pay the income tax on that income with the return that covers that year.

Except as provided in § 10-820(a)(3) of this title, if an individual files a Maryland income tax return electronically no later than April 15 of the next taxable year, the income tax due with the return may be paid on or before April 30 of the next taxable year if the income tax is paid electronically.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, each individual, partnership, or corporation required to file quarterly estimated income tax returns shall pay:

paragraph.text: at least 25% of the estimated income tax shown on the declaration or amended declaration for a taxable year:

subparagraph.text: with the declaration or amended declaration that covers that year; and
with each quarterly return for that year; and

paragraph.text: any unpaid income tax for the year shown on the income tax return that covers that year, with the return.

subsection.text: If an individual under subsection (a) of this section files a final income tax return on or before January 31 of a taxable year, as allowed under § 10-820(b)(3) of this title instead of paying 25% of the estimated income tax shown on the declaration or amended declaration for that year with the estimated tax return on January 15, the individual shall pay in full the unpaid income tax for that year with the final return.

If an individual with estimated income from fishing or farming files the declaration or the return on the dates allowed under § 10-820(c) of this title, the individual shall pay in full the income tax shown on the return for that taxable year on or before March 1 of the next year.

An individual who receives income from wagering not subject to withholding under § 10-906 of this subtitle shall pay in full the income tax on that income with the estimated tax return that covers the period in which the individual receives that income.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a fiduciary may use the annualization method as allowed for federal income tax purposes under § 6654(d)(2)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code to determine the amount of estimated tax required to be paid.

For purposes of this subsection, § 6654(d)(2)(B)(i) of the Internal Revenue Code shall be applied by in each instance substituting “ending before the date one month before the due date for the installment” for “ending before the due date for the installment”.

subsection.text: In this Part II of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Annuity, sick pay, or retirement distribution” means:

paragraph.text: an annuity or sick pay payment described in § 3402(o) of the Internal Revenue Code; or
a designated distribution as defined in § 3405(e) of the Internal Revenue Code other than an eligible rollover distribution within the meaning of § 3405(c) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Employer” has the meaning stated in § 3401 of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Employer” includes:

subparagraph.text: the federal government;
the State;
a county, municipal corporation, political subdivision, or instrumentality of the State;
another state to the extent that functions of its government are carried on or performed in this State; and
if the employer is a corporation:

sub-subparagraph.text: any officer of the corporation who exercises direct control over its fiscal management; and
any agent of the corporation who has a duty to withhold income tax from wages.

subsection.text: “Payment subject to withholding” means:

paragraph.text: an annuity, sick pay, or retirement distribution;
income that is subject to the income tax and is distributed by a fiduciary to a nonresident alien;
a payment of winnings derived from wagering in the State if the payment is subject to withholding under § 3402 of the Internal Revenue Code; and
a payment of a death benefit by the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System.
“Payor” means a person responsible to make a payment subject to withholding.
“Payor” includes:

subparagraph.text: the federal government;
the State;
a county, municipal corporation, political subdivision, or instrumentality of the State;
another state to the extent that functions of its government are carried on or performed in this State; and
if the payor is a corporation:

sub-subparagraph.text: any officer of the corporation who exercises direct control over its fiscal management; and
any agent of the corporation who has a duty to withhold income tax from payments subject to withholding.

subsection.text: “Wagering” includes:

paragraph.text: any lottery, including the State lottery; and
any pari–mutuel wagering, including any pari–mutuel wagering conducted under Title 11 of the Business Regulation Article.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “wages” means salary, wages, or compensation for personal services of any kind as defined in §§ 3401 and 3402(o)(2)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Wages” includes remuneration paid for services described in § 3401(a)(5) and (6) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: “Withhold” includes deducting income tax.
Except as provided in § 10-907 of this subtitle, each employer or payor shall:

paragraph.text: withhold the income tax required to be withheld under § 10-908 of this subtitle; and
pay to the Comptroller the income tax withheld for a period with the withholding return that covers the period.

subsection.text: Any income tax withheld is deemed to be held in trust for the State by the employer or payor who withholds the tax.
An employer or payor who withholds income tax shall keep a separate ledger account for withholdings that indicates clearly:

paragraph.text: the amount of income tax withheld; and
that the income tax withheld is the property of the State.

subsection.text: If an employer or payor negligently fails to withhold or to pay income tax in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, personal liability for that income tax extends:

paragraph.text: to the employer or payor;
if the employer or payor is a corporation, to:

subparagraph.text: any officer of the corporation who exercises direct control over its fiscal management; or
any agent of the corporation who is required to withhold and pay the income tax; and

paragraph.text: if the employer or payor is a limited liability company as defined under Title 4A of the Corporations and Associations Article or a limited liability partnership as defined under Title 9A of the Corporations and Associations Article, including a limited partnership registered as a limited liability limited partnership, to:

subparagraph.text: any person who exercises direct control over its fiscal management; and
any agent of the limited liability company or limited liability partnership who is required to withhold and pay the income tax.

subsection.text: Income tax is not required to be withheld at the time wages are paid to a nonresident:

paragraph.text: for State income tax withholding purposes, if the Comptroller and the state in which the nonresident resides have agreed in writing to allow a reciprocal exemption from tax and withholding for the wages of residents of each state that are earned in the other state;
for county income tax withholding purposes, if:

subparagraph.text: the nonresident derives wages from employment in a county; and
the Comptroller determines that each locality in which the nonresident resides:

sub-subparagraph.text: imposes no tax on the income of a Maryland resident from wages from employment in that locality;
exempts that income from its tax on income; or
allows a credit for that income and exempts that income from the withholding requirement for its tax on income;

paragraph.text: for tips, to the extent that the amount required to be withheld on the tips causes the total withholdings for the period to exceed the available net wages other than tips after deductions are made for:

subparagraph.text: the federal income and Social Security taxes and income tax required to be withheld on wages other than tips; and
the federal income and Social Security taxes required to be withheld on the tips; or

paragraph.text: if the wages are paid to an individual rendering police, fire, rescue, or emergency services in an area covered under a state of emergency declared by the Governor under § 14–107 of the Public Safety Article by:

subparagraph.text: a nonprofit organization not registered to do business in the State and not otherwise doing business in the State; or
a state, county, or political subdivision of a state, other than the State of Maryland.

subsection.text: Unless the payee specifically asks that income tax be withheld from an annuity, sick pay, or retirement distribution, income tax is not required to be withheld from that payment.

Income tax is not required to be withheld on that portion of a death benefit to be excluded from federal adjusted gross income, including amounts to be transferred by the beneficiary or the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System to an eligible retirement plan as defined in § 402(c)(8)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code in a nontaxable rollover. The State Retirement Agency is authorized to obtain such representation as it deems necessary to determine if the beneficiary will make a nontaxable rollover.
An employer shall withhold from the wages of an individual the amount indicated in the income tax withholding tables or income tax percentage withholding schedules that the Comptroller prepares.

A payor that is a fiduciary shall withhold from each distribution the amount indicated in the income tax withholding tables or income tax percentage withholding schedules that the Comptroller prepares.
A payor shall withhold the amount from an annuity, sick pay, or retirement distribution that the payee requests.
A payor shall withhold from a payment subject to withholding of winnings derived from wagering:

paragraph.text: if the payee is a resident, a rate equal to the sum of 3.0% and the top marginal State income tax rate for individuals under § 10-105(a) of this title, applied to the payment; and

if the payee is a nonresident, a rate equal to the sum of the rate of the tax imposed under § 10-106.1 of this title and the top marginal State income tax rate for individuals under § 10-105(a) of this title, applied to the payment.

subsection.text: The Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System shall withhold from a payment of a death benefit to a resident payee the sum of:

paragraph.text: 4.75% of the payment; and
the county income tax rate applied to the payment.

subsection.text: If a payment to a resident payee is a designated distribution that is an eligible rollover distribution within the meaning of § 3405(c) of the Internal Revenue Code and the payment is subject to mandatory withholding of federal income tax, the payor shall withhold from the payment an amount equal to 7.75% of the payment.

section.text: The income tax required to be withheld under § 10–908 of this subtitle shall be withheld:

paragraph.text: by a payor other than a fiduciary or S corporation and by an employer:

subparagraph.text: on the basis of each weekly, 2–week, semimonthly, or monthly regular period of payment; or
if there is no regular period of payment as specified in item (i) of this item, on a daily basis; and

paragraph.text: by a payor who is a fiduciary, on a quarterly basis.

subsection.text: At the time of employment, an employee shall sign and file with the employer an exemption certificate that states the number of exemptions to which the employee is entitled under this title.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an employer shall base withholding for an employee:

subparagraph.text: on the number of exemptions stated in the exemption certificate that the employee files; or
if the employee fails to file an exemption certificate or files an invalid certificate under subsection (c) of this section, on 1 exemption.

paragraph.text: If the Comptroller notifies an employer that an employee has an unpaid tax liability, that the employee failed to file a required Maryland income tax return, or that an employee is subject to a tax refund interception request, the employer shall base withholding for the employee:

subparagraph.text: on a number of exemptions not exceeding the actual number of exemptions allowed on the employee’s prior year’s income tax return, as specified by the Comptroller; or
if the employee failed to file a required Maryland income tax return, on 1 exemption.

paragraph.text: An exemption certificate is invalid if it:

subparagraph.text: does not contain the information required; or
contains false or fraudulent information.

paragraph.text: An exemption certificate is not invalid if it states:

subparagraph.text: a number of exemptions that is less than the number of exemptions to which the individual is entitled under § 10–211 of this title; or
a number of additional exemptions less than or equal to the fraction, rounded down to the nearest whole number:

sub-subparagraph.text: the numerator of which equals the excess of the total of estimated itemized deductions, alimony payments, allowable child care expenses, qualified retirement contributions, business losses, and employer business expenses over the standard deduction allowance; and
the denominator of which equals the amount allowed for each exemption under § 10–211(a)(1) of this title for the applicable taxable year.

subsection.text: A person who is entitled to receive a payment subject to withholding of winnings derived from wagering shall complete, under oath, and give to the payor a withholding certificate that contains the name, address, state of residence, and taxpayer identification number of:

paragraph.text: the person who is to receive the payment; and
each person entitled to any portion of the payment.

subsection.text: Each employer or payor required under § 10–906 of this subtitle to withhold income tax for an employee or a person who receives a payment subject to withholding shall prepare a statement that shows for the previous calendar year:

paragraph.text: the name of the employer or payor;
the name of the employee or person who receives the payment subject to withholding;
the total amount that the employer paid to the employee as wages or the total amount that the payor has paid to the person;
the total amount of tips that the employee reported;
the total amount of income tax that has been withheld under this subtitle;
any amount by which income tax required to be withheld on tips exceeds the other net wages paid to the employee; and
any other information that the Comptroller requires by regulation.

subsection.text: An employer or payor of a payment subject to withholding shall:

paragraph.text: provide 2 copies of the statement required under subsection (a) of this section to the employee or person who receives a payment subject to withholding on or before January 31 of each year; and
submit 1 copy of the statement to the Comptroller on or before February 28 of each year.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an employer or payor shall submit statements required under subsection (a) of this section on magnetic media or in other machine–readable or electronic format that the Comptroller requires by regulation, if:

subparagraph.text: the total number of statements of that statement type that the employer or payor is required to submit equals or exceeds 25; or
a lower threshold applies for federal income tax purposes.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: shall adopt regulations to provide a process for an employer or payor that is required to submit statements on magnetic media or in other machine–readable or electronic format under paragraph (1) of this subsection to request a waiver from the requirement; and

may waive the requirement that an employer or payor submit statements on magnetic media or in other machine–readable or electronic format under paragraph (1) of this subsection if the Comptroller determines that the requirement will result in undue hardship to the employer or payor.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, “net proceeds” means the total sales price paid to the transferor less:

sub-subparagraph.text: debts of the transferor secured by a mortgage or other lien on the property being transferred that are being paid upon the sale or exchange of the property; and

other expenses of the transferor arising out of the sale or exchange of the property and disclosed on a settlement statement prepared in connection with the sale or exchange of the property, not including adjustments in favor of the transferee.

subparagraph.text: “Net proceeds” does not include adjustments in favor of the transferor that are disclosed on a settlement statement prepared in connection with the sale or exchange of the property.

paragraph.text: “Nonresident entity” means an entity that:

subparagraph.text: is not formed under the laws of the State; and
is not qualified by or registered with the Department of Assessments and Taxation to do business in the State.

paragraph.text: “Resident entity” means an entity that:

subparagraph.text: is formed under the laws of the State; or
is formed under the laws of another state and is qualified by or registered with the Department of Assessments and Taxation to do business in the State.

paragraph.text: “Total payment” means the net proceeds of a sale actually paid to a transferor, including the fair market value of any property transferred to the transferor.
“Transfer pursuant to a deed in lieu of foreclosure” includes:

subparagraph.text: a transfer by the owner of the property to:

sub-subparagraph.text: with respect to a deed in lieu of foreclosure of a mortgage, the mortgagee, the assignee of the mortgage, or any designee or nominee of the mortgagee or assignee of the mortgage;

with respect to a deed in lieu of foreclosure of a deed of trust, the holder of the debt or other obligation secured by the deed of trust or any designee, nominee, or assignee of the holder of the debt or other obligation secured by the deed of trust;

with respect to a deed in lieu of foreclosure of any other lien instrument, the holder of the debt or other obligation secured by the lien instrument or any designee, nominee, or assignee of the holder of the debt secured by the lien instrument; and

subparagraph.text: a transfer by any of the persons described in item (i) of this paragraph to a subsequent purchaser for value.

paragraph.text: “Transfer pursuant to a foreclosure of a mortgage, deed of trust, or other lien instrument” includes:

subparagraph.text: with respect to the foreclosure of a mortgage:

sub-subparagraph.text: a transfer by the mortgagee, the assignee of the mortgage, the attorney named in the mortgage, or the attorney or trustee conducting a foreclosure sale pursuant to the mortgage to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the mortgagee or the assignee of the mortgage;
any designee, nominee, or assignee of the mortgagee or assignee of the mortgage; or
any purchaser, substituted purchaser, or assignee of any purchaser or substituted purchaser of the foreclosed property; and

sub-subparagraph.text: a transfer by any of the persons described in item 1 of this item to a subsequent purchaser for value;

subparagraph.text: with respect to the foreclosure of a deed of trust:

sub-subparagraph.text: a transfer by the trustees, successor trustees, substituted trustees under the deed of trust, or trustees conducting a foreclosure sale pursuant to the deed of trust to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the holder of the debt or other obligation secured by the deed of trust;
any designee, nominee, or assignee of the holder of the debt secured by the deed of trust; or
any purchaser, substituted purchaser, or assignee of any purchaser or substituted purchaser of the foreclosed property; and

sub-subparagraph.text: a transfer by any of the persons described in item 1 of this item to a subsequent purchaser for value; and

subparagraph.text: with respect to the foreclosure of any other lien instrument:

sub-subparagraph.text: a transfer by the party authorized to make the sale to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the holder of the debt or other obligation secured by the lien instrument;
any designee, nominee, or assignee of the holder of the debt secured by the lien instrument; or
any purchaser, substituted purchaser, or assignee of any purchaser or substituted purchaser of the foreclosed property; and

sub-subparagraph.text: a transfer by any of the persons described in item 1 of this item to a subsequent purchaser for value.

paragraph.text: For every deed or other instrument of writing that effects a change of ownership on the assessment books under the Tax – Property Article and for which a payment is required under subsection (c) of this section, the total payment shall be described on the form that the Comptroller specifies by regulation.
The form required under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be signed under oath by:

subparagraph.text: the transferor of the property;
an agent of the transferor; or
the real property reporting person, as defined under § 6045 of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, in a sale or exchange of real property and associated tangible personal property owned by a nonresident or nonresident entity, the deed or other instrument of writing that effects a change of ownership on the assessment books under the Tax – Property Article may not be recorded with the clerk of the circuit court for a county or filed with the Department of Assessments and Taxation unless payment is made to the clerk of the circuit court for a county or the Department of Assessments and Taxation in an amount equal to:

paragraph.text: the sum of the rate of the tax imposed under § 10–106.1 of this title and the top marginal State income tax rate for individuals under § 10–105(a) of this title, applied to the total payment to a nonresident; or
the rate of the tax for a corporation under § 10–105(b) of this title of the total payment to a nonresident entity.

subsection.text: Subsection (c) of this section does not apply when:

paragraph.text: a certification under penalties of perjury that the transferor is a resident of the State or is a resident entity is provided by each transferor in:

subparagraph.text: the recitals or the acknowledgment of the deed or other instrument of writing transferring the property to the transferee; or
an affidavit signed by the transferor or by an agent of the transferor that accompanies and is recorded with the deed or other instrument of writing transferring the property;

paragraph.text: the transferor presents to the clerk of the circuit court for a county or the Department of Assessments and Taxation a certificate issued by the Comptroller stating that:

subparagraph.text: no tax is due from that transferor in connection with that sale or exchange of property;

a reduced amount of tax is due from that transferor in connection with that sale or exchange of property and stating the reduced amount that should be collected by the clerk of the circuit court for a county or the Department of Assessments and Taxation before recordation or filing; or
the transferor has satisfied the transferor’s tax liability described in subsection (c) of this section or has provided adequate security to cover such liability;

paragraph.text: the property transfer is:

subparagraph.text: a transfer pursuant to a foreclosure of a mortgage, deed of trust, or other lien instrument; or
a transfer pursuant to a deed in lieu of foreclosure;

paragraph.text: the property is transferred by the United States, the State, or a unit or political subdivision of the State;
a certification under penalties of perjury that the property being transferred is the transferor’s principal residence is provided by each transferor in:

subparagraph.text: the recitals or the acknowledgment of the deed or other instrument of writing transferring the property to the transferee; or
an affidavit signed by the transferor or by an agent of the transferor that accompanies and is recorded with the deed or other instrument of writing transferring the property; or

paragraph.text: the property is transferred pursuant to a deed or other instrument of writing that includes a statement of consideration required by § 12–104 of the Tax – Property Article indicating that the consideration payable is zero.

Except as provided in this section, the amounts described in subsection (c) of this section shall be collected by the clerk of the circuit court for a county or the Department of Assessments and Taxation when the deed or other instrument of writing is presented for recordation or filing.

Within 30 business days after the date the amount payable under subsection (c) of this section is paid, the clerk of the circuit court for the county or the Department of Assessments and Taxation shall pay over to the Comptroller the amount collected under subsection (c) of this section as prescribed by the Comptroller.

Amounts collected under subsection (c) of this section and paid over to the Comptroller under subsection (e) of this section shall be deemed to have been paid to the Comptroller on behalf of the transferor from whom the amounts were withheld.
The transferor shall be credited with having paid the amounts for the taxable year in which the transaction that is the subject of the tax occurred.

subsection.text: The transferee, title insurance producer, title insurer, settlement agent, closing attorney, lending institution, and real estate agent or broker in any transaction subject to this section are not liable for any amounts required to be collected and paid over to the Comptroller under this section.
This section does not:

paragraph.text: impose any tax on a transferor or affect any liability of the transferor for any tax; or
prohibit the Comptroller from collecting any taxes due from a transferor in any other manner authorized by law.
The Comptroller shall adopt regulations to administer this section.
The Comptroller’s regulations shall establish procedures for the issuance of the certificate referred to in subsection (d)(2) of this section.

The Comptroller’s regulations shall establish a procedure by which a transferor may apply for an early refund of the tax collected under this section if the transferor establishes that no tax will be owed or less tax than collected will be owed.
On or before January 1 of each calendar year, the Comptroller shall publish the maximum income eligibility for the earned income tax credit under § 10–704 of this title for the calendar year.
The Comptroller shall prepare a notice that meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section and mail the notice to all employers in the State.

On or before December 31 of each calendar year, an employer shall provide electronic or written notice to an employee who may be eligible for the earned income tax credit under § 10–704 of this title that:

subparagraph.text: the employee may be eligible for the federal earned income tax credit under § 32 of the Internal Revenue Code; and
the employee may be eligible for the earned income tax credit under § 10–704 of this title.

paragraph.text: An employer may provide the notice required under this subsection to:

subparagraph.text: all employees; or
employees with wages that are less than or equal to the maximum income eligibility published under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: An employee may not pursue a private cause of action against an employer for the employer’s failure to provide the notice required under subsection (b) of this section.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Buyer” means a person who:

paragraph.text: acquires tangible personal property in a sale; or
obtains a taxable service in a sale.

subsection.text: “Cleaning of a commercial or industrial building” means the following services performed to a commercial or industrial building:

paragraph.text: floor, carpet, wall, window, ceiling, and exterior cleaning; and
janitorial services.

subsection.text: “Person” includes:

paragraph.text: this State or a political subdivision, unit, or instrumentality of this State;
another state or a political subdivision, unit, or instrumentality of that state; and
a unit or instrumentality of a political subdivision of this State or of another state.

subsection.text: “Prepaid telephone calling arrangement” means the right to use telecommunications services, paid for in advance, that enables the origination of calls using an access number or authorization code, whether manually or electronically dialed.

paragraph.text: “Production activity” means:

subparagraph.text: except for processing food or a beverage by a retail food vendor, assembling, manufacturing, processing, or refining tangible personal property for resale;
generating electricity for sale or for use in another production activity;

sub-subparagraph.text: laundering, maintaining, or preparing textile products for rental; or

laundering, maintaining, or preparing textile products in providing the taxable service of commercial cleaning or laundering of textiles for a buyer who is engaged in a business that requires the recurring service of commercial cleaning or laundering of the textiles;

subparagraph.text: producing or repairing production machinery or equipment;
