establishing or maintaining clean rooms or clean zones as required by applicable provisions of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, the Public Health Service Act, and the Virus–Serum–Toxin Act, and the regulations adopted thereunder, pertaining to the manufacture of drugs, medical devices, or biologics;
providing for the safety of employees; or
providing for quality control.

paragraph.text: “Production activity” does not include:

subparagraph.text: servicing or repairing tangible personal property, except for servicing or repairing production machinery or equipment;

maintaining tangible personal property other than textile products for rental and production machinery and equipment, except for maintaining tangible personal property in providing the taxable service of commercial cleaning or laundering of textiles for a buyer who is engaged in a business that requires the recurring service of commercial cleaning or laundering of the textiles;
providing for the comfort or health of employees; or
storing the finished product.

subsection.text: “Production machinery or equipment” means machinery or equipment used in a production activity.

paragraph.text: “Retail sale” means the sale of:

subparagraph.text: tangible personal property; or
a taxable service.

paragraph.text: “Retail sale” includes:

subparagraph.text: a sale of tangible personal property for use or resale in the form of real estate by a builder, contractor, or landowner; and

except as provided in paragraph (3)(i) of this subsection, use of tangible personal property as facilities, tools, tooling, machinery, or equipment, including dies, molds, and patterns, even if the buyer intends to transfer title to the property before or after that use.

paragraph.text: “Retail sale” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a transfer of title to tangible personal property after its use as facilities, tools, tooling, machinery, or equipment, including dies, molds, and patterns, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: at the time of purchase, the buyer is obligated, under the terms of a written contract, to make the transfer; and
the transfer is made for the same or greater consideration to the person for whom the buyer manufactures goods or performs work;

subparagraph.text: a sale of tangible personal property if the buyer intends to:

sub-subparagraph.text: resell the tangible personal property in the form that the buyer receives or is to receive the property;
use or incorporate the tangible personal property in a production activity as a material or part of other tangible personal property to be produced for sale; or
transfer the tangible personal property as a part of a taxable service transaction; or

subparagraph.text: a sale of a taxable service if the buyer intends to resell the taxable service in the form that the buyer receives or is to receive the service.

paragraph.text: “Sale” means a transaction for a consideration whereby:

subparagraph.text: title or possession of property is transferred or is to be transferred absolutely or conditionally by any means, including by lease, rental, royalty agreement, or grant of a license for use; or
a person performs a service for another person.

paragraph.text: “Sale” does not include a transaction whereby an employee performs a service for the employee’s employer.

subsection.text: “Sale for use” means a sale in which tangible personal property or a taxable service that is consumed, possessed, stored, or used in the State is acquired.

paragraph.text: “Tangible personal property” means:

subparagraph.text: corporeal personal property of any nature; or
a right to occupy a room or lodgings as a transient guest.

paragraph.text: “Tangible personal property” includes:

subparagraph.text: farm equipment;
wall–to–wall carpeting that is installed into real estate, regardless of the purpose, method, or permanency of its installation; and
coal, electricity, oil, nuclear fuel assemblies, steam, and artificial or natural gas.

paragraph.text: “Taxable price” means the value, in money, of the consideration of any kind that is paid, delivered, payable, or deliverable by a buyer to a vendor in the consummation and complete performance of a sale without deduction for any expense or cost, including the cost of:

subparagraph.text: any labor or service rendered;
any material used; or
any property sold.

paragraph.text: “Taxable price” includes, for tangible personal property acquired by a sale for use in the State by the person who assembles, fabricates, or manufactures the property, only the price of the raw materials and component parts contained in the property.
“Taxable price” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a charge that is made in connection with a sale and is stated as a separate item of the consideration for:

sub-subparagraph.text: a delivery, freight, or other transportation service for delivery directly to the buyer by the vendor or by another person acting for the vendor, unless the transportation service is a taxable service;
a finance charge, interest, or similar charge for credit extended to the buyer;
a labor or service for application or installation;
a mandatory gratuity or service charge in the nature of a tip for serving food or beverage to a group of 10 or fewer individuals for consumption on the premises of the vendor;
a professional service;
a tax:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: imposed by a county on the sale of coal, electricity, oil, nuclear fuel assemblies, steam, or artificial or natural gas;
imposed under § 3–302(a) of the Natural Resources Article, as a surcharge on electricity, and added to an electric bill;

imposed under §§ 6–201 through 6–203 of the Tax – Property Article, on tangible personal property subject to a lease that is for an initial period that exceeds 1 year and is noncancellable except for cause; or
imposed under § 4–102 of this article on the gross receipts derived from an admissions and amusement charge;

sub-subparagraph.text: any service for the operation of equipment used for the production of audio, video, or film recordings; or
reimbursement of incidental expenses paid to a third party and incurred in connection with providing a taxable detective service;

subparagraph.text: the value of a used component or part (core value) received from a purchaser of the following remanufactured truck parts:

sub-subparagraph.text: an air brake system;
an engine;
a rear axle carrier; or
a transmission; or

subparagraph.text: a charge for a nontaxable service that is made in connection with a sale of a taxable communication service, even if the nontaxable charges are aggregated with and not separately stated from the taxable charges for communications services, if the vendor can reasonably identify charges not subject to tax from its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business.

paragraph.text: “Taxable price” includes, for a short–term vehicle rental as defined under § 11–104(c) of this subtitle, all sales and charges made in connection with the short–term vehicle rental, including insurance, freight handling, equipment and supplies, delivery and pickup, cellular telephone, and other accessories, but not including sales of motor fuel subject to the motor fuel tax.

subsection.text: “Taxable service” means:

paragraph.text: fabrication, printing, or production of tangible personal property by special order;
commercial cleaning or laundering of textiles for a buyer who is engaged in a business that requires the recurring service of commercial cleaning or laundering of the textiles;
cleaning of a commercial or industrial building;
cellular telephone or other mobile telecommunications service;
“900”, “976”, “915”, and other “900”–type telecommunications service;
custom calling service provided in connection with basic telephone service;
a telephone answering service;
pay per view television service;
credit reporting;
a security service, including:

subparagraph.text: a detective, guard, or armored car service; and
a security systems service;

paragraph.text: a transportation service for transmission, distribution, or delivery of electricity or natural gas, if the sale or use of the electricity or natural gas is subject to the sales and use tax;
a prepaid telephone calling arrangement; or
the privilege given to an individual under Article 2B, § 12–107(b)(10) of the Code to consume wine that is not purchased from or provided by a restaurant, club, or hotel.
“Use” means an exercise of a right or power to use, consume, possess, or store that is acquired by a sale for use of:

subparagraph.text: tangible personal property; or
a taxable service.

paragraph.text: “Use” includes an exercise of a right or power to use, consume, possess, or store that is acquired by a sale for use of tangible personal property:

subparagraph.text: for use or resale in the form of real estate by a builder, contractor, or landowner; or

except as provided in paragraph (3)(i) of this subsection, as facilities, tools, tooling, machinery, or equipment, including dies, molds, and patterns, even if the buyer intends to transfer title to the property before or after that use.

paragraph.text: “Use” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a transfer of title to tangible personal property after its use as facilities, tools, tooling, machinery, or equipment, including dies, molds, and patterns, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: at the time of purchase, the buyer is obligated, under the terms of a written contract, to make the transfer; and
the transfer is made for the same or greater consideration to the person for whom the buyer manufactures goods or performs work;

subparagraph.text: an exercise of a right or power over tangible personal property acquired by a sale for use if the buyer intends to:

sub-subparagraph.text: resell the tangible personal property in the form that the buyer receives or is to receive the property;
use or incorporate the tangible personal property in a production activity as a material or part of other tangible personal property to be produced for sale; or
transfer the tangible personal property as part of a taxable service transaction; or

subparagraph.text: an exercise of a right or power over a taxable service acquired by a sale for use if the buyer intends to resell the taxable service in the form that the buyer receives or is to receive the service.

paragraph.text: “Vendor” means a person who:

subparagraph.text: engages in the business of an out–of–state vendor, as defined in § 11–701 of this title;
engages in the business of a retail vendor, as defined in § 11–701 of this title; or
holds a special license issued under § 11–707 of this title.

paragraph.text: “Vendor” includes, for an out–of–state vendor, a salesman, representative, peddler, or canvasser whom the Comptroller, for the efficient administration of this title, elects to treat as an agent jointly responsible with the dealer, distributor, employer, or supervisor:

subparagraph.text: under whom the agent operates; or
from whom the agent obtains the tangible personal property or taxable service for sale.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a tax is imposed on:

paragraph.text: a retail sale in the State; and
a use, in the State, of tangible personal property or a taxable service.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, in addition to the tax imposed under subsection (a) of this section, a hotel surcharge is imposed in Dorchester County on the sale of a right to occupy a room or lodgings as a transient guest in an establishment that offers at least 380 rooms.

The hotel surcharge imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be imposed if the Maryland Economic Development Corporation certifies to the Comptroller that the bonds issued by the Maryland Economic Development Corporation secured by the Dorchester County Economic Development Fund established under § 10–130 of the Economic Development Article have been paid in full.
A county, municipal corporation, special taxing district, or other political subdivision of the State may not impose any retail sales or use tax except:

subparagraph.text: a sales tax or use tax that was in effect on January 1, 1971;
a tax on the sale or use of:

sub-subparagraph.text: fuels;
utilities;
space rentals; or

any controlled dangerous substance, as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article, unless the sale is made by a person who registers under and complies with Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the Criminal Law Article; or

subparagraph.text: a tax imposed by a code county on the sale or use of food and beverages authorized under Article 25B, § 13H of the Code.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be construed as conferring authority to impose a sales and use tax.

subsection.text: A rebuttable presumption exists that any sale in the State is subject to the sales and use tax imposed under § 11-102(a)(1) of this subtitle.
The person required to pay the sales and use tax has the burden of proving that a sale in the State is not subject to the sales and use tax.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the sales and use tax rate is:

paragraph.text: for a taxable price of less than $1:

subparagraph.text: 1 cent if the taxable price is 20 cents;
2 cents if the taxable price is at least 21 cents but less than 34 cents;
3 cents if the taxable price is at least 34 cents but less than 51 cents;
4 cents if the taxable price is at least 51 cents but less than 67 cents;
5 cents if the taxable price is at least 67 cents but less than 84 cents; and
6 cents if the taxable price is at least 84 cents; and

paragraph.text: for a taxable price of $1 or more:

subparagraph.text: 6 cents for each exact dollar; and
for that part of a dollar in excess of an exact dollar:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 cent if the excess over an exact dollar is at least 1 cent but less than 17 cents;
2 cents if the excess over an exact dollar is at least 17 cents but less than 34 cents;
3 cents if the excess over an exact dollar is at least 34 cents but less than 51 cents;
4 cents if the excess over an exact dollar is at least 51 cents but less than 67 cents;
5 cents if the excess over an exact dollar is at least 67 cents but less than 84 cents; and
6 cents if the excess over an exact dollar is at least 84 cents.

subsection.text: If a retail sale of tangible personal property or a taxable service is made through a vending or other self–service machine, the sales and use tax rate is 6%, applied to 94.5% of the gross receipts from the vending machine sales.

paragraph.text: In this subsection:

subparagraph.text: “short-term vehicle rental” means a rental of a passenger car, as defined in § 11-144.1 of the Transportation Article, or a vehicle that may be registered as a Class E, F, G, or M vehicle under Title 13, Subtitle 9 of the Transportation Article, for a period of 180 days or less under the following terms:

sub-subparagraph.text: the vendor does not provide a driver for the vehicle as a part of the rental; and

if the vehicle is a passenger car, as defined in § 11-144.1 of the Transportation Article, or a multipurpose passenger vehicle, the vehicle is not to be used to transport individuals or property for hire; and

subparagraph.text: “short-term vehicle rental” does not include a rental of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a dump truck, as described in § 13-919 of the Transportation Article;
a tow truck, as described in § 13-920 of the Transportation Article; or
a farm vehicle exempt from the sales and use tax under § 11-201(a) of this title.

paragraph.text: The sales and use tax rate for a short-term vehicle rental for a taxable price of $2 or more is:

subparagraph.text: if the vehicle is a passenger car or a multipurpose passenger vehicle:

sub-subparagraph.text: 23 cents for each exact multiple of $2; and
for that part of $2 in excess of an exact multiple of $2:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: 1 cent if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 1 cent but less than 9 cents;
2 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 9 cents but less than 18 cents;
3 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 18 cents but less than 27 cents;
4 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 27 cents but less than 35 cents;
5 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 35 cents but less than 44 cents;
6 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 44 cents but less than 53 cents;
7 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 53 cents but less than 61 cents;
8 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 61 cents but less than 70 cents;
9 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 70 cents but less than 79 cents;
10 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 79 cents but less than 87 cents;
11 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 87 cents but less than 96 cents;
12 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least 96 cents but less than $1.05;
13 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.05 but less than $1.14;
14 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.14 but less than $1.22;
15 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.22 but less than $1.31;
16 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.31 but less than $1.40;
17 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.40 but less than $1.48;
18 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.48 but less than $1.57;
19 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.57 but less than $1.66;
20 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.66 but less than $1.74;
21 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.74 but less than $1.83;
22 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.83 but less than $1.92; and
23 cents if the excess over an exact multiple of $2 is at least $1.92 but less than $2.00; or

subparagraph.text: if the vehicle is a vehicle that may be registered as a Class E, F, or G vehicle under Title 13, Subtitle 9 of the Transportation Article:

sub-subparagraph.text: 8 cents for each exact dollar; and
2 cents for each 25 cents or part of 25 cents in excess of an exact dollar.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax rate for the first retail sale of a manufactured home, as defined in § 12-301(g) of the Public Safety Article, is the rate imposed under subsection (a) of this section applied to 60% of the taxable price.
The rate of the hotel surcharge imposed under § 11-102(b) of this subtitle is 2.5% of the taxable price.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “modular building” includes single-family or multifamily houses, apartment units, or commercial buildings, and permanent additions to single-family or multifamily houses, apartment units, or commercial buildings, comprised of one or more sections that are:

subparagraph.text: intended to become real property;
primarily constructed at a location other than the permanent site at which they are to be assembled;
built to comply with the standards for industrialized buildings under Title 12, Subtitle 3 of the Public Safety Article; and
shipped with most permanent components in place.

paragraph.text: The sales and use tax rate for the sale of a modular building is the rate imposed under subsection (a) of this section applied to 60% of the taxable price.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax rate for the sale of an alcoholic beverage, as defined in § 5–101 of this article, is:

paragraph.text: 9% of the charge for the alcoholic beverage; and
6% of a charge that is made in connection with the sale of an alcoholic beverage and is stated as a separate item of the consideration and made known to the buyer at the time of sale for:

subparagraph.text: any labor or service rendered;
any material used; or
any property sold.
In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Dyed diesel fuel” means diesel fuel that is dyed under U.S. Environmental Protection Agency rules for high sulfur diesel fuel or is dyed under Internal Revenue Service rules for nontaxable use.
“Marina” means a person who maintains a place of business where motor fuel is sold primarily to vessels.

paragraph.text: If a retail sale of dyed diesel fuel is made by a marina, the sales and use tax rate is 6%, applied to 94.5% of the gross receipts from the dyed diesel fuel sales.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax rate for a mandatory gratuity or service charge in the nature of a tip for serving food or any type of beverage to a group of more than 10 individuals is 6%.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, a vendor who timely files a sales and use tax return is allowed, for the expense of collecting and paying the tax, a credit equal to 0.9% of the gross amount of sales and use tax that the vendor is to pay to the Comptroller.

The credit allowed under this section does not apply to any sales and use tax that a vendor is required to pay to the Comptroller for any purchase or use that the vendor makes that is subject to the tax.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the credit allowed under this section is 1.2% of the first $6,000 of the gross amount of sales and use tax that the vendor is to pay with each return.

For a vendor who files or is eligible to file a consolidated return under § 11–502 of this title, the credit allowed under paragraph (1) of this subsection is 1.2% of the first $6,000 of the gross amount of sales and use tax that the vendor is or would be required to pay with the consolidated return.
The credit allowed under subsection (a) of this section may not exceed $500 for each return.

For a vendor who files or is eligible to file a consolidated return under § 11–502 of this title, the total maximum credit that the vendor is allowed under this section for all returns filed for any period is $500.

subsection.text: In this section, “Agreement” means the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement as adopted by the member states of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Project on November 12, 2002.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subsection, the State of Maryland hereby adopts the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement as adopted by the member states of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Project on November 12, 2002.

The adoption of the Agreement by the State of Maryland as provided in this section is contingent on the enactment of legislation by the U.S. Congress consenting to the Agreement and authorizing states that are parties to the Agreement to require remote sellers to collect and remit the sales and use taxes of those states.

Within 90 days after the enactment of legislation by the U.S. Congress consenting to the Agreement and authorizing states that are parties to the Agreement to require remote sellers to collect and remit the sales and use taxes of those states, the Comptroller shall prepare and submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and the House Committee on Ways and Means proposed regulations and draft legislation that:

subparagraph.text: identify and implement:

sub-subparagraph.text: any changes to State statutes, regulations, or policies that need to be made in order to bring the State into compliance with the Agreement; and
any other changes to State laws that would not be required but that the Comptroller recommends should reasonably be made in connection with implementing the Agreement; and

subparagraph.text: for each change identified under item (i) of this paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: estimates the impact of that change on State sales and use tax revenue; and
identifies and explains any fiscal or policy issues that would be associated with the change.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the adoption of the Agreement under this section, unless and until further legislation is enacted by the General Assembly to implement necessary changes to bring the State in compliance with the Agreement:

paragraph.text: no provision of the Agreement in whole or in part invalidates or amends any provision of the law of this State;
adoption of the Agreement does not amend or modify any other provision of this title or other law of this State; and
implementation of any condition of the Agreement in this State, whether adopted before, at, or after adoption of the Agreement by this State, must be by the action of this State.

subparagraph.text: The Agreement adopted by this section binds and inures only to the benefit of this State and the other member states.
No person, other than a member state, is an intended beneficiary of the Agreement.
Any benefit to a person other than a state must be established by the law of this State and the other member states and not by the terms of the Agreement.
No person shall have any cause of action or defense under the Agreement or by virtue of the State’s adoption of the Agreement.

No person may challenge, in any action brought under any provision of law, any action or inaction by any department, agency, or other instrumentality of this State, or any political subdivision of this State, on the ground that the action or inaction is inconsistent with the Agreement.

paragraph.text: No law of this State, or the application thereof, may be declared invalid as to any person or circumstance on the ground that the provision or application is inconsistent with the Agreement.

section.text: The sale or recharge of a prepaid telephone calling arrangement is taxable in the State if:

paragraph.text: the sale or recharge takes place at the vendor’s place of business located in the State;
the buyer’s shipping address is in the State; or
there is no item shipped, but the buyer’s billing address or the location associated with the buyer’s mobile telephone number is in the State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “On-site generated electricity” means electricity that is generated at a facility:

subparagraph.text: the owner of which is an electric consumer that, together with any tenants of the owner, consumes at least 80% of the electricity generated by the facility each year; and
that is operated by the owner or a designee of the owner.

paragraph.text: “On-site generated electricity” does not include electricity generated at a facility that is owned by more than one person or governmental entity unless the ownership of the facility and the ownership of the building or machinery and equipment that consumes the electricity is substantially the same, as determined under regulations that the Comptroller adopts.

subsection.text: “Owner” means the person or governmental entity that has a capital investment in a facility and that for federal income tax purposes is entitled to deduct depreciation on the facility or would be entitled to the deduction if subject to the federal income tax.
“Public service company” has the meaning stated in § 8-401 of this article.
“Special use tax on electricity” means the tax imposed under this subtitle.

In addition to any tax imposed under § 11-102 of this title, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a tax is imposed on the use, in the State, of electricity that is not delivered by a public service company.
The special use tax on electricity does not apply to the use of:

paragraph.text: electricity that is:

subparagraph.text: used for residential purposes; or
used exclusively for emergency back-up generation; or

paragraph.text: on-site generated electricity.

section.text: The rate of the special use tax on electricity is 0.062 cents for each kilowatt hour of electricity that is subject to the tax.
The exemptions provided under Subtitle 2 of this title do not apply to the special use tax on electricity.
In addition to any information required under Subtitle 5 of this title:

paragraph.text: the return of a vendor who makes a sale for use of electricity that is subject to the special use tax on electricity shall state for the period that the return covers:

subparagraph.text: the kilowatt hours of electricity the use of which became subject to the special use tax on electricity; and
the special use tax on electricity that is due; and

paragraph.text: the return of a person who uses electricity that is subject to the special use tax on electricity and fails to pay the tax to the vendor shall state for the period that the return covers:

subparagraph.text: the kilowatt hours of electricity that is subject to the special use tax on electricity; and
the special use tax on electricity that is due.

section.text: The Comptroller shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of the following items for an agricultural purpose:

paragraph.text: livestock;
feed or bedding for livestock;
seed, fertilizer, fungicide, herbicide, or insecticide;
baler twine or wire;
fuel for use in farm equipment or a farm tractor, as defined in §§ 11–120 and 11–121 of the Transportation Article; and
if bought by a farmer:

subparagraph.text: a container to transport farm products that the farmer raises to market;
a farm vehicle, as defined in § 13–911(c) of the Transportation Article, when used in farming;
a milking machine, when used in farming;
fabrication, processing, or service, by a sawmill, of wood products for farm use in which the farmer retains title; and
farm equipment when used to:

sub-subparagraph.text: raise livestock;
prepare, irrigate, or tend the soil; or
plant, service, harvest, store, clean, dry, or transport seeds or crops.

subsection.text: Except for flowers, sod, decorative trees and shrubs, and any other product that usually is sold by a nursery or horticulturist, the sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of an agricultural product by a farmer.
In this section, “bulk vending machine” means a vending machine that:

paragraph.text: contains unsorted merchandise; and
on insertion of a coin, dispenses the unsorted merchandise in approximately equal portions at random and without selection by the customer.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of tangible personal property through a bulk vending machine for a taxable price of 75 cents or less.
The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale to a cemetery company, as described in § 501(c)(13) of the Internal Revenue Code in effect on July 1, 1987;
a sale to a credit union organized under the laws of the State or of the United States;
a sale to a nonprofit organization made to carry on its work, if the organization:

sub-subparagraph.text: is located in the State;
is located in an adjacent jurisdiction and provides its services within the State on a routine and regular basis; or
is located in an adjacent jurisdiction whose law:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: does not impose a sales or use tax on a sale to a nonprofit organization made to carry on its work; or
contains a reciprocal exemption from sales and use tax for sales to nonprofit organizations located in adjacent jurisdictions similar to the exemption allowed under this subsection;

subparagraph.text: is a charitable, educational, or religious organization;
is not the United States; and
except for the American National Red Cross, is not a unit or instrumentality of the United States;

paragraph.text: a sale, not exceeding $500, to a nonprofit incorporated senior citizens’ organization made to carry on its work, if the organization:

subparagraph.text: is located in the State; and
receives funding from the State or a political subdivision of the State;

paragraph.text: a sale to a volunteer fire company or department or volunteer ambulance company or rescue squad located in the State made to carry on the work of the company, department, or squad;

a sale of tangible personal property to a nonprofit parent–teacher association located in the State if the association makes the purchase to contribute the property to a school to which a sale is exempt under item (3) of this subsection or § 11–220 of this subtitle;
a sale to a nonprofit organization made to carry on its work, if the organization:

subparagraph.text: is qualified as tax exempt under § 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code; and

is engaged primarily in providing a program to render its best efforts to contain, clean up, and otherwise mitigate spills of oil or other substances occurring in United States coastal and tidal waters; or

paragraph.text: a sale to a bona fide nationally organized and recognized organization of veterans of the armed forces of the United States or an auxiliary of the organization or one of its units, if the organization is qualified as tax exempt under § 501(c)(4) or § 501(c)(19) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale by:

paragraph.text: a bona fide church or religious organization, if the sale is made for the general purposes of the church or organization;
a gift shop at a mental hospital that the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene operates;
a hospital thrift shop that:

subparagraph.text: is operated by all volunteer staff;
sells only donated articles;
contributes the profits from sales to the hospital with which the shop is associated; and
is not operated in conjunction with a gift shop or another retail establishment;

paragraph.text: a vending facility operated under the Maryland Vending Program for the Blind if:

subparagraph.text: the facility is located on property held or acquired by or for the use of the United States for any military or naval purpose; and
a post exchange or other tax–exempt concession is located and operated on the same property;

paragraph.text: an elementary or secondary school in the State or a nonprofit parent–teacher organization or other nonprofit organization within an elementary or secondary school in the State for the sale of magazine subscriptions in a fund–raising campaign, if the net proceeds are used solely for the educational benefit of the school or its students, including a sale resulting from an agreement or contract with an organization to participate in a fund–raising campaign for a percentage of the gross receipts under which students act as agents or salespersons for the organization by selling or taking orders for the sale; or
subject to subsection (e) of this section, a bona fide church, religious organization, or other nonprofit organization exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code if:

subparagraph.text: the sale is made at an auction sale; and
the proceeds of the sale are used to carry on the exempt purposes of the church or organization.

subsection.text: To qualify as an organization to which a sale is exempt under subsection (a)(3) or (5) of this section, the organization shall file an application for an exemption certificate with the Comptroller.

The Comptroller may treat the possession of an effective determination letter of status under § 501(c)(3) or (13) of the Internal Revenue Code from the Internal Revenue Service as evidence that an organization qualifies under subsection (a)(3) or (5) or (1) of this section, respectively.

For a sale described under subsection (b)(6) of this section that is not otherwise exempt under this section, only that part of the sale price that qualifies for a deduction under the federal income tax as a charitable contribution under the regulations and guidelines of the Internal Revenue Service is exempt from the sales and use tax under this section.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: a Maryland State flag;
a United States flag; or
a prisoner of war flag or missing in action flag honoring and remembering military personnel who have served in the armed forces of the United States.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Facility for food consumption” does not include parking spaces for vehicles as the sole accommodation.

subparagraph.text: “Food” means food for human consumption.
“Food” includes the following foods and their products:

sub-subparagraph.text: beverages, including coffee, coffee substitutes, cocoa, fruit juices, and tea;
condiments;
eggs;
fish, meat, and poultry;
fruit, grain, and vegetables;
milk, including ice cream; and
sugar.

subparagraph.text: “Food” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: an alcoholic beverage as defined in § 5–101 of this article;
a soft drink or carbonated beverage; or
candy or confectionery.

paragraph.text: “Food for immediate consumption” means:

subparagraph.text: food obtained from a salad, soup, or dessert bar;
party platters;
heated food;
sandwiches suitable for immediate consumption; or
ice cream, frozen yogurt, and other frozen desserts, sold in containers of less than 1 pint.

paragraph.text: “Premises” includes any building, grounds, parking lot, or other area that:

subparagraph.text: a food vendor owns or controls; or
another person makes available primarily for the use of the patrons of 1 or more food vendors.

paragraph.text: “Substantial grocery or market business” means a business at which at least 10% of all sales of food are sales of grocery or market food items, not including food normally consumed on the premises even though it is packaged to carry out.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of food stamp eligible food, as defined in 7 U.S.C. § 2012, bought with a food coupon issued in accordance with 7 U.S.C. § 2016.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of food for consumption off the premises by a food vendor who operates a substantial grocery or market business at the same location where the food is sold.
The exemption under paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: food that the vendor serves for consumption on the premises of the buyer or of a third party; or
food for immediate consumption.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale of food:

subparagraph.text: to patients in a hospital when the food charge is included in the regular room rate;
by a church or religious organization;

by a school other than an institution of postsecondary education, including sales at a school by a food concessionaire that is under contract with the school or with its designated contract agent, but not including sales at events that are not sponsored by the school or are not educationally related;
to students at an institution of postsecondary education if the food charge is for a meal plan or is included in the regular charge for room and board; or
by a nonprofit food vendor if there are no facilities for food consumption on the premises, unless the food is sold within an enclosure for which a charge is made for admission;

paragraph.text: if the proceeds of the sale are used to support a bona fide nationally organized and recognized organization of veterans of the armed forces of the United States or auxiliary of the organization or 1 of its units, a sale of food or meals for consumption only on the premises, served by the organization or auxiliary;

if the proceeds of the sale are used to support a volunteer fire company or department or its auxiliary or a volunteer ambulance company or rescue squad or its auxiliary, a sale of food served by the company, department, squad, or auxiliary; or

a sale of food, bottled water, soft drink or carbonated beverage, or candy or confectionery by a nonprofit food vendor at a youth sporting event or 4–H youth event for individuals under the age of 18 years if there are no facilities for food consumption on the premises, unless the sale is within an enclosure for which a charge is made for admission.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of food or any beverage in a vehicle that is being operated in the State while in the course of interstate commerce.
The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale for consumption off the premises of:

paragraph.text: crabs; or
seafood that is not prepared for immediate consumption.
In this subsection, “snack food” means:

subparagraph.text: potato chips and sticks;
corn chips;
pretzels;
cheese puffs and curls;
pork rinds;
extruded pretzels and chips;
popped popcorn;
nuts and edible seeds; or
snack mixtures that contain any one or more of the foods listed in items (i) through (viii) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of snack food through a vending machine.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale through a vending machine of milk, fresh fruit, fresh vegetables, or yogurt.
The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale of electricity, steam, or artificial or natural gas for use in residential condominiums;
a sale of electricity, steam, or artificial or natural gas that is delivered under a residential or domestic rate schedule on file with the Public Service Commission;

a sale of coal, firewood, heating oil, or propane gas or similar liquefied gas for use in residential property that contains not more than 4 units, cooperative housing, condominiums, or other similar residential living arrangements;
a sale of electricity through 3 or more bulk meters for use in a nonprofit planned retirement community of more than 2,000 housing cooperative or condominium units if:

subparagraph.text: ownership of units is restricted by age;
any unit is served by an individual meter; and
on or before July 1, 1979, at least 3 bulk meters served the community; or

paragraph.text: a sale of electricity generated by solar energy equipment or residential wind energy equipment, as defined under § 11–230 of this subtitle, for use in residential property owned by an eligible customer–generator under § 7–306 of the Public Utilities Article.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of wood, wood bark or residue, or refuse-derived fuel used for heating purposes.
The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale of equipment or machinery that is used only to load, unload, and handle cargo of ocean going vessels within an international marine terminal; or
a rental of equipment or machinery that:

subparagraph.text: is owned by the Maryland Port Administration; and
is used only to load and unload ocean going vessels.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of film or video tape for use only in television broadcasting by a television station that the Federal Communications Commission licenses specifically to broadcast to a city or town outside the State.
The sales and use tax does not apply:

paragraph.text: to a sale of an aircraft, motor vehicle, railroad rolling stock, or vessel that is used principally to cross State lines in interstate or foreign commerce;
to a sale of a replacement part or other tangible personal property to be used physically in, on, or by a conveyance described in item (1) of this subsection; or
except for a rental, to a sale of a motor vehicle, other than a house or office trailer, that will be titled or registered in another state.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a casual and isolated sale by a person who regularly does not sell tangible personal property or a taxable service if:

paragraph.text: the sale price is less than $1,000; and
the sale is not made through an auctioneer or a dealer.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a distribution of tangible personal property by:

paragraph.text: a corporation or joint-stock company to its stockholders as a liquidating distribution;
a partnership to a partner; or
a limited liability company to a member.
The sales and use tax does not apply to a transfer of tangible personal property:

subparagraph.text: under a reorganization within the meaning of § 368(a) of the Internal Revenue Code;
on organization of a corporation or joint-stock company, to the corporation or company principally in consideration for the issuance of its stock;
to a partnership only as a contribution to its capital or in consideration for a partnership interest in the partnership; or
to a limited liability company only as a capital contribution or in consideration for an interest in the limited liability company.

paragraph.text: For a transfer that would qualify as a casual and isolated sale under subsection (a) of this section if the sale price limitation were disregarded, the amount of liability transferred to or assumed by a corporation, joint-stock company, partnership, or limited liability company shall be excluded from the consideration transferred by the corporation, joint-stock company, partnership, or limited liability company in exchange for the tangible personal property to determine whether the transfer is made:

subparagraph.text: principally in consideration for the issuance of stock of a corporation or joint-stock company;
only as a contribution to the capital of a partnership or in consideration for a partnership interest; or
only as a capital contribution to a limited liability company or in consideration for an interest in a limited liability company.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: machinery or equipment used to produce bituminous concrete; or
electricity, fuel, and other utilities used to operate that machinery or equipment.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: tangible personal property used directly and predominantly in a production activity at any stage of operation on the production activity site from the handling of raw material or components to the movement of the finished product, if the tangible personal property is not installed so that it becomes real property;
a melting, smelting, heating, or annealing coke oven, aluminum furnace, anode bake oven, electrolytic pot, cathode, refractory, or other material used in relining and rebuilding a furnace or oven; or
a foundation to support other machinery or equipment or an item required to conform to an air or water pollution law and normally considered part of real property.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of equipment that is used by a retail food vendor to manufacture or process bread or bakery goods for resale if:

paragraph.text: the taxable price of each piece of equipment is at least $2,000; and
the retail food vendor operates a substantial grocery or market business, as defined in § 11-206(a) of this subtitle, at the same location where the food is sold.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale, on or after January 1, 2000 but before January 1, 2008, of machinery or equipment:

paragraph.text: that enables a television or radio station to originate and broadcast or to receive and broadcast digital signals; and
that was or is purchased to comply with or to facilitate compliance with the Telecommunications Act of 1996, Pub. L. 104-104, 110 Stat. 56.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of:

paragraph.text: machinery or equipment used directly and predominantly to produce Energy Star windows or Energy Star entry doors for residential real property; or
electricity, fuel, and other utilities used to operate that machinery or equipment.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale, to or by a physician or hospital, of drugs or medical supplies;
a sale of medicine;
a sale of disposable medical supplies; or
a sale of a patient’s medical records to the patient or the patient’s representative.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: a hemodialysis drug or device, by a licensed pharmacist or by a person who holds a permit under § 12-603 of the Health Occupations Article, directly to a hemodialysis patient requiring regular home treatment;

tangible personal property that is manufactured or adapted specifically to compensate for blindness, including braille slates and paper, items with braille markings, preset insulin syringes, and raised line drawing kits;
a decoder for captioned television programs for use by a hearing-impaired individual;
a telecommunications device that is adapted specifically for hearing-impaired individuals and is:

subparagraph.text: a device that changes digital codes into tones for transmission through telephone lines;
a flashing signal device; or
a telebraille machine;

paragraph.text: an artificial eye, hearing device, or limb;
a colostomy or ileostomy appliance;
corrective eyeglasses;
an orthopedic or surgical appliance prescribed by a physician and designed to be worn on the person of the user;
a battery for an artificial hearing device or larynx, transcutaneous nerve stimulator, or electrically powered wheelchair;
a replacement cord for an artificial hearing device;
crutches;
a wheelchair;
a hospital bed;
an oxygen tent;
any other sickroom equipment that the Comptroller defines by regulations or medical equipment that:

subparagraph.text: can withstand repeated use;
is used exclusively to serve a medical purpose;
is not useful to a person in the absence of illness or injury; and
is for use in the home or on the individual’s person;

paragraph.text: tangible personal property for installation in a motor vehicle:

subparagraph.text: to provide access to the motor vehicle by an individual with a disability; or
to permit an individual with a disability to operate the motor vehicle;

paragraph.text: a wig or hairpiece needed as a result of documented medical or surgical treatment;
nicotine patches, nicotine gum, or any other product intended for use as an aid in tobacco use cessation and approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for that purpose; or

tangible personal property that is manufactured for the purpose of initiating, supporting, or sustaining breast-feeding, including breast pumps, breast pump kits, nipple enhancers, breast shields, breast shells, supplemental nursing systems, softcup feeders, feeding tubes, breast milk storage bags, periodontal syringes, finger feeders, haberman feeders, and purified lanolin.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: baby oil or baby powder; or
sanitary napkins or tampons.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: fabrication, processing, or service, by a sawmill, of wood products for mine use in which the miner retains title; or
diesel fuel for use in reclamation of land that has been mined for coal by strip or open-pit mining.

section.text: Except for the first retail sale of the manufactured home, the sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of a manufactured home, as defined in § 12-301(g) of the Public Safety Article.
The sales and use tax does not apply to use of tangible personal property or a taxable service that:

paragraph.text: a nonresident:

subparagraph.text: acquires before the property or service enters the State; and
uses:

sub-subparagraph.text: for personal enjoyment or use or for a use that the Comptroller specifies by regulation, other than for a business purpose; or
in a presentation or in conjunction with a presentation of an exhibit, show, sporting event, or other public performance or display; and

paragraph.text: does not remain in the State for more than 30 days.

subsection.text: In this section:

paragraph.text: “precious metal bullion or coins” means:

subparagraph.text: any precious metal that has gone through a refining process and is in a state or condition such that its value depends on its precious metal content and not on its form; or
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, monetized bullion, coins, or other forms of money that:

sub-subparagraph.text: are manufactured from precious metals; and
are or have in the past been used as a medium of exchange under the laws of the State, the United States, or a foreign nation; and

paragraph.text: “precious metal bullion or coins” does not include jewelry or a work of art made of precious metal bullion or coins.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of precious metal bullion or coins if the sale price is greater than $1,000.
The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of photographic material for use in the production of an item that is used in:

paragraph.text: composition or printing; or
production of another item used in printing.

The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of art works, electros, electrotypes, hand or machine compositions, lithographic plates or negatives, mats, photoengravings, stereotypes, or typographies:

subparagraph.text: to a person engaged in the printing of tangible personal property for sale; and
for direct use by the person to produce that property for sale.

paragraph.text: A vendor who sells any item under paragraph (1) of this subsection is not entitled to any exclusion under § 11-101(h)(3)(ii) or (n)(3)(ii) of this title for material that the vendor buys to produce that item.
The sales and use tax does not apply to the printing and sale of newspapers that are distributed by the publisher at no charge.
A publication is not a newspaper unless it is published and distributed at least once per month and it meets other criteria as defined by the Comptroller.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale of direct mail advertising literature and mail order catalogues that will be distributed outside the State, and a sale of computerized mailing lists to the extent used for the purpose of providing addresses to which direct mail advertising literature and mail order catalogues will be distributed outside the State; or
a sale of government documents, publications, records, or copies by the federal or State or a local government or an instrumentality of the federal or State or a local government.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale for use of tangible personal property that:

subparagraph.text: is bought outside this State;
is intended solely for use in another state; and
is stored in this State pending shipment to another state;

paragraph.text: a sale of tangible personal property to a person obligated under a contract to incorporate that property into real property located in another state where the purchase or use of that property would not be subject to a sales tax, use tax, or similar tax; or

except for that portion of the purchase price allocable to intended viewing in this State, a sale of a series of images stored on video tape or in other optical or digital forms or electronic signals generated from these images to a cable or other nonbroadcast television network, if the images are intended for viewing by television viewers located outside the State.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax shall be paid:

paragraph.text: on a sale under subsection (a)(1) of this section, when the tangible personal property is imported or stored in the State; and
on a sale under subsection (a)(2) of this section, when the sale is made.

subsection.text: A person who pays the sales and use tax under subsection (b) of this section may obtain the exemption by:

paragraph.text: filing a claim for refund with the Comptroller when the property is removed from the State; and
providing the Comptroller with the evidence that the Comptroller requires by regulation, including:

subparagraph.text: evidence of use or removal of the property from the State; and
satisfactory proof of entitlement to exemption in another state.

paragraph.text: In this section, “research and development” means:

subparagraph.text: basic and applied research in the sciences and engineering; and
the design, development, and governmentally required pre-market testing of prototypes, products, and processes.

paragraph.text: “Research and development” does not include:

subparagraph.text: market research;
research in the social sciences or psychology and other nontechnical activities;
routine product testing;
sales services; or
technical and nontechnical services.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of tangible personal property for use or consumption in research and development.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: a clam or oyster rake, crab bait, crab or eel pot, or fish net;
a dredge, handscrape, or hand or patent tong; or
fuel or a repair part for a commercial fishing vessel or for a vessel otherwise used for commercial purposes.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a personal, professional, or insurance service that:

paragraph.text: is not a taxable service; and
involves a sale as an inconsequential element for which no separate charge is made.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of custom computer software services relating to procedures and programs that:

paragraph.text: otherwise are taxable under this title;
are to be used by a specific person;

subparagraph.text: are created for that person; or
contain standard or proprietary routines that incorporate significant creative input to customize the procedures and programs for that person; and

paragraph.text: do not constitute a program, procedure, or documentation that is mass produced and sold to:

subparagraph.text: the general public; or
persons associated in a trade, profession, or industry.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of an optional computer software maintenance contract if the buyer does not have a right, as part of the contract, to receive at no additional cost software products that are separately priced and marketed by the vendor.
The sales and use tax does not apply to the use of a taxable service obtained by using a prepaid telephone calling arrangement.
The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale to the State or a political subdivision of the State.

The exemption under subsection (a) of this section may not be construed to exempt any sale of tangible personal property, otherwise taxable under this title, to a contractor to be used under a contract with the State or a political subdivision of the State for construction, repair, or alteration of real property.
The sales and use tax does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale of an admission by a person whose gross receipts from the sale are subject to the admissions and amusement tax;

a sale of a communication service, other than a taxable service, rendered by a person whose charge for a communication service is or would be subject to the federal excise tax as described in § 4251 of the Internal Revenue Code in effect on July 1, 1979;
a sale of a motor fuel that is subject to the motor fuel tax or the motor carrier tax;
except for a rental, a sale of a motor vehicle, other than a house or office trailer, that is subject to the motor vehicle excise tax under § 13-809 or § 13-811 of the Transportation Article;
a lease of a motor vehicle that is leased for a period of at least 1 year;

a rental of a motion picture, motion picture trailer, or advertising poster for display on theater premises by a person whose gross receipts from the activity related to the rental is subject to the admissions and amusement tax; or
except for a rental, a sale of a vessel that is subject to the excise tax under § 8-716 of the Natural Resources Article.

subsection.text: If a person who buys tangible personal property or a taxable service in a retail sale pays the sales and use tax when the retail sale is made, the person is not required to pay the tax again when the person uses that tangible personal property or taxable service in the State.

paragraph.text: To the extent that a buyer pays another state a tax on a sale or gross receipts from a sale of tangible personal property or a taxable service that the buyer acquires before the property or service enters this State, the sales and use tax does not apply to use of the property or service in this State.

If the tax paid to another state is less than the sales and use tax, the buyer shall pay the difference between the sales and use tax and the amount paid to the other state in accordance with the formula under § 11-303(b) of this title.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of deliverable end item testing equipment that is used to perform a contract for the United States Department of Defense and that, under the terms of the contract, is to be transferred to the federal government, if the contract is awarded as a result of a bid submitted after June 1, 1986.
The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of:

paragraph.text: a bus to a person who uses the bus only:

subparagraph.text: in the operation of the transportation system of a political subdivision of the State; and
for public transportation on regular schedules and between fixed termini, as defined in Title 11 of the Transportation Article; or

paragraph.text: a transportation service.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of water that is delivered to the buyer through pipes or conduits.

subsection.text: In this section, “computer program” means a set of statements or instructions to be used directly or indirectly in a computer in order to bring about a certain result.
The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of a computer program that is legally permitted to be and is intended to be:

paragraph.text: reproduced for sale; or
incorporated in whole or in part into another computer program intended for sale.

In this subsection, “Energy Star product” means an air conditioner, clothes washer or dryer, furnace, heat pump, standard size refrigerator, compact fluorescent light bulb, dehumidifier, boiler, or programmable thermostat that has been designated as meeting or exceeding the applicable Energy Star efficiency requirements developed by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Department of Energy.

Beginning in calendar year 2011, the weekend that consists of the Saturday immediately preceding the third Monday in February through the third Monday in February each year shall be a tax–free weekend during which the exemption under paragraph (3) of this subsection shall apply.
During the tax–free weekend established under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of any:

subparagraph.text: Energy Star product; or
solar water heater.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of a multifuel pellet stove designed to burn agricultural field corn.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Film production activity” means the production or postproduction of film or video projects including feature films, television projects, commercials, corporate films, infomercials, music videos, or other projects for which the producer or production company will be compensated, and which are intended for nationwide commercial distribution.
“Film production activity” includes the production or postproduction of digital, animation, and multimedia projects.
“Film production activity” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: production or postproduction of student films or noncommercial personal videos; or
any activity not necessary to and undertaken directly and exclusively for the making of a master film, tape, or image.

paragraph.text: “Tangible personal property or a taxable service used directly in connection with a film production activity” includes:

subparagraph.text: camera equipment and supplies;
film and tape;
lighting and stage equipment and supplies;
sound equipment and supplies;
recording equipment and supplies;
costumes, wardrobes, and materials to construct them;
props, scenery, and materials to construct them;
design supplies and equipment;
drafting supplies and equipment;
special effects supplies and equipment;
short-term vehicle rentals; and
fabrication, printing, or production of scripts, storyboards, costumes, wardrobes, props, scenery, or special effects.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of tangible personal property or a taxable service used directly in connection with a film production activity by a film producer or production company certified by the Department of Business and Economic Development under Title 6, Subtitle 2 of the Economic Development Article.
In this section, “accessory items” includes jewelry, watches, watchbands, handbags, handkerchiefs, umbrellas, scarves, ties, headbands, and belt buckles.

paragraph.text: Beginning in calendar year 2010, the 7–day period from the second Sunday in August through the following Saturday shall be a tax–free period for back–to–school shopping in Maryland during which the exemption under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall apply.

During the tax–free period for back–to–school shopping established under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of any item of clothing or footwear, excluding accessory items, if the taxable price of the item of clothing or footwear is $100 or less.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of electricity, fuel, and other utilities used to operate the machinery or equipment used to produce snow for commercial purposes.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Geothermal equipment” means equipment that uses ground loop technology to heat and cool a structure.
“Residential wind energy equipment” means equipment installed on residential property that uses wind energy to generate electricity to be used in a residential structure on the property.

subparagraph.text: “Solar energy equipment” means equipment that uses solar energy to heat or cool a structure, generate electricity to be used in a structure or supplied to the electric grid, or provide hot water for use in a structure.
“Solar energy equipment” does not include equipment that is part of a nonsolar energy system or that uses any type of recreational facility or equipment as a storage medium.

subsection.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to a sale of geothermal equipment, residential wind energy equipment, or solar energy equipment.

section.text: The sales and use tax does not apply to the sale of a right to occupy a room or lodgings as a transient guest at a dormitory or other lodging facility that:

paragraph.text: is operated solely in support of a corporate or any other headquarters, training, conference, or awards facility or campus;
provides lodging solely for employees, contractors, vendors, and other invitees of the corporation that owns the dormitory or lodging facility; and
does not offer lodging services to the general public.

section.text: The sales and use tax is computed on:

paragraph.text: the taxable price of each separate sale;
if a combined sale is made, the combined taxable price of all retail sales on the same occasion by the same vendor to the same buyer; or
if retail sales of tangible personal property or a taxable service are made through vending or other self–service machines, 94.5% of the gross receipts from the retail sales.

section.text: For each retail sale or sale for use other than a sale under § 11–405, § 11–406, or § 11–410 of this title, the sales and use tax shall be:

paragraph.text: stated separately from the sale price; and
shown separately from the sale price on any record of a sale:

subparagraph.text: at the time of the sale;
when the vendor issues evidence of the sale; or
when the vendor uses evidence of the sale.

subsection.text: A buyer is allowed a depreciation allowance as an adjustment to taxable price if:

paragraph.text: tangible personal property or a taxable service is acquired before the tangible personal property is brought into the State for use in the State or before the taxable service is used in the State; and
the use first occurs in another state or federal jurisdiction.

subsection.text: The allowance under subsection (a) of this section for each full year that follows the date of purchase is 10% of the taxable price paid to acquire the tangible personal property or taxable service.
A vendor is a trustee for the State and is liable for the collection of the sales and use tax for and on account of the State.

A vendor has the same rights to collect the sales and use tax from a buyer and the same rights regarding the nonpayment of the sales and use tax by a buyer that the vendor would have if the sales and use tax were a part of the purchase price of the tangible personal property or taxable service at the time of the sale.

section.text: Subject to § 11–302 of this title, a vendor may:

paragraph.text: assume or absorb all or any part of the sales and use tax imposed on a retail sale or use; and
pay that sales and use tax on behalf of the buyer.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a vendor shall collect the applicable sales and use tax from the buyer:

paragraph.text: at the time that the sale is made, regardless of when the taxable price is paid;
if the tax is based on a credit or installment sale, at the time that the Comptroller requires by regulation; or
if a sale for use is not taxable when the sale is made, at the time that the use becomes taxable.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, unless a buyer is otherwise required by regulation to pay the sales and use tax directly to the Comptroller, the buyer shall pay the sales and use tax to the vendor at the time required under subsection (a) of this section.
A vendor shall refund to a buyer the proportionate amount of sales and use tax that the buyer has paid if:

subparagraph.text: a sale is rescinded or canceled; or
the property sold is returned to the vendor; and

paragraph.text: the purchase price is wholly or partially repaid or credited.

section.text: The collection of the sales and use tax on a sale for use in the State is not affected even if:

paragraph.text: as a result of solicitation by the vendor in a catalog or other written advertisement, the order of the buyer or the contract of sale is delivered, mailed, or otherwise transmitted out of the State to the vendor;
the order of the buyer or the contract of sale provides for tangible personal property obtained or manufactured out of the State to be shipped directly to the buyer from the point of origin;
tangible personal property, intended to be brought into the State for use in the State, is delivered outside the State directly to the buyer;
the order of the buyer or the contract of sale is made or closed:

subparagraph.text: by acceptance or approval out of the State; or
before the tangible personal property enters the State; or

paragraph.text: whether transportation costs are paid by the vendor or the buyer, tangible personal property:

subparagraph.text: is mailed to a buyer in the State from outside the State; or
is delivered outside the State to a carrier freight on board or otherwise and directed to the buyer in the State.

section.text: A vendor who sells tangible personal property or a taxable service through a vending or other self-service machine:

paragraph.text: shall pay the sales and use tax to the Comptroller; and
may not collect the sales and use tax from the buyer as a separately stated item.

If the nature of a vendor’s business makes the collection of the sales and use tax at the time of a retail sale impracticable, the vendor may submit to the Comptroller an application for authority to prepay the tax.
If the Comptroller approves the application, the Comptroller may impose on the applicant any condition that is reasonable under the circumstances.
If the Comptroller denies an application or imposes a condition on the applicant, the Comptroller shall:

subparagraph.text: give the applicant notice of the action; and
schedule a prompt hearing for review of the action.

paragraph.text: An applicant may waive the hearing under paragraph (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A vendor who obtains authority to prepay the tax under this section:

paragraph.text: shall pay the sales and use tax to the Comptroller; and
may not collect the sales and use tax from the buyer as a separately stated item.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, on or after July 1, 1993, the Comptroller may not:

subparagraph.text: grant the authority to make direct payment, to the Comptroller, of sales and use tax due on purchases by a vendor; or
issue permits evidencing such authority.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Comptroller may continue to administer direct payment permits issued to vendors before July 1, 1993.
The Comptroller may:

subparagraph.text: issue the permit subject to reasonable and necessary terms and conditions; and
revoke the direct payment permit at any time for cause.

subsection.text: A vendor who receives evidence that the buyer has a direct payment permit is discharged from:

paragraph.text: the duty to collect the sales and use tax; and
the liability for the sales and use tax.

subparagraph.text: The Comptroller may enter into an effective rate agreement with a vendor licensed under Subtitle 7 of this title to allow the vendor to compute its sales and use tax liability for purchases made by the vendor for a specific period using a predetermined agreed-upon effective rate, eliminating the need to determine the liability on a transaction-by-transaction basis.
An effective rate agreement:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall specify the types of records to be maintained by the vendor; and
may exclude specified types of purchases or purchases in excess of specified dollar amounts.

subparagraph.text: The Comptroller may void an effective rate agreement entered into under this subsection if the vendor’s operations significantly change during the term of the agreement.

If the Comptroller enters into an effective rate agreement with a vendor under this subsection, the Comptroller may issue a direct payment permit authorizing the vendor to make direct payment, to the Comptroller, of the sales and use tax due on purchases by that vendor that are subject to the effective rate agreement.
A direct payment permit issued under this paragraph remains in effect as long as the effective rate agreement is in effect.

subsection.text: If a buyer is required under Subtitle 2 of this title or by regulation to provide a vendor with evidence of an exemption, the vendor may not recognize the exemption unless the buyer, before the sale is consummated, provides the vendor with:

paragraph.text: evidence that the buyer has an exemption certificate; or
the evidence that the Comptroller requires by regulation.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the duty of a vendor to collect the sales and use tax from a buyer is waived if the buyer provides the vendor with a signed resale certificate that:

subparagraph.text: is in the form that the Comptroller requires by regulation;
states the name and address of the buyer;

sub-subparagraph.text: provides the Maryland sales and use tax registration number of the buyer; or

for the sale of an antique or used collectible, provides a sales and use tax registration number of another state and states that the buyer is an out-of-state vendor who does not engage in the business of an out-of-state vendor, as defined in § 11-701 of this title; and

subparagraph.text: contains a statement to the effect that the tangible personal property or taxable service is bought for the purpose of resale.

If a buyer provides a resale certificate with a sales and use tax registration number of another state as provided under paragraph (1)(iii)2 of this subsection, the buyer shall also provide a copy of a sales and use tax registration license issued to the buyer from that state.
If a buyer is from a state without a sales and use tax, that buyer shall provide a copy of a trader’s license from that state or a comparable type of identification.
A vendor may not accept a resale certificate if the vendor knows or should know that the sale is not for the purpose of resale.
A vendor may not accept a resale certificate for a cash, check, or credit card sale if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the taxable price is less than $200; and
the tangible personal property or taxable service is not delivered by the vendor directly to the buyer’s retail place of business.

paragraph.text: A vendor shall obtain a resale certificate from a buyer:

subparagraph.text: before the sale is consummated; or
if the vendor receives a notice of the Comptroller’s intent to assess sales and use tax for failure to obtain a proper resale certificate, within 60 days after the date on which the notice is mailed.

paragraph.text: If the vendor fails to obtain the resale certificate as required, the Comptroller’s assessment under paragraph (4)(ii) of this subsection is final.

subsection.text: If the taxable price is less than $200 for a cash, check, or credit card sale or sale for use that is not a retail sale and the tangible personal property or taxable service is not delivered by the vendor directly to the buyer’s retail place of business:

paragraph.text: the sales and use tax shall be paid when the sale is made or when the use becomes taxable; and
the buyer who pays the sales and use tax may file a claim for a refund with the Comptroller.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provisions of law, before a State agency issues a rebate or similar instrument or authorizes a rebate or similar instrument to be issued by a nongovernment entity to reduce the cost of a retail sale of household appliances under a program to promote energy efficiency, the State agency or nongovernment entity shall require the buyer of a household appliance to certify that:

paragraph.text: the household appliance was purchased at a retail sale in the State; or
the buyer paid the applicable State sales and use tax.

section.text: A marina that sells dyed diesel fuel, as defined in § 11–104(h) of this title:

paragraph.text: shall pay the sales and use tax to the Comptroller; and
may not collect the sales and use tax from the buyer as a separately stated item.

subsection.text: A buyer who fails to pay the sales and use tax on a purchase or use subject to the tax to the vendor as required in § 11-403 of this title or who is required by regulation to file a return for a purchase or use subject to the tax shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller a sales and use tax return:

paragraph.text: on or before the 20th day of the month that follows the month in which the buyer makes that purchase or use; and
for other periods and on other dates that the Comptroller specifies, by regulation, including periods in which the buyer does not make any purchase or use subject to the sales and use tax.

subsection.text: The return shall state for the period that the return covers:

paragraph.text: the total value of the tangible personal property or taxable service that is subject to the sales and use tax; and
the sales and use tax due.

subsection.text: Each vendor shall complete, under oath, and file with the Comptroller a sales and use tax return:

paragraph.text: on or before the 20th day of the month that follows the month in which the vendor makes any retail sale or sale for use; and
