The Comptroller shall pay the financial institution a reasonable fee, not to exceed the actual costs incurred by the financial institution to comply with the requirements of this section, less any fees received from other units of the State for the same report.
The Comptroller may institute civil proceedings to enforce this section.

subsection.text: A financial institution that complies with a request from the Comptroller by submitting a report to the Comptroller in accordance with subsection (d) of this section is not liable under State law to any person for any:

paragraph.text: disclosure of information to the Comptroller under this section; or
other action taken in good faith to comply with the requirements of this section.

subsection.text: A financial institution furnishing a report to the Comptroller under this section is prohibited from disclosing to an obligor that the name of that obligor has been received from or furnished to the Comptroller.
Unpaid tax, interest, and penalties constitute a lien, in favor of the State, extending to all property and rights to property belonging to:

paragraph.text: the person required to pay the tax; or
the fiduciary estate on which the tax is imposed.

subsection.text: Unpaid inheritance tax, interest, and penalties constitute a lien, in favor of the State, extending to:

paragraph.text: the assets of a small business for which an alternative payment schedule was granted under § 7-218 of this article; and
any other property on which inheritance tax is due.

subsection.text: Unpaid Maryland estate tax and interest constitute a lien, in favor of the State, extending to the estate that is subject to the Maryland estate tax.

Unpaid Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax and interest constitute a lien, in favor of the State, extending to any property included in the generation-skipping transfer for which the Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax is due.

Unless another date is specified by law and except for a lien under subsection (b) of this section, a lien arises on the date of notice that the tax is due and continues to the date on which the lien is:

paragraph.text: satisfied; or
released by the tax collector because the lien is:

subparagraph.text: unenforceable by reason of lapse of time; or
uncollectible.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a lien for unpaid inheritance tax:

subparagraph.text: arises on the date of distribution; and
continues for 4 years.

paragraph.text: If the property is subject to a special valuation under § 7-211 of this article, a lien:

subparagraph.text: arises on the date on which the interest in the property vests in possession; and
continues for 4 years.

paragraph.text: If the unpaid inheritance tax is attributable to the disqualification of property that was qualified for special valuation or exemption under § 7-211 of this article, the lien:

subparagraph.text: arises on the date on which the decedent died; and
continues for 20 years.

subsection.text: A tax collector may file a notice of tax lien with the clerk of the circuit court for the county where the property that is subject to the lien is located.

paragraph.text: On receipt of a notice of tax lien, the clerk of a circuit court promptly shall:

subparagraph.text: record and index the lien; and
enter the lien in the judgment docket of the court.

paragraph.text: The docket entry shall include:

subparagraph.text: the name of the person whose property is subject to the tax lien; and
the amount and date of the tax lien.

section.text: From the date on which a tax lien is filed under § 13-807 of this subtitle, the lien has the full force and effect of a judgment lien.

subsection.text: A tax lien shall be first paid and satisfied from the proceeds of a sale of any property of a person liable for the tax.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a tax lien is not valid against any purchaser, holder of a security interest, mechanic’s lienor, or judgment lien creditor until notice of the tax lien has been filed under § 13-807 of this subtitle.
Even if notice of a tax lien is filed, the lien is not valid against any claim described in § 6323(b), (c), or (d) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: The rules and definitions in § 6323(e), (h), and (i) of the Internal Revenue Code shall apply in construing this section.

If a tax lien is not satisfied or released on or before the 15th day after the notice of the lien is filed, recorded, and indexed under § 13-807 of this subtitle, a qualified attorney who is a regular salaried employee of the Comptroller or, at the request of the tax collector, the Attorney General may bring an action in a court of the State to enforce the lien.
The following persons shall be made parties to the proceeding:

paragraph.text: each person who has a lien on the property that is sought to be subjected to the proceedings; and
each person who claims a right to or an interest in the property that is sought to be subjected to the proceedings.

subsection.text: The court, acting without a jury, shall:

paragraph.text: adjudicate all matters involved in the proceedings; and
determine the merits of all claims or liens.

subsection.text: If the claim or interest of the State is established, the court may order:

paragraph.text: a sale of the property or rights to property; and
a distribution of any proceeds of sale in accordance with the interests of the parties and the State.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Paymaster”:

subparagraph.text: means an employer’s officer, representative, agent, or employee charged with the duty of paying salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services to an employee named in a notice of lien; and

if the person named in a notice of lien is employed by the federal government or its instrumentality with an office in the State where employee records are kept, whether or not payroll records are kept or the payroll is prepared at that office, includes the employee who:

sub-subparagraph.text: is designated to keep and maintain employee records in that office; and
is or may be designated to receive and distribute pay checks to the employees.

paragraph.text: “Tax wage lien” means the lien on wages described in this section.

subsection.text: A tax lien for any tax administered by the Comptroller under this article extends to and covers all salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services that is due or becomes payable on or after the time the lien arises.
The Comptroller promptly shall give notice of a tax wage lien that states the lien amount, the type of tax, and the name of the person against whom the lien is taken by:

paragraph.text: certified mail, return receipt requested, under the postmark of the United States Postal Service, to the employer; or
personal service on the employer.

If an employer knows or has reason to know of the import of the contents of the certified mail and refuses to accept its delivery, service as required under subsection (c)(1) of this section is made when delivery is refused.
Service as required under subsection (c)(2) of this section is made when personal service is made on an officer or paymaster of the employer.

From salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services that is due or becomes payable on or after the date on which a notice of wage lien is served to the date on which a notice of satisfaction or release of the wage lien is received, an employer or paymaster promptly shall pay to the Comptroller any salary, wages, or other compensation due to the delinquent taxpayer, excluding only those amounts specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The amount excluded under paragraph (1) of this subsection from amounts paid to the delinquent taxpayer is the amount exempt from attachment provided in § 15-601.1 of the Commercial Law Article.

subsection.text: The Comptroller promptly shall give a notice of satisfaction or release of a tax wage lien to each employer or paymaster who received notice of the wage lien.

If, after service of a notice of a tax wage lien, an employer or paymaster pays an employee salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services in excess of the amount allowed in subsection (e)(2) of this section, the employer or paymaster or both shall be personally liable for the excess amount paid to the employee. However, the total amount that the Comptroller recovers may not exceed the total amount paid to the employee in violation of this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Account”, “account holder of interest”, and “financial institution” have the meanings stated in § 13-804 of this subtitle.
“Obligor” means a person whose property is subject to a tax lien.

subparagraph.text: The Comptroller may send notice of a tax lien to any financial institution that the Comptroller reasonably believes holds property subject to a tax lien.
The notice to be sent under this paragraph shall be provided by:

sub-subparagraph.text: first-class mail, under the postmark of the United States Postal Service, at the address designated for this purpose by the financial institution or, if no address has been designated, to the principal office of the financial institution;
an electronic format agreed on by the Comptroller and the financial institution; or
any other reasonable manner as agreed on by the Comptroller and the financial institution.

paragraph.text: The notice to be sent by the Comptroller to a financial institution under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name of the obligor;
the amount of the tax lien;
the last known address of the obligor;
the Social Security number or federal employer identification number of the obligor; and

a notice to immediately seize and attach from one or more accounts held by the financial institution in the name of the obligor an aggregate amount equal to the lesser of the amounts in all accounts or the amount of the tax lien.

paragraph.text: On receipt of the notice described in subsection (b) of this section, the financial institution promptly shall seize and attach from one or more of the accounts of the obligor held by the financial institution an aggregate amount equal to the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the total of the amounts in all the accounts of the obligor held by the financial institution; or
the amount stated in the notice sent under subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: Within 30 days after the financial institution receives the notice directing it to seize and attach accounts of the obligor, the financial institution shall send notice to the Comptroller, in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section, specifying the aggregate amount held under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: The financial institution may assess a fee against the accounts or the obligor, in addition to the amount identified in the notice under subsection (b) of this section.

In the case of insufficient funds to cover both the fee and the amount identified in the notice under subsection (b) of this section, the financial institution may first deduct and retain the fee from the amount seized and attached as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: The financial institution may not be held liable to any person, including the Comptroller, the obligor, or any account holder of interest, for wrongful dishonor or for any other claim relating to the seizure and attachment of an account or other actions taken in compliance with this section.

Within 10 business days after the Comptroller has received notice from the financial institution under subsection (c)(2) of this section, the Comptroller shall send a notice to the obligor, by regular mail, to the obligor’s last known address.
The notice shall contain the following information, to the extent known by the Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: the address of the Comptroller;
the telephone number, address, and name of a contact person at the office of the Comptroller;
the name and Social Security number, federal employer identification number, or other taxpayer identification number of the obligor;
the address of the obligor;
for each account of the obligor, the name of the financial institution that has seized and attached amounts as required by this section;
the total amount of the tax lien owed by the obligor;
the date the notice is being sent;

a statement informing the obligor that the Comptroller has directed the financial institution to seize and attach the amount of the tax lien owed by the obligor from one or more of the accounts of the obligor and, on subsequent notice by the Comptroller, to forward the amount to the Comptroller; and

a statement informing the obligor that, unless a timely challenge is made by the obligor or an account holder of interest under subsection (g) of this section, the Comptroller shall notify the financial institution to forward the amount seized and attached by the financial institution to the Comptroller.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall not be obligated to send the notice described in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection if, prior to the time that the notice must be sent, the Comptroller and the obligor agree to an arrangement under which the obligor will pay amounts owed under the tax lien.

If a timely challenge is not made by the obligor or an account holder of interest under subsection (g) of this section, the Comptroller shall send a notice to the financial institution, in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section, directing the institution to:

subparagraph.text: forward the amount seized and attached by the financial institution to the Comptroller;
reduce the amount seized and attached by the financial institution to a revised amount as stated, forward the revised amount to the Comptroller, and release the excess amount; or
release the amount seized and attached by the financial institution.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may send the notice described in paragraph (1) of this subsection before the time for filing a timely challenge under subsection (g) of this section on agreement among the Comptroller, the obligor, and, if the Comptroller is aware of an account holder of interest, the account holder of interest.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall apply the amount seized and forwarded by the financial institution to the obligor’s tax lien obligation.

paragraph.text: An obligor or an account holder of interest may challenge the actions of the Comptroller under this section by filing a motion with the circuit court within 10 days of the date of the notice sent under subsection (d)(1) of this section.
An obligor or an account holder of interest may challenge the actions of the Comptroller based on:

subparagraph.text: a mistake in the identity of the obligor;
a mistake in the ownership of the account;
a mistake in the contents of the account;
invalidity of the Comptroller’s actions under § 11-603 of the Courts Article;
a mistake in the amount of the lien obligation due; or
any other good cause.

paragraph.text: An obligor or an account holder of interest may not challenge the actions of the Comptroller based on a mistake or error in the original tax assessment underlying the tax lien against the obligor.

The Comptroller may withdraw the notice to seize and attach accounts by sending notice to the financial institution, in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section, directing the financial institution to release the attachment on the accounts.

If a determination is made by the Comptroller or by the circuit court that the account or accounts of the obligor should not have been held, the Comptroller shall notify the financial institution, in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section, to release the amount seized and attached by the financial institution.

If a determination is made by the Comptroller or by the circuit court, pursuant to a challenge under subsection (g) of this section, to reduce the amount seized and attached by the financial institution, the Comptroller shall notify the financial institution, in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section, to revise the amount as stated, forward the revised amount to the Comptroller, and release the excess amount seized and attached by the financial institution.

If a challenge made under subsection (g) of this section is denied by the circuit court, the Comptroller shall notify the financial institution, in the manner specified in subsection (b) of this section, to forward the amount seized and attached by the financial institution to the Comptroller.

subsection.text: A financial institution that complies with a notice from the Comptroller sent under this section is not liable under State law to any person for:

paragraph.text: any disclosure of information to the Comptroller under this section;
seizing and attaching any amounts from an account or sending any amount seized and attached by the financial institution to the Comptroller; or
any other action taken in good faith to comply with the requirements of this section.

subsection.text: A financial institution has no obligation to reimburse fees assessed as a result of the Comptroller instituting an action under this section or as otherwise permitted by law or authorized by contract.
This section may not be construed to prohibit the Comptroller from collecting taxes due from the obligor in any other manner authorized by law.
Within the period allowed in Subtitle 11 of this title, an action to collect tax imposed under this article may be brought in a court of competent jurisdiction.
If a person owes State and county or municipal corporation taxes to the same tax collector, an action under this section may combine claims for those taxes.

If a tax under this article is not paid when due, the Governor, tax collector, or Treasurer shall ask a qualified attorney who is a regular salaried employee of the Comptroller or the Attorney General to bring an action against the person responsible to pay the tax, unless a lien on real property under Part II of this subtitle sufficiently secures the tax or a judgment in the action would not be collectible.

paragraph.text: If a request is made under subsection (a) of this section, the attorney or the Attorney General shall bring the action.
In an action under this section, the plaintiff shall be:

subparagraph.text: the State;
the Treasurer; or
the tax collector authorized by law to collect the tax.

subsection.text: If the attorney or Attorney General and the tax collector agree that the full amount of the claim is not collectible, the attorney or Attorney General may:

paragraph.text: compromise the claim;
accept a lesser amount; and
issue a release of the claim or a satisfaction of the judgment.

subsection.text: In an action under § 13-816 of this subtitle, a request for attachment before judgment against any asset of the defendant may be filed in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
The plaintiff in the action is not required to file an attachment bond.
If the plaintiff in an action under § 13-816 of this subtitle requests, the action shall be tried as soon as the action is at issue and shall take precedence over all other civil cases.
In an action under § 13-816 of this subtitle, a certificate of the tax collector that shows the amount of tax, penalty, and interest due:

paragraph.text: is prima facie evidence of the amount of tax, penalty, and interest; and
imposes on the defendant the burden of proving that the tax, penalty, and interest have been paid or any other defense.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, if a tax collector finds that the collection of a tax under this article will be jeopardized by the departure, from the State, of the person required to pay the tax, the removal of property from the State, the concealment of the person or the property, or any other act, the tax collector immediately may assess the tax, interest, and penalty as a jeopardy assessment.
The tax collector shall mail to the person required to pay the tax a notice of jeopardy assessment that states:

paragraph.text: the findings about the jeopardy of tax collection;
the amount of the assessment; and
a demand that the person immediately:

subparagraph.text: pay the assessment; or
submit evidence that collection of the tax is not in jeopardy.

subsection.text: The findings of the tax collector about the jeopardy of tax collection are final and conclusive.

If, within the 10 days after a notice of jeopardy assessment is mailed, a person fails to comply with the notice, the tax collector may take any action to collect the unpaid tax as authorized under this title.

section.text: To protect tax revenue, a tax collector may, to the extent allowed or required under § 13-825 of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: set an amount to secure payment of the tax, interest, and penalty that is due or may become due; and
require acceptable security to be posted.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may require a person whose gross receipts are subject to admissions and amusement tax and whose business is not a permanent operation in the State to post security for the tax in the amount that the Comptroller determines.
The Comptroller shall require:

paragraph.text: a manufacturer, wholesaler, or nonresident winery permit holder who sells or delivers beer or wine to retailers in the State to post security for the alcoholic beverage tax:

subparagraph.text: in an amount not less than:

sub-subparagraph.text: $1,000 for beer; and
$1,000 for wine; and

subparagraph.text: if the alcoholic beverage tax on beer and wine paid in any 1 month exceeds $1,000, in an additional amount at least equal to the excess;

paragraph.text: a manufacturer or wholesaler who sells or delivers any distilled spirits or any wine and distilled spirits in the State to post a security for the alcoholic beverage tax:

subparagraph.text: in an amount not less than $5,000; and
in an additional amount:

sub-subparagraph.text: equal to twice the amount of its largest monthly alcoholic beverage tax liability for wine and distilled spirits in the preceding calendar year less $5,000; or
if the information for the preceding calendar year is not available or cannot be provided, equal to the amount that the Comptroller requires; and

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (i) of this section, a holder of a direct wine shipper’s permit to post security for the alcoholic beverage tax in an amount not less than $1,000.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may require a person whose gross receipts are subject to the boxing and wrestling tax to post security for the boxing and wrestling tax in the amount that the Comptroller determines.
The Comptroller may require a real estate investment trust to post security for income tax in the amount that the Comptroller requires, if the trust:

paragraph.text: does not hold property in the State; or
holds insufficient property in the State to provide adequate security for the income tax if the property were to become subject to a lien under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may require a person seeking a refund of motor carrier tax to post security for the tax in an amount of not less than $5,000 but not more than $100,000.

The Comptroller shall require an applicant for any license under Title 9 of this article, except for a Class “W” license, to post security for the motor fuel tax in the amount that the Comptroller requires, but not less than:

paragraph.text: $200,000 for a Class “A” license;
$50,000 for a Class “B” license;
$10,000 for a Class “C” license;
$200,000 for a Class “D” license;
$1,000 for a Class “F” license;
$10,000 for a Class “G–Temporary” license;
$1,000 for a Class “S” license; and
$1,000 for a Class “U” license.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may require a person subject to the sales and use tax to post security for the tax in the amount that the Comptroller determines.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may require a person subject to the tobacco tax to post security for the tax in the following amounts:

subparagraph.text: for a manufacturer or wholesaler:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount, if any, by which the tobacco tax due for any 1 month exceeds $10,000;

subparagraph.text: for a subwholesaler or vending machine operator:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount, if any, by which the tobacco tax due for any 1 month exceeds $1,000; and

subparagraph.text: for an other tobacco products wholesaler:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount, if any, by which the tobacco tax due for any 1 month exceeds $5,000.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (5) of this subsection, the Comptroller may exempt a person from posting security for the tobacco tax if the person is and has been for the past 5 years:

subparagraph.text: licensed as required under § 16–202 of the Business Regulation Article to act as a wholesaler or § 16.5–201 to act as an other tobacco products wholesaler; and

sub-subparagraph.text: in continuous compliance with the tobacco tax laws, as determined under paragraph (3) of this subsection; and
in continuous compliance with the conditions of the person’s security posted under this subsection.

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person is in continuous compliance with the tobacco tax laws for a period if the person has not, at any time during that period:

subparagraph.text: failed to pay any tobacco tax or any tobacco tax assessment when due;
failed to file a tobacco tax return when due; or
otherwise violated any of the provisions of Title 12 or Title 13 of this article or Title 16 or Title 16.5 of the Business Regulation Article.

An exemption granted under paragraph (2) of this subsection is effective only to the extent that a person’s potential tobacco tax liability does not exceed an amount determined by the Comptroller based on the person’s experience during the 5–year compliance period under paragraph (2) of this subsection.

The Comptroller may revoke an exemption granted to a person under paragraph (2) of this subsection if the person at any time fails to be in continuous compliance with the tobacco tax laws, as described in paragraph (3) of this subsection.

The Comptroller may reinstate an exemption revoked under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph if the person meets the requirements of paragraph (2)(i) and (ii) of this subsection for a period of 2 years following the revocation.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may not exempt a person from posting a bond or other security for the tobacco tax unless the Comptroller determines that the person is solvent and financially able to pay the person’s potential tobacco tax liability.

If a corporation is granted an exemption from posting a bond or other security for the tobacco tax, any officer of the corporation who exercises direct control over its fiscal management is personally liable for any tobacco tax, interest and penalties owed by the corporation.

subsection.text: A person need not post security under subsection (b)(3) of this section if:

paragraph.text: the person is a manufacturer that has posted security under subsection (b)(2) of this section; or
at any time starting 3 years after the Comptroller first issues a direct wine shipper’s permit to the person, the Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: determines that the person has a substantial record of tax and reporting compliance; and
waives the security requirement.

section.text: The following securities are acceptable:

paragraph.text: a bond issued by a surety company that is authorized to do business in the State and is approved by the State Insurance Commissioner as to solvency and responsibility;
cash in an amount that the tax collector approves;
marketable securities that the tax collector approves; or
for admissions and amusement tax, alcoholic beverage tax, boxing and wrestling tax, and tobacco tax, an irrevocable letter of credit:

subparagraph.text: in an amount that the Comptroller approves; and
with a date certain for coverage during the collection period.

section.text: When a tax collector requires a person to post security under § 13-825 of this subtitle, the tax collector shall mail the person a notice of the requirement and the amount required to be posted.

subsection.text: If, within 5 days after the date on which the notice to post security is mailed to a person, the person submits to the tax collector a written request for a hearing, the tax collector shall:

paragraph.text: hold the hearing; and
at the hearing, make a final determination of the necessity for, propriety of, and amount of the security.

subsection.text: The tax collector shall mail the person a notice of the final determination.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person shall post the security required under § 13-825 of this subtitle within 5 days after the date on which the notice is mailed under § 13-827 of this subtitle.
If a hearing is held under § 13-828 of this subtitle, a person shall post the security within 15 days after the date on which the notice of the tax collector’s final determination is mailed.

section.text: If the tax, interest, and penalty are not paid when due, the tax collector, without notice to the person who posted the security under § 13-829 of this subtitle, may:

paragraph.text: apply a cash or security deposit to the tax, interest, or penalty; or
sell a security at public or private auction and apply the proceeds of the sale to the tax, interest, or penalty.

subsection.text: Except for a liability that has accrued or will accrue before the date of release or discharge, a surety is released and discharged from liability on a bond to the State 60 days after the surety submits to the tax collector a written request for release or discharge.
On receipt of a written request from a surety for release and discharge, the tax collector promptly shall give the person who posted the bond notice that:

paragraph.text: the surety has asked to be released and discharged from liability on the bond; and
a substitute security must be filed before the date on which the surety is released and discharged under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitation in subsection (b) of this section, if a tax under this article is referred for collection to an independent agency with which the Comptroller has contracted for the collection of taxes, in addition to interest and penalties required to be assessed under this subtitle the Comptroller shall assess a collection fee sufficient to cover all collection costs charged by the agency to the Comptroller.

The collection fee assessed by the Comptroller under paragraph (a) of this section may not, as a percentage, exceed the percentage of the fee charged by the Central Collection Unit in accordance with § 3-304(a)(2) of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
For reasonable cause, the Comptroller may waive or reduce a collection fee assessed under this section.
In this Part VI of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Contraband alcoholic beverage” means an alcoholic beverage, as defined in § 5-101 of this article:

paragraph.text: on which alcoholic beverage tax is not paid; and
that is delivered, possessed, sold, or transported in the State in a manner not authorized under Title 5 of this article or Article 2B of the Code.

subsection.text: “Contraband tobacco products” means cigarettes or other tobacco products, as defined in § 12-101 of this article:

paragraph.text: on which tobacco tax is not paid; and
that are delivered, possessed, sold, or transported in the State in a manner not authorized under Title 12 of this article or Title 16 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: “Contraband motor fuel” means motor fuel, as defined in § 9-101 of this article:

paragraph.text: on which motor fuel tax is not paid; and
that is delivered, possessed, sold, or transferred in the State in a manner not authorized under Title 9 of this article or Title 10 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: “Conveyance” means:

paragraph.text: an aircraft, vehicle, or vessel used to transport alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, or other tobacco products; and
a tank car, vehicle, or vessel that is used to transport motor fuel and that, exclusive of any tank used for its own propulsion, has a capacity exceeding 50 gallons.

subsection.text: The Comptroller or a peace officer of the State may:

paragraph.text: seize contraband alcoholic beverages or contraband tobacco products in the State without a warrant;

stop and search a conveyance in the State if the Comptroller or officer knows or has reason to suspect that the conveyance is being used to transport in the State contraband tobacco products having a retail value of $100 or more or contraband alcoholic beverages; and
seize a conveyance being used in the State to transport contraband alcoholic beverages or contraband tobacco products.

subsection.text: A police officer of the State may:

paragraph.text: seize any contraband motor fuel in the State without a warrant;
stop and search a conveyance in the State for contraband motor fuel if the officer has probable cause to believe that the conveyance is being used to carry contraband motor fuel in the State; and
seize a conveyance being used to transport contraband motor fuel.
If contraband alcoholic beverages or contraband tobacco products are seized:

subparagraph.text: the Comptroller or police officer shall give a notice of seizure to the person from whom the property is seized at the time of the seizure; and
the Comptroller shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: where possible, give a notice of seizure to the registered owner of a seized conveyance; and
publish a notice of seizure of the conveyance in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the seizure occurred.

paragraph.text: If contraband motor fuel is seized, within 48 hours after the seizure, not including weekends and holidays, the Comptroller shall give a notice of seizure to:

subparagraph.text: the owner of the contraband motor fuel;
the registered owner of the seized conveyance; and
any secured party noted in the records of the Motor Vehicle Administration.

paragraph.text: A notice of seizure shall state the right of an owner or other interested person, including a secured party of record, to file a claim for the return of the seized property.
A police officer who seizes a conveyance used to transport contraband alcoholic beverages promptly shall notify the Comptroller of the seizure.

A police officer who seizes any contraband tobacco products or conveyance used to transport contraband tobacco products shall deliver the seized cigarettes or other tobacco products and conveyance to the Comptroller.
A police officer who seizes any contraband motor fuel shall:

subparagraph.text: deliver the seized contraband motor fuel and conveyance to the Comptroller; or

if the seized conveyance is operated by a common carrier, regulated by either the Maryland Public Service Commission or the Interstate Commerce Commission, and transports motor fuel for another person, for a fee, direct the operator of the conveyance to take it to a location that the Comptroller designates.

subsection.text: For a seized conveyance transporting contraband motor fuel that is operated by a common carrier, the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: remove the contraband from the conveyance at the location that the Comptroller designates;
retain the contraband, subject to §§ 13-840 and 13-841 of this subtitle;
after removing the contraband, release the conveyance to its operator; and
reimburse the common carrier for all tariff charges applicable to the movement of the conveyance from:

subparagraph.text: the place of seizure to the location where the contraband motor fuel was removed; and
the place where the contraband motor fuel was removed to the nearer of the common carrier’s home terminal or the place of seizure.

section.text: The owner or another person with an interest in seized property may file a claim for the return of the property with the Comptroller within 30 days after:

paragraph.text: the seizure of alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, other tobacco products, motor fuel or conveyances used to transport motor fuel; or
a notice of seizure of a conveyance used to transport alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, or other tobacco products is published.

subsection.text: A person forfeits any interest, right, or title to property that is seized for violation of the alcoholic beverage tax laws if the person:

paragraph.text: fails to file a claim for return of the seized property within the time allowed under § 13–837 of this subtitle; or
is adjudged guilty of violating the alcoholic beverage tax laws.

If, within the time allowed to file a claim under § 13–837 of this subtitle, a person who has a lien interest in property seized for violation of the alcoholic beverage tax law files a petition, the circuit court for the county in which property is seized shall proceed in rem to hear and determine the question of forfeiture of the interest by the lien holder.
If the circuit court finds that the lien holder had knowledge of the intended unlawful use of the property, the interest, right, and title of a lien holder shall be forfeited.
Absent a finding under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Comptroller, in the best interest of the State may:

subparagraph.text: pay the outstanding indebtedness secured by the lawful lien and keep the property; or
deliver the property to the lien holder.

subsection.text: If a person files a claim for return of seized alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, other tobacco products, or a conveyance used for their transportation under § 13-837 of this subtitle, the Comptroller or the Comptroller’s designee shall:

paragraph.text: promptly act on the request and hold an informal hearing;

direct the return of alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, or other tobacco products unless the Comptroller or Comptroller’s designee has satisfactory proof that the person was not in compliance with any provisions of Title 5 or Title 12 of this article at the time of seizure; and

direct the return of the conveyance if the Comptroller or Comptroller’s designee has satisfactory proof that the owner of the conveyance was not willfully evading any provisions of Title 5 or Title 12 of this article at the time of seizure.

subsection.text: The Comptroller or Comptroller’s designee shall grant or deny the application for return of seized alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, other tobacco products, or a conveyance in accordance with subsection (a) of this section by mailing the person a notice of final determination.
If a person files with the Comptroller a claim for return of the seized motor fuel or conveyances used in its transportation, the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: provide an opportunity for a hearing; and
if requested by the claimant, conduct the hearing within 5 working days after the claim is received.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: make a final determination of whether the property should be forfeited within 2 working days after the date of the conclusion of the hearing; and
mail a notice of the final determination on the date on which that determination is made.
Contraband alcoholic beverages that are seized under this title and forfeited may be disposed of or destroyed in the manner allowed under Article 2B, § 1-201(f)(5) and (6) and (g) of the Code.
The Comptroller shall sell at public auction a conveyance that is seized under this title in connection with contraband alcoholic beverages and forfeited.

The Comptroller shall sell contraband tobacco products seized under this title and forfeited to a State institution, a nonprofit charitable institution, a licensed cigarette wholesaler, or a licensed cigarette manufacturer in the manner the Comptroller determines.
The Comptroller shall sell at public auction a conveyance that is seized under this title in connection with contraband tobacco products and forfeited.
If either the Comptroller or, on appeal, a court determines that seized conveyance or motor fuel is not subject to forfeiture:

subparagraph.text: the Comptroller is not required to return the motor fuel seized to the owner or other interested person who filed the claim for return of the property, but may, at the option of the Comptroller, pay to the person an amount equal to the value of the motor fuel as determined by the average wholesale value on the date of seizure for the Baltimore Terminal as reported by a nationally recognized oil price reporting service on the date of seizure; and
the Comptroller shall return the conveyance to the registered owner and shall have no further liability to the registered owner.

paragraph.text: If a seized conveyance or motor fuel is forfeited, the Comptroller shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: use the contraband motor fuel for any public purpose; or
sell the contraband motor fuel to any person; and

subparagraph.text: sell the seized conveyance to any person.

subsection.text: In the manner required under Title 2 of this article for distributions of revenue, the Comptroller shall distribute the net proceeds from the sale of any conveyance or other property under this section after paying:

paragraph.text: the costs incurred in conjunction with the seizure and disposal of the property;
the cost of the sale; and
any bona fide lien against the conveyance.

section.text: A person who possessed contraband alcoholic beverages, contraband tobacco products, or contraband motor fuel that are seized and sold under this section is not relieved from any penalty under this title.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, if the inheritance tax determined on an interest in property under § 7-209, § 7-210, or § 7-211 of this article is not paid when due, the court that has jurisdiction to administer the estate shall order the personal representative to sell as much of the interest in property on which inheritance tax is unpaid as is necessary to:

paragraph.text: pay inheritance tax on the property; and
pay the expenses of the sale.

subsection.text: A court may not order the sale of an interest in property under subsection (a) of this section after the period provided for the lien on the property under § 13-806 of this subtitle has expired.
A claim for refund may be filed with the tax collector who collects the tax, fee, or charge by a claimant who:

paragraph.text: erroneously pays to the State a greater amount of tax, fee, charge, interest, or penalty than is properly and legally payable;
pays to the State a tax, fee, charge, interest, or penalty that is erroneously, illegally, or wrongfully assessed or collected in any manner; or
pays a tax qualifying for refund under subsections (b) through (h) of this section.

subsection.text: A claim for refund of alcoholic beverage tax may be filed by a claimant who:

paragraph.text: buys alcoholic beverages that are exempt under § 5-104(b) of this article;
discontinues an alcoholic beverage business;
discontinues the sale and delivery in the State of alcoholic beverages in certain container sizes; or
holds alcoholic beverages for sale that:

subparagraph.text: are condemned by an authorized official; or
if the claim is $250 or more, are lost, rendered unmarketable, or destroyed in the State due to fire, flood, or other disaster, or due to vandalism or malicious mischief, except loss due to theft.

paragraph.text: A claim for refund of income tax may be filed by a claimant whose Maryland taxable income is decreased as a result of a federal contract renegotiation under § 1481 of the Internal Revenue Code.
A claim for refund of income tax under this subsection or subsection (a) of this section may be filed:

subparagraph.text: by the claimant; or
on behalf of the claimant, by a person allowed to file a return under § 10-808 of this article.

subsection.text: A claim for refund of Maryland estate tax or Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax may be filed by a claimant required to pay the tax if:

paragraph.text: the Maryland estate tax is decreased as a result of:

subparagraph.text: a decrease in the federal estate tax on the estate; or
an inheritance tax payment made after a Maryland estate tax payment; or

paragraph.text: the Maryland generation-skipping transfer tax is decreased as a result of a decrease in the federal generation-skipping transfer tax on the generation-skipping transfer.

subsection.text: A claim for refund of motor carrier tax may be filed by a claimant who has excess motor carrier tax credit, if:

paragraph.text: the claimant has provided the security required for a motor carrier under § 13-825 of this title; or
the Comptroller has audited the records of the claimant.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a claim for refund of motor fuel tax may be filed by a claimant who pays the tax on:

subparagraph.text: aviation fuel, as defined in § 9–101 of this article, that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: dispensed to aircraft by an aircraft manufacturing company located in the State; or
used:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: by a person who engages in agricultural activities; and
in an aircraft that is used for agricultural purposes at least 70% of the time that the aircraft is used; or

subparagraph.text: motor fuel, as defined in § 9–101 of this article, that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is used to operate:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a bus that is used only in the operation of a transportation system of a political subdivision of the State to transport the public on regular schedules between fixed termini, as defined in Title 11 of the Transportation Article;
farm equipment that is used for an agricultural purpose and is not registered to operate on a public highway;
fire or rescue apparatus or vehicles by a volunteer fire company or nonprofit volunteer rescue company incorporated in the State;
an internal combustion engine that is installed permanently at a fixed location; or
a vehicle that is owned and used by a Maryland chapter of the American Red Cross or a bona fide unit of a national veterans’ organization;

sub-subparagraph.text: is bought by:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the United States or a unit of the United States government;
the Department of General Services for use by State agencies; or
a person who is required to pay a tax on the same fuel to another state;

sub-subparagraph.text: except for any operation of a motor vehicle on a public highway in the State, is used for a commercial purpose, including:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the operation of a vessel used only for commercial purposes;
commercial cleaning; or
commercial dyeing;

sub-subparagraph.text: is used in any of the following vehicles that have pumping or other equipment mechanically or hydraulically driven by the engine that propels the vehicle:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a concrete mixing motor vehicle or concrete pump truck;
a motor fuel delivery vehicle;
a solid waste compacting vehicle;
a well–drilling vehicle; or
farm equipment registered as a vehicle for highway use that is designed or adapted solely and used exclusively for bulk farm spreading of agriculture liming materials, chemicals, or fertilizer;

sub-subparagraph.text: is used by a system of transportation based in the State, in a vehicle that is used to provide transportation to elderly or low income individuals, or individuals with disabilities, if the system is operated by a nonprofit organization for purposes relating to the charge for which the nonprofit organization was established and the nonprofit organization:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is exempt for federal income tax purposes under § 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code;
is funded to provide transportation to elderly or low income individuals, or individuals with disabilities;
receives part of its operating funding from the Maryland Department of Transportation or the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;

has stated in its charter or bylaws that operating transportation services for elderly or low income individuals, or individuals with disabilities, is one of the purposes for which it was established; and
is actively operating a system of transportation for elderly or low income individuals, or individuals with disabilities; or

sub-subparagraph.text: is lost as a result of fire, collision, or other casualty, except for loss in ordinary transportation and storage.

paragraph.text: A refund based on a claim under paragraph (1)(ii)4 of this subsection may not exceed the following percentages of the motor fuel tax paid:

subparagraph.text: 35% for a concrete mixing vehicle or concrete pump truck;
55% for farm equipment, registered as a vehicle for highway use, that is designed or adapted solely and used exclusively for bulk spreading of agriculture liming materials, chemicals, or fertilizers;
10% for a motor fuel delivery vehicle;
15% for a solid waste compacting vehicle; and
80% for a well–drilling vehicle.

paragraph.text: A person may not make a claim for a refund of motor fuel tax under paragraph (1)(ii)1B of this subsection for motor fuel used to operate a farm truck under the provisions of § 8–602(c) of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: A claim for refund of sales and use tax may be filed by a claimant who:

paragraph.text: pays the tax on a sale exempt under § 11-216 of this article;
refunds the tax to a buyer in a canceled or rescinded sale under § 11-403(c) of this article;
pays the tax in a canceled or rescinded sale for which the vendor refuses to refund the tax as required under § 11-403(c) of this article; or
pays the tax under § 11-408(c) of this article on a cash sale or sale for use that is not a retail sale.

subsection.text: A claim for refund of tobacco tax may be filed by a claimant who buys tobacco tax stamps that:

paragraph.text: are affixed erroneously to anything other than a package of cigarettes;
are affixed to a package of unsalable cigarettes;
are canceled by the Comptroller;
if the claim is $250 or more, are lost or destroyed in the State due to fire, flood, or other disaster, vandalism, or malicious mischief, except loss due to theft; or
mutilated or damaged, whether or not affixed to a package of cigarettes.

section.text: A claim for refund shall be:

paragraph.text: made, under oath, in the form that the tax collector requires; and
supported by the documents that the tax collector requires, including original invoices showing alcoholic beverage and motor fuel purchases.

section.text: A claim for refund shall be filed within the time required under § 13-1104 of this title.

subsection.text: The tax collector shall:

paragraph.text: investigate each claim for refund; and
conduct a hearing at the request of the claimant prior to a final determination on the claim.

subsection.text: The tax collector shall give the claimant notice of:

paragraph.text: the determination of the claim for refund; and
any delay in paying an allowed claim.

subsection.text: Subject to the additional provisions under this section, a tax collector shall pay any claim for refund that has been allowed by the tax collector unless:

paragraph.text: the claimant has not paid all other taxes, fees, or charges payable to the State; or
the amount of the refund due is less than $1.

subsection.text: If a claim for refund of income tax is based on a return that is filed jointly by the personal representative and surviving spouse of a decedent, the Comptroller shall pay the claim to the estate of the decedent.
The payment of income tax refunds is subject to tax refund interception under § 10–113 of the Family Law Article and §§ 13–912 through 13–919 of this subtitle.

The Comptroller may not pay a refund of excess motor carrier tax credit unless the motor carrier has complied with Title 9, Subtitle 2 of this article and regulations adopted under it for a full registration year and the Comptroller, in the Comptroller’s discretion, allows the refund.
For a claim of refund for sales and use tax, the Comptroller shall either:

paragraph.text: pay the refund; or
allow a credit of the amount of the refund on subsequent sales and use tax payments due from the claimant.

subsection.text: If requested by a claimant on a form provided by the Comptroller, the Comptroller shall directly deposit portions of an income tax refund into at least two accounts at one or more financial institutions.
In this section, “register” means the register of wills of a county.

paragraph.text: If a person is required to pay inheritance tax the payment of which would reduce the Maryland estate tax imposed on an estate and would entitle the estate to a Maryland estate tax refund, on the written request of the personal representative of the estate, the Comptroller may pay directly to the register, to be applied against the inheritance tax, any Maryland estate tax refund to which the estate would be entitled as a result of the payment of the inheritance tax.

If a person becomes entitled to an inheritance tax refund the payment of which would result in an increase in the Maryland estate tax imposed on an estate, on the written request of the person making a claim for the inheritance tax refund or if a claim for an inheritance tax refund has not been made, the register may pay the inheritance tax refund directly to the Comptroller to be applied against any unpaid Maryland estate tax or additional Maryland estate tax that would become due as a result of the inheritance tax refund.

subsection.text: If a payment from the Comptroller to the register or from the register to the Comptroller under subsection (b) of this section does not discharge a person’s tax liability in its entirety, the person shall pay any remaining unpaid inheritance tax to the register or any remaining unpaid Maryland estate tax to the Comptroller.

Payment by the Comptroller to the register or by the register to the Comptroller under subsection (b) of this section shall satisfy the obligation of the register or Comptroller to pay a refund to the extent of the payment.

If the tax collector determines that collection of financial institution franchise tax or income tax is not warranted because of the administration and collection costs involved, the tax collector may abate the tax or any interest, penalties or charges relative to the tax.

paragraph.text: The income tax imposed under this article shall be abated in the case of any individual:

subparagraph.text: who dies while in active service as a member of the armed forces of the United States, if such death occurs while serving in a combat zone or as a result of wounds, disease, or injury incurred while so serving; or

who dies while a military or civilian employee of the United States, if such death occurs as a result of wounds or injury incurred while the individual was a military or civilian employee of the United States and which were incurred outside the United States in a terroristic or military action.

paragraph.text: The abatement of tax shall have the same effect and shall apply to the same taxable years as provided under § 692 of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: Without regard to the provisions of § 13-1104 of this title, if the tax collector determines a person’s financial institution franchise tax or income tax for multiple taxable years and simultaneously finds both overpayments and deficiencies in those taxable years, the tax collector:

paragraph.text: may offset the deficiencies to the extent of the overpayments; but
may not allow a refund that is barred under Subtitle 11 of this title.

subsection.text: An overpayment determined under subsection (a) of this section may not be applied as an offset to a deficiency in any taxable year other than the years included in the Comptroller’s determination under subsection (a) of this section.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Central Collection Unit” means the Central Collection Unit in the Department of Budget and Management.

paragraph.text: “Debt” means:

subparagraph.text: a liquidated sum due and owing any State agency that has accrued through contract, subrogation, tort, operation of law, or other cause of action, regardless of whether there is an outstanding judgment for that sum; or
a delinquent restitution account on a judgment of restitution referred to the Unit for collection under § 11-616 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

paragraph.text: “Debt” includes converted funds as defined in § 15-122.2 of the Health - General Article.

subsection.text: “Debtor” means:

paragraph.text: a person owing a debt to a State agency that has not been adjudged satisfied by court order, set aside by court order, or discharged in bankruptcy; or
a defendant or liable parent in arrears of restitution payments whose account has been referred to the Central Collection Unit under § 11-616 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

subsection.text: “State agency” means any agency, association, board, bureau, college, commission, committee, council, foundation, fund, department, institute, institution, public corporation, service, trust, university, the Maryland Higher Education Loan Corporation, or other unit of State government, including any subunit of these agencies.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, for any debt not excepted by law from the Central Collection Unit’s responsibilities under Title 3, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article or otherwise, the Central Collection Unit may:

subparagraph.text: certify to the Comptroller the existence of any debt that has been referred to it for collection by a State agency; and
request the Comptroller to withhold the sum certified from any income tax refund to which a debtor is entitled.

paragraph.text: A debt may not be withheld if the State agency or the Central Collection Unit has been advised by the Attorney General that the validity of the debt is legitimately in dispute or an alternate means of collection is pending and believed to be adequate.

The Department of Budget and Management shall establish by regulation those classes or categories of debts, including any minimum debt amount, that may be referred to the Central Collection Unit for withholding.

Subject to § 13-918 of this subtitle, if more than one State agency is owed money by the same debtor, any amount withheld from an income tax refund shall be applied in the order of referral of the debt by the State agencies.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the withholding of debt from an income tax refund authorized by this part does not preclude use of any other remedy provided by law for the collection of debts owed to the State and this part shall be liberally construed to effectuate its purposes.

This part shall be interpreted in a manner that does not deprive a debtor of any rights or defenses that would be available to that debtor in defending against a claim of setoff incident to a judicial proceeding.

subsection.text: At least 30 calendar days before certifying a debt to the Comptroller, the Central Collection Unit shall notify the debtor in writing that it intends to request the Comptroller to withhold the debt from any income tax refund due the debtor.
The notice required under subsection (a) of this section shall advise the debtor of:

paragraph.text: the amount due and owing;
the basis of the debt;
the opportunity to request an investigation of the debt;
the opportunity to contest any adverse determination after an investigation in a hearing before the Central Collection Unit; and
the right to a judicial appeal of a final action by the Central Collection Unit.
A certification by the Central Collection Unit to the Comptroller shall be made on or before November 1 of each calendar year in the form that the Comptroller prescribes.
The certification shall include:

subparagraph.text: the full name and address of the debtor and any other names known to be used by the debtor;
the Social Security number or federal tax identification number of the debtor; and
the amount of the debt.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall:

subparagraph.text: withhold any income tax refund that may be due to a debtor whose name has been certified by the Central Collection Unit; and
pay to the Central Collection Unit the entire refund or the amount certified by the Central Collection Unit, whichever is less.

paragraph.text: All moneys paid to the Central Collection Unit by the Comptroller under this part shall be disposed of by the Central Collection Unit as provided in § 3-305 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Any income tax refund in excess of the certified amount shall be paid to the debtor.
The Comptroller shall notify the debtor of:

subparagraph.text: any amount paid to the Central Collection Unit; and
the debtor’s right:

sub-subparagraph.text: to request an investigation by the Central Collection Unit of the validity of the debt or correctness of the amount; and
to an administrative hearing and judicial appeal if the Central Collection Unit makes a determination adverse to the debtor.

paragraph.text: If a debtor has filed a joint income tax return and the debt is not the liability of both taxpayers, the Comptroller may not withhold that portion of an income tax refund attributable to the individual not owing the debt.

After receiving certification of a debt from the Central Collection Unit, the Comptroller shall promptly notify the Central Collection Unit if the Comptroller determines that a withholding cannot be made.
If an income tax refund is insufficient to satisfy a debt, the Comptroller may withhold amounts from subsequent income tax refunds due a debtor until the debt is extinguished.
Partial payments of the debt shall first be applied against accrued interest, if any, and then to the principal amount of the debt.
Interest on a debt may be withheld at the rate established for that debt by law or contract.

subsection.text: Except for the amount of any income tax refund to which a debtor is entitled, the Comptroller may not disclose any item contained on a State or federal tax return or information required by State law to be attached to the State return.
A debtor may request the Central Collection Unit to investigate a debt:

paragraph.text: after notification from the Central Collection Unit under § 13-914 of this subtitle that the Central Collection Unit intends to request the Comptroller to withhold the debt from any income tax refund due the debtor; or
within 30 days after notification from the Comptroller under § 13-915 of this subtitle that a debt has been withheld.
On receipt of a request for an investigation, the Central Collection Unit shall investigate any questioned debt with the State agency that referred the debt.
The Central Collection Unit shall make a written determination within 15 calendar days after it receives a request for investigation from the debtor.
If the Central Collection Unit determines that a referral or certification is in error, it shall, as appropriate:

subparagraph.text: correct the referral or certification;
discontinue certification procedures; or
promptly remit to the debtor any amounts that have been improperly withheld.

paragraph.text: After its investigation, if the Central Collection Unit makes a determination adverse to the debtor, it shall promptly advise the debtor of the debtor’s right to request a hearing on unresolved factual issues before the Central Collection Unit in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

Except for good cause shown, a request for a hearing before the Central Collection Unit must be made within 30 days after the date of notification of the debtor of an adverse determination by the Central Collection Unit following an investigation.
The State agency that referred the debt to the Central Collection Unit may be made a party in any hearing before the Central Collection Unit.
An issue may not be considered at the hearing that has been previously litigated.
Within 15 days after receipt of a timely or otherwise proper request for a hearing under this subsection, the debtor shall be notified of the date of the hearing.
After a hearing, if the Central Collection Unit determines that a certification or referral is in error, it shall take appropriate action as described in § 13-916(b)(3) of this subtitle.
A determination by the Central Collection Unit of the validity of the debt or correctness of the amount owed shall be considered as final agency action under the Administrative Procedure Act.

A debtor aggrieved by a final decision of the Central Collection Unit concerning the validity of the debt or correctness of the amount may appeal the decision as provided for contested cases in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

If a debtor disputes a denial by the Comptroller of a claim for an income tax refund on grounds other than the validity of the debt or the correctness of the amount owed and that debtor also is appealing an adverse determination of the Maryland Tax Court under § 13-532 of this title, judicial review of both decisions shall be consolidated.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall honor income tax refund interception requests in the following order:

paragraph.text: a refund interception request to collect an unpaid State, county, or municipal tax;
a refund interception request under Title 10, Subtitle 1, Part II of the Family Law Article;
a refund interception request for converted funds under § 15–122.2 of the Health – General Article;
a refund interception request under § 3–304 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
any other refund interception request by the State, county, or other political subdivision of the State;
a request for intercept made by a taxing official under Part IV of this subtitle; and
a request for intercept made by a federal official under Part VI of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall honor vendor payment interception requests in the same order of priority provided in subsection (a) of this section for honoring income tax refund interception requests.

The Secretary of Budget and Management may adopt regulations relating to the referral of debts by State agencies to the Central Collection Unit and to the administrative procedures authorized under this part.
The Comptroller may adopt regulations relating to the certification and withholding of amounts under this part.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Refund” means an individual’s Maryland income tax refund or any other state’s individual income tax refund.
“Taxing official” means a unit or official of another state charged with the imposition, assessment, or collection of state income taxes.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a taxing official may:

paragraph.text: certify to the Comptroller the existence of an individual’s delinquent income tax liability; and
request the Comptroller to withhold any refund to which the individual is entitled.

subsection.text: A taxing official may not certify or request the Comptroller to withhold a refund unless the laws of the taxing official’s state:

paragraph.text: allow the Comptroller to certify an income tax due;
allow the Comptroller to request the taxing official to withhold the individual’s tax refund; and
provide for the payment of the refund to Maryland.

subsection.text: The withholding of a refund shall be subject to the priorities under § 13-918 of this subtitle.
A certification by a taxing official to the Comptroller shall include:

paragraph.text: the full name and address of the individual and any other names known to be used by the individual;
the Social Security number or federal tax identification number;
the amount of the income tax liability including a detailed statement for each taxable year showing tax, interest, and penalty; and
a statement that all administrative remedies and appeals have been exhausted and that the assessment of tax, interest, and penalty has become final.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall determine if an individual for whom a certification is received is due a refund of Maryland income tax.
As to any individual due a refund, the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: notify the individual of a certification by another state of the existence of an income tax liability;
provide the individual with notice of an opportunity to request a hearing to challenge the certification; and
inform the individual that the hearing may be requested:

subparagraph.text: pursuant to § 13-508 of this title; or
with the taxing official, in accordance with the laws of the state of the taxing official.

subsection.text: If the individual requests a hearing pursuant to § 13-508 of this title, the certification of the taxing official shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the individual’s delinquent income tax liability to the certifying state.
Subject to subsection (f) of this section, the Comptroller may:

paragraph.text: withhold any income tax refund that is due to an individual whose name has been certified by a taxing official;
pay to the other state the entire refund or the amount certified, whichever is less;
pay any income tax refund in excess of the certified amount to the individual; and

if an income tax refund is less than the certified amount, withhold amounts from subsequent income tax refunds due the individual, if the laws of the other state provide that the other state shall withhold subsequent refunds of individuals certified to that state by the Comptroller.

The Comptroller may not withhold or pay to another state an individual’s income tax refund until all administrative and judicial remedies provided under Subtitle 5 of this title and Title 10 of this article have been exhausted.

If an individual filed a joint return, the Comptroller may not withhold or pay to another state the individual’s income tax refund unless the certification includes both names of the individuals jointly owing income tax to the other state.

subsection.text: After receiving a certification from a taxing official, the Comptroller shall notify the other state if the Comptroller determines that a withholding cannot be made.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Local official” means a unit or official of a political subdivision of the State charged with the imposition, assessment, or collection of taxes or other liabilities payable to the political subdivision.
“Refund” means a refund of any tax imposed under Maryland law.

paragraph.text: “Vendor payment” means any payment made by the State or by a political subdivision of the State to any person.
“Vendor payment” includes any expense reimbursement payable to an employee of the State or of a political subdivision of the State.
“Vendor payment” does not include a person’s salary, wages, or pension.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a local official may:

paragraph.text: certify to the Comptroller the existence of a person’s delinquent tax liability or any other liability owed by the person to the local official’s political subdivision; and
request the Comptroller to withhold any refund and vendor payment to which the person is entitled.

subsection.text: A local official may not certify or request the Comptroller to withhold a refund or vendor payment unless the laws of the local official’s political subdivision:

paragraph.text: allow the Comptroller to certify tax due to the State;
allow the Comptroller to request the local official to withhold from any vendor payment the person’s tax due to the State; and
provide for the payment of the amount withheld to the Comptroller.

subsection.text: The withholding of a refund or vendor payment shall be subject to the priorities under § 13-918 of this subtitle.
A certification by a local official to the Comptroller shall include:

paragraph.text: the full name and address of the person and any other names known to be used by the person;
the Social Security number or federal tax identification number, if known;
the amount of the tax or other liability including:

subparagraph.text: a statement indicating the nature of the liability; and
in the case of a liability for taxes, a detailed statement for each taxable year showing tax, interest, and penalty; and

paragraph.text: a statement that all administrative remedies and appeals have been exhausted and that the tax or other liability has become final.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall determine if a person for whom a certification is received is due a refund of Maryland tax or a vendor payment.
Subject to subsection (d) of this section, as to any person due a refund or vendor payment, the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: withhold any refund and vendor payment that is due a person whose name has been certified by a local official;
notify the person of the amount withheld in accordance with the certification by a local official of the existence of a tax or other liability;
pay to the political subdivision the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the entire refund and vendor payment; or
the amount certified;

paragraph.text: pay any refund and vendor payment in excess of the certified amount to the person; and

if the refund and vendor payment is less than the certified amount, withhold amounts from subsequent refunds and vendor payments due the person, if the laws of the political subdivision provide that the political subdivision shall withhold a vendor payment due persons certified to the political subdivision by the Comptroller.

subsection.text: If an individual filed a joint income tax return, the Comptroller may not withhold or pay to a political subdivision the individual’s income tax refund unless the certification includes both names of the individuals filing the joint income tax return.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Federal official” means a unit or official of the federal government charged with the collection of nontax liabilities payable to the federal government pursuant to 31 U.S.C. § 3716.
“Nontax liability due the State” means a liability certified by the Secretary of Budget and Management to the Comptroller.
“Refund” means an amount described as a refund of tax under the provisions of law that authorize its payment.
“Vendor payment”:

paragraph.text: means any payment, other than a refund, made by the State to any person;
includes any expense reimbursement to an employee of the State; and
does not include a person’s salary, wages, or pension.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a federal official may:

paragraph.text: certify to the Comptroller the existence of a person’s delinquent nontax liability owed by the person to the federal government; and
request the Comptroller to withhold any refund and vendor payment to which the person is entitled.

subsection.text: A federal official may certify and request the Comptroller to withhold a refund or vendor payment only if the laws of the United States:

paragraph.text: allow the Comptroller, on behalf of the State, to certify tax and nontax liabilities due to the State;

allow the Comptroller, on behalf of the State, to enter into a reciprocal agreement with the United States, pursuant to which the federal official would be required to offset federal payments to collect delinquent debts owed to the State; and
provide for the payment of the amount withheld to the State.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall apply a refund or vendor payment received from a federal official according to the priorities under § 13-918 of this subtitle.
A certification by a federal official to the Comptroller shall include:

paragraph.text: the full name and address of the person and any other names known to be used by the person;
the Social Security number or federal tax identification number;
the amount of the nontax liability; and
a statement that the debt is past due and legally enforceable in the amount certified and that there are no legal barriers to collection by offset.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall determine if a person for whom a certification is received is due a refund of Maryland tax or a vendor payment.
Subject to § 13-931(b) of this subtitle and subsection (d) of this section, as to any person due a refund or vendor payment, the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: withhold any refund and vendor payment that is due a person whose name has been certified by a federal official;
notify the person of the amount withheld in accordance with the certification by a federal official of the existence of a liability;
pay to the federal official the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the entire refund and vendor payment; or
the amount certified;

paragraph.text: pay any refund and vendor payment in excess of the certified amount to the person; and
withhold amounts from subsequent refunds and vendor payments due the person if the initial refund and vendor payment is less than the certified amount.

subsection.text: If an individual filed a joint income tax return and the debt certified by a federal official is not the liability of both parties to the joint income tax return, the Comptroller may not withhold or pay to the federal official that portion of the income tax refund attributable to the individual not owing the debt.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 451 OF 2012 //

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Refund” means an individual’s Maryland income tax refund.

paragraph.text: “Warrant” means a criminal arrest warrant.
“Warrant” includes a warrant issued for or that results from:

subparagraph.text: a failure to appear before a court of the State;
a violation of the Maryland Vehicle Law that is punishable by a term of confinement; or
a violation of probation.

paragraph.text: “Warrant” does not include a body attachment.

subsection.text: “Warrant official” means an official of the federal, State, or local government charged with serving a warrant.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 451 OF 2012 //

subsection.text: This part applies only to individuals who:

paragraph.text: are residents of Anne Arundel County; or
have an outstanding warrant from Anne Arundel County.

subsection.text: This part does not apply to an individual:

paragraph.text: who is an active duty member of the armed forces of the United States; or
who files a joint Maryland income tax return.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 451 OF 2012 //
A warrant official may:

paragraph.text: certify to the Comptroller the existence of an outstanding warrant for an individual who is a resident of Maryland or who receives income from Maryland; and
request the Comptroller to withhold any refund to which the individual is entitled.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2013 PER CHAPTER 451 OF 2012 //

subsection.text: A certification by a warrant official to the Comptroller shall include:

paragraph.text: the full name and address of the individual and any other names known to be used by the individual;
the Social Security number or federal tax identification number; and
a statement that the warrant is outstanding.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall determine if an individual for whom a certification is received is due a refund.
